posts.title: Backing up Spotify
posts.author: vitplister
posts.title_cn: 备份Spotify
posts.abstract:
该讨论围绕“备份Spotify”展开，核心话题是数字媒体保存的重要性及安娜档案馆大规模抓取Spotify音乐数据引发的争议。多数用户认同数字内容易消失的问题，如链接失效、平台下架歌曲导致播放列表变灰，认为长期保存文化资料具有价值。

讨论中提到，安娜档案馆此前以图书为主，此次涉足音乐可能面临更严厉的法律风险（如RIAA的追责）。有用户指出，此次抓取数据量巨大（约1.86亿条），堪比昔日的“亚历山大图书馆”What.CD，可能帮助找回已从主流平台同步删除的曲目。

但观点存在分歧：有人认为此举对普通用户意义有限，因为Spotify本身便捷，且从庞大种子文件中定位单曲不便；也有用户强调，大规模破解Spotify DRM并公开下载令人震惊，可能引发版权争议。此外，有用户反映该网站在某些地区被网络提供商屏蔽，访问需借助VPN。整体上，社区虽肯定保存数字遗产的初衷，但对实践方式与法律后果看法不一。

comments.author: mvkel
comments.content: This work is so critical.Read an article that was published just 10 years ago, and witness the bit rot as most external links will 404, gone forever.I think it's worth questioning the value of preserving -everything-, but it seems like if we can, we should.
comments.content_cn: 这项工作至关重要。阅读一篇仅仅十年前发表的文章，就能见证链接失效的现象——大多数外部链接都会变成404错误，永远消失。虽然值得思考是否值得保存一切，但似乎只要能做到，我们就应该尽力保存。

comments.author: p0w3n3d
comments.content: This is something really important, especially in the days when music and film vanishes from platforms one by one. I myself have three playlists with greyed out titles (titles are missing so there's no possibility for me to find out what was there).That's why I divide music to the one that I want to have forever - I buy it on CDs - and dance music that I can live without one day
comments.content_cn: 这件事确实非常重要，尤其是在音乐和影视作品接连从平台消失的当下。我自己就有三个歌单里的曲目标题变成了灰色（曲目缺失导致我无法追溯原本的内容）。正因如此，我会把音乐分为两类：一类是希望永久珍藏的——我会购买实体CD；另一类是舞曲这类某天失去也无妨的音乐。

comments.author: djfergus
comments.content: Anna’s Archive has largely flown under the radar by focusing on books.Even perceived involvement in music piracy puts a much bigger target on their back from far more aggressive actors (RIAA, major labels)
comments.content_cn: 安娜档案馆主要通过专注于书籍领域保持低调。一旦被认为涉及音乐盗版，就会招致更强势方（如美国唱片业协会、各大唱片公司）更猛烈的针对。

comments.author: ZeWaka
comments.content: Since the article asks:> We're curious about the peaks at whole minutes (particularly 2:00, 3:00, 4:00). If you know why this is, please let us know!As a hobby video/audio editor, people will start with their track taking up a preset amount and fill up the time - even if it means having some dead space at the end.The other alternative is algorithmically created music.
comments.content_cn: 既然文章提到：> 我们对整分钟（特别是2:00、3:00、4:00）出现峰值感到好奇。如果您知道原因，请告诉我们！作为一名业余视频/音频编辑爱好者，人们通常会从预设时长开始制作音轨，并填满时间——即使这意味着末尾会留有一些空白。另一种可能是算法生成的音乐。

comments.author: Etheryte
comments.content: To put this into perspective, What.CD [0] was widely considered to be the music library of Alexandria, unparalleled in both its high quality standard and it's depth. What had in the ballpark of a few million torrents when it got raided and shut down. Anna's rip of Spotify includes roughly 186 million unique records. Granted, the tail end is a mixed bag of bot music and whatnot, but the scale is staggering.[0] https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/What.CD
comments.content_cn: 从这个角度来看，What.CD [0] 曾被广泛视为音乐界的亚历山大图书馆，其高品质标准和深度无与伦比。在被突击搜查并关闭时，它拥有大约数百万个种子文件。而安娜对Spotify的抓取包含了约1.86亿条独特记录。诚然，末尾部分混杂着机器人音乐等内容，但其规模仍然令人震惊。[0] https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/What.CD

comments.author: bob1029
comments.content: I recall many interesting tracks that were very aggressively deleted from all platforms in sync. I wonder if I could find them in this archive.There is contemporary lost media being created every day because of how we distribute things now. I think in some cases, the intent of the publisher was to literally destroy every copy of the information. I understand the legal arguments for this, but from a spiritual perspective, this is one of the most offensive things I can imagine. Intentionally destroying all copies of a creative work is simply evil. I don't care how you frame it.Making media effectively lost is not much different in my mind. Is it available if it's sitting on a tape in an iron mountain bunker that no one will ever look at again?
comments.content_cn: 我记得许多有趣的曲目曾同步从所有平台被激进地删除。不知能否在这个档案中找到它们。由于当今的传播方式，每天都有当代的遗失媒体在不断产生。我认为在某些情况下，发布者的意图确实是彻底销毁信息的每一份副本。我理解这背后的法律依据，但从精神层面来看，这简直是我能想象到最令人反感的行为之一。故意销毁创意作品的所有副本就是纯粹的恶行，无论你如何粉饰。在我看来，让媒体实质上消失与此并无太大区别。如果它只是封存在铁山堡垒的磁带里，再无人问津，那还能算真正存在吗？

comments.author: crazygringo
comments.content: This is insane.I definitely was not aware Spotify DRM had been cracked to enable downloading at scale like this.The thing is, this doesn't even seem particularly useful for average consumers/listeners, since Spotify itself is so convenient, and trying to locate individual tracks in massive torrent files of presumably 10,000's of tracks each sounds horrible.But this does seem like it will be a godsend for researchers working on things like music classification and generation. The only thing is, you can't really publicly admit exactly what dataset you trained/tested on...?Definitely wondering if this was in response to desire from AI researchers/companies who wanted this stuff. Or if the major record labels already license their entire catalogs for training purposes cheaply enough, so this really is just solely intended as a preservation effort?
comments.content_cn: 这太疯狂了。我完全没意识到Spotify的DRM已被破解，能实现如此大规模的下载。问题是，这对普通消费者或听众来说似乎并不特别有用，因为Spotify本身已经非常方便，而试图在可能包含数万首曲目的庞大种子文件中定位单曲，听起来简直可怕。但这对于从事音乐分类和生成等研究的人员来说，似乎将是一大福音。唯一的问题是，你无法公开承认训练或测试所用的具体数据集……？我很好奇这是否是为了回应AI研究人员或公司对此类数据的需求。或者，各大唱片公司是否已经以足够低廉的价格授权了整个曲库用于训练目的，因此这真的只是一项纯粹的保存工作？

comments.author: tristanc
comments.content: This is one of the greatest news I've ever heard for the digital preservation community. Just so many projects over the years could have used resources like this. Thank you for contributing to humankind!
comments.content_cn: 这是数字保存领域有史以来最令人振奋的消息之一。多年来有太多项目本可以借助这样的资源。感谢您为人类作出的贡献！

comments.author: yoan9224
comments.content:
The metadata alone is incredibly valuable for researchers. Having 186 million ISRCs catalogued with associated genre, tempo, and popularity data is a goldmine for music analysis that doesn't even require touching the audio files.  I've always found it interesting how streaming services have become the de facto music library of record, yet they can and do remove content at will. When Spotify pulled out of Russia, entire catalogs became inaccessible. Physical media and personal archives suddenly matter again in ways we thought were obsolete.

  The copyright discussion is complex, but from a pure preservation standpoint, I'm glad someone is doing this work.
comments.content_cn:
仅元数据本身对研究者就具有难以置信的价值。将1.86亿条ISRC编码与对应的流派、节奏和流行度数据编目收录，这简直是音乐分析的金矿，甚至无需触及音频文件本身。我一直觉得有趣的是，流媒体服务如何成为事实上的音乐资料库，但它们却能够且确实会随意下架内容。当Spotify退出俄罗斯市场时，整个音乐目录便无法访问。实体媒介和个人档案的重要性突然以我们曾认为过时的方式重新凸显。

版权讨论固然复杂，但从纯粹的保存角度来看，我很高兴有人在从事这项工作。

comments.content: Hmmm I don’t like this. There are sources for music with better quality out there and all this will do is paint them a bigger target for takedowns/prosecution. I am worried about losing their ebook library. Quoting from the announcement: “Generally speaking, music is already fairly well preserved.“ They should have done this as a separate identity.
comments.content_cn: 嗯，我不太赞同这个做法。明明有音质更好的音乐资源渠道，这样做只会让他们更容易成为被打击或起诉的目标。我担心会失去他们的电子书库。引用公告里的话：“总的来说，音乐保存得已经相当不错了。”他们本应该以独立身份来做这件事。

comments.author: performative
comments.content: this is a really incredible effort. but, for the developers and analysts currently working with music metadata in a world where so much of music is being consumed thru streaming services that keep a tight hold on how their metadata and album art can be used, i am constantly yearning for a way to link streaming releases to public metadata sources that can be manipulated, embedded, and queried. i've done my best to build my own w/o a background in data science, but it's a hole that desperately needs filling to enable the new generation of scrobbling/music listening habit exploration.
comments.content_cn: 这确实是一项令人惊叹的尝试。然而，在当前这个音乐主要通过流媒体服务消费的时代，这些平台对元数据和专辑封面的使用有着严格限制。对于像我这样从事音乐元数据工作的开发者和分析师而言，我们始终渴望能找到一种方法，将流媒体平台的发行内容与可自由处理、嵌入和查询的公共元数据源关联起来。尽管没有数据科学背景，我已尽力自行构建解决方案，但这一空白亟需填补，才能支撑新一代的音乐播放记录与听歌习惯分析的发展。

comments.author: shevy-java
comments.content:
Hmm. This is actually not really something I need, I think; but
I consider anna's archive etc... as about as important as the
internet web archive. We need to preserve data, at the least
important data, also historic data - how the original websites
looked. Creativity of past generations. Same for games and books.It may be only ~30 years for webpages to have emerged, but there
are also many young people who may not have experienced that since
they are too young to have experienced it. There is always a 
generational change; our generation has the opportunity to store
more things.
comments.content_cn: 嗯。这其实并不是我真正需要的东西，我想；但我认为安娜档案馆等……其重要性不亚于互联网网页档案馆。我们需要保存数据，至少是重要的数据，还有历史数据——原始网站的模样。过去世代的创造力。游戏和书籍也是如此。网页的出现可能只有大约30年，但也有许多年轻人可能没有经历过，因为他们太年轻了。世代更迭总是存在的；我们这一代有机会存储更多的东西。

comments.author: WD-42
comments.content: Incredible.> A while ago, we discovered a way to scrape Spotify at scale.They wont and shouldn’t divulge the details, but I imagine that would be a fun read!
comments.content_cn: 太不可思议了。> 不久前，我们发现了一种大规模抓取Spotify数据的方法。他们不会也不应该透露细节，但我想那读起来会很有趣！

comments.author: yegle
comments.content: Not that we should, but it's technically feasible to have a music streaming server with the torrent as the backend, and selectively download the part of the torrent in respond to on-demand streaming request from the client.
comments.content_cn: 并非我们应该这样做，但从技术上讲，以种子文件为后端搭建音乐流媒体服务器是可行的，并且能够根据客户端的点播流请求选择性地下载种子文件中的相应部分。

comments.author: xandrius
comments.content: Truly amazing work. I couldn't help but being sad of the less popular songs not being currently stored, as those are definitely the ones more in risk of being lost forever.If you like the goal and you have even a few 100gb available on your server, consider "donating" some of that space to seeding the data (music or books). It's absolutely how we can fight the system, even if just a tiny bit. https://annas-archive.org/torrents
comments.content_cn: 这真是令人惊叹的工作。我不禁为那些目前未被保存的冷门歌曲感到难过，因为它们确实更有可能永远消失。如果你认同这个目标，并且服务器上还有几百GB的可用空间，请考虑“捐赠”部分空间来为这些数据（音乐或书籍）做种。这绝对是我们对抗体制的方式，哪怕只是微小的努力。https://annas-archive.org/torrents

comments.author: gorbachev
comments.content: Quoting from their page:--------------This is by far the largest music metadata database that is publicly available. For comparison, we have 256 million tracks, while others have 50-150 million. Our data is well-annotated: MusicBrainz has 5 million unique ISRCs, while our database has 186 million.--------------If they truly are on a mission to protect world's information from disappearing, they should work with MusicBrainz to get this data on it.Alternatively, it would be amazing, if they built a MusicBrainz like service around it.In either case, to make the data truly useful, they'd need to solve the problem on how to match the metadata to a fingerprint used to identify the music tracks,  assuming that data is not part of the metadata they collected.
comments.content_cn: 引用自他们的页面：这是迄今为止公开可用的最大音乐元数据库。作为对比，我们拥有2.56亿首曲目，而其他数据库仅有5000万至1.5亿首。我们的数据标注完善：MusicBrainz收录了500万个独立ISRC编码，而我们的数据库则拥有1.86亿个。如果他们真正致力于保护世界信息免遭消失，就应该与MusicBrainz合作，将这些数据纳入其中。或者，如果他们能围绕这些数据构建类似MusicBrainz的服务，那将非常了不起。无论哪种情况，要使这些数据真正发挥作用，他们都需要解决如何将元数据与用于识别音乐曲目的音频指纹相匹配的问题——前提是该数据不属于他们已收集的元数据范畴。

comments.author: syntaxing
comments.content: Moral and legal discussion aside, this is technically very impressive. I also wouldn’t be surprised if this somehow kickstarts open source music generative AI from China.
comments.content_cn: 抛开道德和法律层面的讨论，这项技术本身令人印象深刻。如果它因此推动中国开源音乐生成人工智能的发展，我也不会感到意外。

comments.content: You know, I had the (at time of writing) 600 something comments ran through Opus 4.5 and do a summary of the sentiments. It could't find a single comment that genuinely defends Spotify or expresses sympathy for the company.HN crowd is, of course, biased in the technocratic sense, but you see - everyone seems to actually rejoice the move.The closest to remorse is `linhns` and `locusofself` expressing concern about artists getting hurt (not Spotify itself), but locusofself prefaces with "I hate spotify as a company but..."(disclaimer: this text is NOT LLM generated, I wrote myself a summary of the summary. here's the Claude thread should anyone care https://claude.ai/share/cfc4ca63-2b9e-47ac-a360-202025d1a134)
comments.content_cn: 要知道，我（撰写时）已经用Opus 4.5分析了600多条评论并总结了其中的情绪倾向。它找不到任何一条真正为Spotify辩护或对公司表示同情的评论。HN群体在技术官僚意义上当然存在偏见，但你看——大家似乎都在为这一举措感到高兴。最接近懊悔情绪的是`linhns`和`locusofself`对艺术家可能受到伤害（而非Spotify本身）的担忧，但locusofself开头就表明“我讨厌Spotify这家公司，不过……”（声明：这段文字并非由LLM生成，是我自己对总结的再总结。这是Claude讨论串，有兴趣可查看 https://claude.ai/share/cfc4ca63-2b9e-47ac-a360-202025d1a134）

comments.author: eightys3v3n
comments.content:
I really appreciate platforms that still show the titles and metadada after something is removed. Then at least I can go find it again to maintain my collection.
Tidal does this.
comments.content_cn:
我真的很欣赏那些在内容被移除后仍保留标题和元数据的平台。这样至少我还能重新找到它们来维护我的收藏。
Tidal就做到了这一点。

comments.author: pmdr
comments.content: The bulk of today's customers has no idea how to pirate music, so they're not really a threat anymore. Music streaming has been rather convenient, you pretty much get the same content across all services. Video streaming platforms have, unfortunately become fragmented and, as of late, ad-ridden.
comments.content_cn: 如今大多数顾客根本不知道如何盗版音乐，所以他们已不再构成实质威胁。音乐流媒体服务相当便捷，各平台提供的内容基本一致。遗憾的是，视频流媒体平台却逐渐走向割裂，且近来广告泛滥成灾。

comments.author: nemomarx
comments.content: I've heard 2:00 is some kinda sweet spot for the Spotify algorithm and payouts? You get paid per play so you don't want to it too long, but if your track is much shorter than two minutes you get penalized or something. I know they've had to remove ambient tracks that were cut into 40 second clips as part of this.So you might see a lot of anchoring just like YouTube videos kept stretching to almost exactly ten minutes?
comments.content_cn: 听说Spotify算法和收益分配有个两分钟左右的甜点区间？按播放次数计费所以时长不宜过长，但若曲目远短于两分钟又会受到惩罚。我知道平台为此下架过被切割成40秒片段的环境音乐。所以就像YouTube视频总卡着十分钟时长那样，现在很多作品也开始锚定这个时长了吧？

comments.author: flxy
comments.content: I think what earned what.cd that title wasn't necessarily just the amount but the quality, as you mentioned, as well as the obscurity of a lot of the offered material. I remember finding an early EP of an unknown local band on there, and I live in the middle of nowhere in Europe. There were also quite a few really old and niche records on there which possibly couldn't be put on streaming services due to the ownership of rights being unknown. It was the equivalent of vinyl crate digging without physical restrictions.Additionally there was a lot of discourse about music and a lot of curated discovery mechanisms I sorely miss to this day. An algorithm is no replacement for the amount of time and care people put into the web of similar artists, playlists of recommendations and reviews. Despite it being piracy, music consumption through it felt more purposeful. It's introduced me to some of my all time favourite artists, which I've seen live and own records and merchandise of.
comments.content_cn: 我认为，让what.cd获得这一称号的，不仅仅是其庞大的数量，更在于您所提及的高质量以及大量材料的稀有性。我记得在那上面找到过一个不知名本地乐队的早期EP，而我住在欧洲一个偏远地区。那里还有许多非常古老且小众的唱片，可能因为版权归属不明而无法上架流媒体平台。这就像不受物理限制的实体唱片挖掘过程。此外，平台上还有许多关于音乐的讨论和精心策划的发现机制，这些至今仍让我十分怀念。算法无法替代人们投入在相似艺术家网络、推荐歌单和乐评中的时间与心血。尽管这是盗版行为，但通过它欣赏音乐却显得更有目的性。它让我认识了一些我一生中最喜爱的艺术家，我曾现场观看他们的演出，并收藏了他们的唱片和周边产品。

comments.author: gorbachev
comments.content: Flippant response: If it's ok for Meta for commercial use, why not for researchers for legitimate research work?More serious response: research is explicitly included in fair use protections in US copyright law. News organizations regularly use leaked / stolen copyrighted material in investigative journalism.
comments.content_cn: 轻率回应：既然Meta能用于商业用途，为何研究人员不能用于合法的科研工作？严肃回应：美国版权法明确将研究纳入合理使用保护范围。新闻机构在调查报道中经常使用泄露/窃取的受版权保护材料。

comments.author: paraknight
comments.content: What.cd were extreme sticklers for quality! When you applied to get in, they did a live interview on IRC to test your knowledge of ripping, transcoding, and different kinds of compression, how torrents and private trackers work, and their code of conduct. I remember studying for it. They also had ways to make sure you weren't cheating like checking your screen, as well as very aggressive automated checks for VPNs and blocklisted IPs to prevent ban evasion and multiple accounts.They also had good incentive structures for keeping the bar high -- you could get kicked out for having a bad ratio, so the easiest way to pump your upload up was to fulfil obscure requests for FLACs you could purchase online but were extremely difficult to purchase (if you're lucky it's just an unknown artist on Bandcamp). I discovered a lot of obscure music this way, some that I'm still looking for to this day after it shut down.Because I cared so much about being part of that private tracker, this is what also prompted me to rent a seedbox for the first time. I paid in Bitcoin out of paranoia (I lived in Germany where the fines for piracy are HEFTY, and they actually do come after you) back when Bitcoin wasn't really worth that much, and later found that that old wallet suddenly had a couple thousand in it instead of the spare change I couldn't move!

该平台还通过巧妙的激励机制维持高标准——用户若分享率过低会被清退，而提升上传量最便捷的方式就是满足那些冷门无损音频的求种需求。这些资源虽可在线购买，但实际获取难度极高（运气好的话可能只是Bandcamp上某位无名艺术家的作品）。通过这种方式，我发现了大量小众音乐，有些甚至在网站关闭后至今仍在寻找。

comments.content_cn: 我宁愿下载音乐和购买黑胶唱片，尤其是来自小众艺术家的作品，也不愿订阅Spotify。这样他们能获得更多分成，而我也能得到一些实在的东西，尽管可能不太实用。唯一讽刺的是，很多小众艺术家只印制极少量的黑胶唱片，我不明白他们为什么不让人们购买他们的作品？也许是为了营造“限量感”，但这感觉真是蠢透了。

posts.title: I can't upgrade to Windows 11, now leave me alone
posts.author: firefoxd
posts.title_cn: 无法升级至Windows 11，请勿打扰。
posts.abstract:
该讨论围绕Windows 11升级的强制性与用户自主权展开。核心话题是用户对现代操作系统不断推送更新、捆绑服务的不满，认为这侵犯了个人设备的控制权。

许多用户怀念早期系统如Windows 95的简洁性，认为当前系统充斥着营销推送和自动更新，破坏了用户体验。有用户指出，微软通过TPM 2.0等硬件要求制造了不必要的电子垃圾，环保承诺形同虚设。也有用户认为，工作设备与个人设备应严格分离，公司提供的电脑应视为“隔离区”。

讨论中提到，部分用户转向Linux作为解决方案，认为近年来的发行版如Bazzite已高度成熟、稳定，甚至游戏兼容性优于Windows。另有用户提供了通过修改注册表阻止Windows 11升级的技术方法。在升级必要性上存在分歧：有人认为旧设备若无损坏无需更换，因为硬件性能提升有限且价格持续上涨；也有观点认为企业环境需服从统一管理。

共识在于，用户普遍反感系统对个人选择的过度干预，追求更简单、自主的计算体验。

comments.author: linguae
comments.content: I miss the days when personal computers were simply tools, akin to pencils and handheld calculators.  I remember the days of Macintosh System 7 and Windows 95.  No upselling services.  No automatic updates.  No nagging.  You turned your computer on, executed programs, and that was it.On the Windows side, things started going downhill starting with the Windows XP era, and on the Mac the annoyances began sometime in the mid-2010s.It seems Microsoft, Apple, and other companies realized that they’re leaving money on the table by not exploiting their platforms.  Thus, they’re no longer selling simple tools, but rather they are selling us services.Yes, there are good Linux distributions that don’t annoy me, and the BSDs never nag me, but the problem with switching to these platforms is that I still need Microsoft Office and other proprietary software tools that are not available outside “Big Tech.”  There are other matters that make switching away from Windows and macOS challenging, such as hardware support and laptop battery life.
comments.content_cn: 我怀念个人电脑还只是简单工具的时代，就像铅笔和手持计算器那样。我记得Macintosh System 7和Windows 95的日子。没有升级服务的推销，没有自动更新，没有烦人的提示。你打开电脑，运行程序，仅此而已。在Windows方面，情况从XP时代开始走下坡路；而在Mac这边，烦恼大约始于2010年代中期。微软、苹果和其他公司似乎意识到，不利用他们的平台就是在白白浪费赚钱机会。因此，他们不再销售简单的工具，而是在向我们推销服务。是的，有些优秀的Linux发行版不会打扰我，BSD系统也从不会烦扰我，但转向这些平台的问题在于，我仍然需要Microsoft Office和其他专有软件工具，而这些在"大科技"公司之外是无法获得的。还有其他一些因素使得脱离Windows和macOS变得困难，比如硬件支持和笔记本电脑的电池续航。

comments.author: isolatedsystem
comments.content: Easy answer to your last point: Work machine and Non-work machine. If I'm working for a company and the company needs MS Office, they will give me a machine with MS Office. I will treat that machine like a radioactive zone. Full Hazmat suit. Not a shred of personal interaction with that machine. It exists only to do work on and that's that. The company can take care of keeping it up to date, and the company's IT department can do the bending over the table on my behest as MS approaches with dildos marked "Copilot" or "Recall" or "Cortana" or "React Native Start Menu" or "OneDrive" or whatever.Meanwhile, my personal machine continues to be Linux.This is what I'm doing at my work now. I'm lucky enough to have two computers, a desktop PC that runs Linux, and a laptop with Windows 11. I do not use that laptop unless I have to deal with xlsx, pptx or docx files. Life is so much better.
comments.content_cn:
对你最后一点有个简单的解决办法：工作机和非工作机分开。如果我为公司工作，公司需要微软Office，他们会给我一台装有Office的电脑。我会把那台机器当作辐射区对待——全套防护服，绝不与那台机器产生任何私人互动。它只用于工作，仅此而已。公司可以负责保持系统更新，当微软带着标有“Copilot”“Recall”“Cortana”“React Native开始菜单”“OneDrive”之类玩意儿来折腾时，公司的IT部门可以替我应付这些麻烦。

与此同时，我的个人电脑继续使用Linux。这就是我目前的工作方式：很幸运有两台电脑，一台跑Linux的台式机，一台装Windows 11的笔记本。除非必须处理xlsx、pptx或docx文件，否则我绝不碰那台笔记本。生活质量显著提升。

comments.author: drnick1
comments.content: The Penguin is calling.
comments.content_cn: 企鹅在呼唤。

comments.author: jjaksic
comments.content: Linux has made an insane amount of progress in recent years. Atomic distros like Bazzite and Aurora are so polished, modern, easy to use, and virtually unbreakable. Even most Windows games work perfectly out of the box (often better than on Windows). Anyone who tried Linux in the past and wasn't happy, should take another look. These distros are so incredible it's hard to believe.Meanwhile Windows has been getting worse and worse. Completely unreasonable and unnecessary hardware requirements, spyware, constantly running antivirus and other processes you don't want, forced updates and reboots, shoving AI down your throat. In other words, you pay money to have a worse experience and less control over your own PC.I've been ideologically opposed to Windows for a while, but a few years ago Linux required many trade-offs and compromises, to the point I wouldn't have recommended to most people. But now things are completely different and I would happily recommend it to anyone except those who have a hard requirement for MS software (or Adobe).
comments.content_cn:
近年来Linux取得了惊人的进步。像Bazzite和Aurora这样的原子发行版如此精致、现代、易用，几乎坚不可摧。甚至大多数Windows游戏都能开箱即用（通常比在Windows上运行得更好）。任何过去尝试过Linux但不满意的用户，都应该重新审视。这些发行版如此不可思议，令人难以置信。

与此同时，Windows却变得越来越糟糕。完全不合理且不必要的硬件要求、间谍软件、持续运行你不需要的杀毒软件和其他进程、强制更新和重启、强行灌输AI功能。换句话说，你花钱买来的却是更差的体验和对个人电脑更少的控制权。

我在理念上反对Windows已有一段时间，但几年前Linux还需要许多权衡和妥协，以至于我不会向大多数人推荐。但现在情况完全不同了，我会很乐意推荐给任何人，除了那些对微软软件（或Adobe）有硬性需求的用户。

comments.author: petcat
comments.content: > at this point a Windows machine only belongs to you in name. Microsoft can run arbitrary code on it.I get what the author is trying to say, but...like... obviously?
comments.content_cn: 此刻，一台Windows电脑名义上只属于你。微软可以在上面运行任意代码。我明白作者想表达什么，但……这难道不是显而易见的吗？

comments.author: eswat
comments.content: Sad to look back years ago when the first mobile apps started adopting this "Remind Me Later"-only dark pattern and is now festering everyday drivers like your OS.Between these and services that suddenly suffer from amnesia and spamming me with marketing notifications and emails after months or years of silence, it’s becoming more tiring to use any service that grows significantly enough where they don’t need to care about what their users actually want.
comments.content_cn: 回首多年前，当首批移动应用开始采用这种仅提供“稍后提醒”的黑暗模式时，不禁令人感到悲哀。如今这种模式已像操作系统一样，在日常使用中不断恶化。无论是这类设计，还是那些突然“失忆”、在沉寂数月或数年后开始用营销通知和邮件轰炸用户的服务，都让人愈发疲惫。任何发展到足够大规模的服务，似乎都越来越不关心用户的真实需求了。

comments.author: gmponyo
comments.content: Do yourself a favor and start using Linux on both machines.
comments.content_cn: 给自己行个方便，两台机器都开始用Linux吧。

comments.author: Animats
comments.content:
Why would anyone want to buy a new computer now unless the old one is worn out?
There is no price/performance improvement. Nor will there be for the next five years or so. NVidia says to expect 10% price increases each year. DRAM prices have doubled, and Samsung says not to expect price cuts. Micron just exited the retail RAM business.Microsoft is trying to escape this trap by pivoting to Windows as a subscription service. It will get worse, not better.
comments.content_cn:
除非旧电脑已经用坏，否则现在谁会想买新电脑呢？
价格性能比没有任何提升，未来五年左右也不会有。英伟达表示预计每年涨价10%。DRAM价格已经翻倍，三星表示不要指望降价。美光刚刚退出了零售内存业务。微软正试图通过将Windows转变为订阅服务来摆脱这一困境。情况只会变得更糟，不会好转。

comments.author: beached_whale
comments.content: Microsoft with the push to require TPM 2.0, that isn't really required, is responsible for huge amounts of new e-waste.  Any green initiative they claim is out the door.
comments.content_cn: 微软强制要求TPM 2.0这一并非真正必要的举措，导致了大量新的电子垃圾。他们宣称的任何环保倡议都因此化为泡影。

comments.author: hoherd
comments.content: A few days ago I started up an old Windows 10 laptop that I haven't used in a few years so my son could play a game that I haven't taken the time to set up in proton on linux. I was amazed at how much the Windows OS experience seems like an unhealthy relationship where the OS is trying to manipulate you and control you. It feels like it's not even my computer, it's a Microsoft owned kiosk that I'm allowed to partially use.Another really remarkable thing is how cloud connected it is. For instance, the lock screen had online feeds shown. The setting to disable them is on a remote website, not in the screensaver prefs or some other local system pref. That was astonishing, and IMHO absurd. If it hadn't been clear to me before, that made it crystal clear that what MS wants the OS to be and what I want the OS of my personal computer to be are not remotely the same thing.
comments.content_cn:
几天前，我启动了一台多年未用的旧Windows 10笔记本电脑，为了让儿子玩一款我还没时间在Linux的Proton上配置的游戏。我惊讶地发现，Windows操作系统的体验就像一段不健康的关系——系统似乎总在试图操控和支配用户。感觉这甚至不是我的电脑，而是一个微软拥有的终端机，只允许我部分使用。

另一个令人印象深刻的特点是它高度依赖云端连接。例如，锁屏界面会显示在线资讯流。关闭该功能的设置竟然在远程网页上，而非屏幕保护程序偏好设置或其他本地系统选项中。这实在令人震惊，在我看来简直荒谬。如果说之前还不够明确，这件事让我彻底明白：微软对操作系统的定位与我个人对电脑操作系统的期待，根本是天壤之别。

comments.author: nfriedly
comments.content: I used Rufus to make a Windows 11 installer USB drive that bypasses the TPM check and online account setup and a couple of other things. I've been using that along with O&O Shut Up 10++, and Firefox with uBlock Origin to refresh computers for local folks.With the "requirements" check bypassed, Windows 11 actually runs on the Intel 1st gen Core i-series and newer, as well as any Ryzen CPU and, I think, a couple of earlier AMD generations. (It requires the popcount instruction, which isn't present on the Core 2 and older.)Anything older gets Windows 10 IoT which gets updates until 2032.
comments.content_cn: 我使用Rufus制作了一个Windows 11安装U盘，可以绕过TPM检测、在线账户设置等限制。我一直在配合O&O Shut Up 10++以及搭载uBlock Origin的Firefox浏览器，为本地用户重装电脑系统。绕过“硬件要求”检测后，Windows 11实际上能在第一代英特尔酷睿i系列及更新的处理器、所有锐龙CPU以及部分更早的AMD架构上运行（需要支持popcount指令，酷睿2及更早的处理器不具备此功能）。更老的设备则安装Windows 10物联网版，该系统将获得支持直到2032年。

comments.author: mastazi
comments.content: For many types of users, Windows is no longer viable. I have friends who work at a .NET shop and most of that team now uses Macs. Unthinkable just a few years ago. Meanwhile, I checked  ProtonDB and now 90% of my Steam library is Platinum or Native. So I finally switched my gaming PC to Linux. Microsoft's priorities are elsewhere, Windows doesn't have a bright future.
comments.content_cn: 对许多类型的用户而言，Windows已不再适用。我有朋友在.NET开发公司工作，他们团队现在大部分人都在用Mac。这在几年前简直无法想象。与此同时，我查看了ProtonDB的数据，现在我的Steam游戏库中90%的作品都达到了白金兼容或原生支持级别。所以我最终将游戏电脑换成了Linux系统。微软的重心已转向别处，Windows的未来并不光明。

comments.author: CommenterPerson
comments.content: I ordered a basic Windows laptop, it comes with Windows 11. It's going to be my Linux starter computer. I'm not a computer person. Wish me luck!
comments.content_cn: 我订购了一台基础款的Windows笔记本电脑，预装了Windows 11系统。这将是我学习Linux的入门电脑。我不是很懂电脑技术，祝我好运吧！

comments.author: prmoustache
comments.content:

NetBSD
OpenBSD

Haiku
Plan9
Redox
ReactOS
Debian Gnu/Hurd

Genode SculptOSAnd probably some others I haven't heard of. Using Windows in 2025 AND complaining about it is complaining about a self inflicted wound.
comments.content_cn: 到2025年末，已有众多替代选择：Linux、FreeBSD、NetBSD、OpenBSD、DragonflyBSD、Haiku、Plan9、Redox、ReactOS、Debian Gnu/Hurd、FreeDOS、Genode SculptOS，可能还有其他一些我没听说过的系统。在2025年还坚持使用Windows并抱怨它，无异于为自找的麻烦发牢骚。

comments.author: garyfirestorm
comments.content: And it’s not just TPM. I have tpm module however they don’t support my Intel 7700K processor.
comments.content_cn: 这不仅仅是TPM的问题。我拥有TPM模块，但它不支持我的英特尔7700K处理器。

comments.author: markus_zhang
comments.content: There must be a way to disable this thing. Maybe we can disable the service? But anyway I already switched to Linux for my daily usage. It is not smooth as Windows due to driver issues and other weird things, like Firefox crashing frequently when I’m typing in a text box like this one, but still feels better than Windows.The Windows team and its product manager is determined to trash the product. Good work!
comments.content_cn: 肯定有办法禁用这东西。或许我们可以停用这项服务？不过反正我已经转用Linux作为日常系统了。虽然因为驱动问题和其他奇怪状况（比如在类似这样的文本框里打字时Firefox经常崩溃），用起来不如Windows流畅，但感觉还是比Windows强。Windows团队和他们的产品经理铁了心要毁了这个产品。干得漂亮！

comments.author: haskellandrust
comments.content: Okay, I’ll bite. Tell me the linux laptop to get, and the distro to use. Cost is no issue, but suspend/hibernate has to work and so does fractional scaling. Also WiFi.
comments.content_cn: 好吧，我上钩了。告诉我该买哪款Linux笔记本，以及该用哪个发行版。价格不是问题，但休眠/睡眠功能必须能用，分数缩放也要支持。还有WiFi也得正常。

comments.author: Melatonic
comments.content: Switch to Win10 LTSC iOT if you want to keep getting security updates for many yearsBonus is it strips out all the crap and is super fastDownside is a few specific pieces of software refuse to install (for no good technical reason). Adobe Photoshop for exampleThere is also win11 LTSC iOT which I believe might actually install on older hardware that normal win11 will not (don't quote me on this)
comments.content_cn: 若想在未来多年持续获得安全更新，请转用Windows 10 LTSC IoT版本。额外好处是它剔除了所有无用组件，运行速度极快。缺点在于少数特定软件会无故拒绝安装（缺乏合理技术原因），例如Adobe Photoshop。此外还有Windows 11 LTSC IoT版本，据信它甚至能在普通Win11无法安装的旧硬件上运行（此说法未经官方证实）。

comments.author: damion6
comments.content: Use Rufus it'll disable hardware requirements, without hassle.  You will need an iso.  If you know someone with 11 have them download it.  Otherwise download the generic.
comments.content_cn: 使用Rufus，它会轻松禁用硬件要求。你需要一个ISO文件。如果你认识有Windows 11的人，请让他们下载。否则就下载通用版本。

comments.author: canyp
comments.content: The most egregious thing in recent iterations of Win11 is that a fresh installation will basically map all of your home folder to OneDrive. My Documents, My Pictures, My Music, etc. A recent Windows update also told me that I need OneDrive now to back up my files. Yup, apparently you really, really need it.
comments.content_cn: 近期Windows 11版本中最令人反感的一点是，全新安装系统后基本会将你的整个用户文件夹映射到OneDrive上——包括"我的文档"、"我的图片"、"我的音乐"等目录。最近一次系统更新甚至提示我现在必须使用OneDrive来备份文件。没错，微软显然在极力暗示你"真的非常需要"这项服务。

comments.author: throwaway613745
comments.content: Ultimately, I didn't switch to Linux because I wanted to.  I switched to Linux because Microsoft became so actively hostile to me I felt like I didn't have any other choice.No Microsoft, I'm not buying new hardware just to get the new OS.  No, I'm not going to let you nag me every single day until I get pissed off enough to.  No, I will not tolerate all the little things in your OS that piss me off everyday.  Your software sucks.  Your filesystem sucks.  Your constant nagging sucks.  I don't want your cloud TPM security bullshit and I DEFINITELY don't want Copilot or Recall.Seriously Microsoft: fuck you.Giving up being able to play certain games - which require me to install malware into my computer anyway -  is a small price to pay to have my sanity and freedom back.  I own my computer, not you.  Goodbye and good riddance.I already used MacOS and Linux for work anyway.  But don't worry Apple, you're riding that line pretty dangerously too - you're gonna be next on the chopping block if you don't get your act together.  Framework Desktop is looking like a mighty capable replacement for my Mac Studio.
comments.content_cn:
最终，我转向Linux并非出于自愿，而是因为微软变得如此充满敌意，让我觉得别无选择。微软，我不会为了新系统就去买新硬件；也不会每天忍受你的骚扰直到忍无可忍；更不会容忍你系统中那些日复一日惹恼我的琐碎问题。你的软件糟透了，文件系统糟透了，没完没了的弹窗也糟透了。我不需要你那套云TPM安全废话，更绝对不想要Copilot或Recall功能。

说真的，微软：去你的吧。

放弃某些游戏——反正那些游戏也得让我在电脑里安装恶意软件——换回理智和自由，这笔交易很划算。我的电脑属于我，而不是你。再见吧，总算摆脱你了。

反正工作早就用MacOS和Linux了。不过苹果你也别得意，你也在危险边缘试探——再不收敛点，下一个被淘汰的就是你。Framework台式机看起来完全能替代我的Mac Studio。

comments.author: neilv
comments.content: Apt username, for a pragmatic strategy.A variation I've done occasionally is to run the Microsoft Windows software in a VM on my Linux laptop.When I last had the MS office suite inflicted upon me, a couple years ago, I was able to run it in a Web browser on Linux.It's important to remember, though, that these measures probably won't work long-term.Historically, MS will tend to shamelessly do whatever underhanded things they can get away with at that point in time.  The only exception being when they are playing a long con, in which case they will pretend to play nice, until some threshold of lock-in (or re-lock-in) is achieved, and only then mask-off, with no sense of shame.  (It's usually not originating bottom-up from the ICs, and I know some nice people from there, but upper corporate is totally like that, demonstrating it again and again, for decades.)Also, a company requiring to run Microsoft software is probably also a bad place to work in other regards.

comments.author: tzs
comments.content: The internet was a big part of it. Most home users did not have internet access in the System 7 days. When it came out in 1991 no country had more than 1% of its population with internet access. By the time Windows 95 came out around 10% of US users had internet access.It wasn't until 2001 that the US reached 50% of users having internet access.Without internet there wasn't really a good way to distribute updates to most users.As a developer in that era working at a company that made software for PCs and Macs it was great. It meant that the way most users would get our software was buying it on floppy disk (or later CD) from a retail software store like CompUSA or Egghead.We'd only make more money from someone who bought our software if that software made a good enough impression that they bought more of our software. We'd lose money if any software went out with enough bugs or a confusing enough interface or a poorly enough written manual that a lot of people made a lot of calls to our toll free tech support.This was great because it largely aligned what developers wanted to do (write a feature complete program with a great UI and no bugs) and what management wanted (happy users who do not call tech support).With internet giving us the ability to push updates at almost zero cost and as often as we want people who release incomplete programs early and add the missing parts in updates are going to outcompete people who don't release until the program is complete and nearly bug free.Once you get there it is not much of a leap to decide that what you are really selling is not software to do X but rather the service of providing software to do X. Customers subscribe to that service and you continuously improve its ability to do X.
comments.content_cn:
互联网在其中扮演了重要角色。在System 7时代，大多数家庭用户并未接入互联网。1991年该系统问世时，没有任何国家的互联网普及率超过1%。到Windows 95面世时，美国约有10%的用户能访问互联网。直到2001年，美国的互联网用户比例才达到50%。在没有互联网的情况下，向大多数用户分发更新实际上缺乏有效途径。

作为那个时代的开发者，在一家为PC和Mac开发软件的公司工作，这种情况非常理想。这意味着大多数用户需要通过CompUSA或Egghead等零售软件商店购买软盘（后来是光盘）来获取我们的软件。只有当用户对我们的软件印象深刻并购买更多产品时，我们才能从他们身上获得更多收益。如果软件存在过多漏洞、界面混乱或手册编写不当，导致大量用户拨打我们的免费技术支持电话，我们就会蒙受损失。

这种模式非常有效，因为它基本统一了开发者的目标（开发功能完善、界面优秀且无漏洞的程序）与管理层的期望（用户满意且无需寻求技术支持）。随着互联网让我们能够以近乎零成本频繁推送更新，那些早期发布不完整程序并通过更新补全功能的人，将比那些等到程序完善、几乎无漏洞才发布的人更具竞争力……

comments.author: tombert
comments.content: I think Haiku is in that "last 5%" phase.  They have something that is 95% of the way there, it's 95% cool, but frustratingly, that last 5% is really important; there's a lot of boring, thankless work with any software that has broad reach.Most people don't like doing it, but in order for the operating system to be "good", you really need most of this unsexy stuff to work; you need to be able to easily install WiFi drivers, you need to support most modern video cards, you need to suss out the minutia of the graphics APIs, you need to test every possible edge case in the filesystem, you need to ensure that file associations are consistent, etc.I've mentioned this before, but this is part of what I respect so much about the Wine project.  It's been going on for decades, each release gets a little better, and a lot of that work is almost certainly the thankless boring stuff that is absolutely necessary to get Wine to be "production ready".I ran Haiku a bit on an old laptop, and I do actually like it. It's ridiculously fast and snappy (even beating Linux in some cases), and I really do wish them the best, but as of right now I don't think it's viable quite yet. I'm not 100% sure how they're going to tackle GPU drivers (since GPU drivers are almost an entire OS in their own right), but I would love to have something FOSS that takes us out of the codified mediocrity of POSIX.
comments.content_cn:
我认为Haiku正处于那“最后5%”的阶段。他们已经完成了95%的工作，实现了95%的酷炫功能，但令人沮丧的是，最后那5%至关重要；任何具有广泛影响力的软件都包含大量枯燥且不被感激的工作。大多数人并不喜欢做这些，但为了让操作系统变得“优秀”，这些不起眼的工作大多必须正常运行：你需要能够轻松安装WiFi驱动，需要支持大多数现代显卡，需要深挖图形API的细节，需要测试文件系统中所有可能的边缘情况，需要确保文件关联的一致性等等。

我之前提到过，这正是我对Wine项目如此敬佩的部分原因。它已经持续开发了几十年，每个版本都有所改进，其中很多工作几乎可以肯定就是那些不被感激却绝对必要的枯燥任务，正是这些让Wine变得“可用于生产环境”。

我在一台旧笔记本上短暂运行过Haiku，实际上我确实喜欢它。它快得离谱，反应敏捷（在某些情况下甚至超过Linux），我真心祝愿他们一切顺利，但就目前而言，我认为它还不够成熟。我不完全确定他们将如何解决GPU驱动问题（因为GPU驱动本身几乎就是一个完整的操作系统），但我非常希望能有一个开源方案，带我们摆脱POSIX那种固化的平庸状态。

posts.author: rbanffy
posts.title_cn: 美国以机密为由全面阻止海上风电建设
posts.abstract: 该讨论围绕美国政府以国家安全为由全面暂停海上风电建设的决定展开。核心争议在于官方给出的“机密原因”是否合理。有用户指出，风力涡轮机叶片确实可能对沿海雷达监测造成干扰，影响低空防御，但这一技术问题自上世纪90年代就已存在，且中国、英国等国家已在军事雷达附近成功运营大量海上风电项目，表明该问题可通过工程手段解决。许多用户质疑其背后存在政治动机，认为这是化石燃料游说集团施加影响的结果，旨在打压非碳基能源发展。也有用户批评此举是政府为维护传统能源利益而采取的极端措施，可能导致能源价格进一步上涨。讨论中普遍对官方解释持怀疑态度，多数观点倾向于认为该决定更多出于政治经济考量而非纯粹的技术安全因素。

posts.title: Waymo halts service during S.F. blackout after causing traffic jams
posts.author: rwoll
posts.title_cn: Waymo在旧金山停电期间造成交通堵塞后暂停服务
posts.abstract: 该讨论围绕Waymo自动驾驶出租车在旧金山停电期间因交通堵塞而暂停服务的事件展开。核心争议在于自动驾驶车辆在突发情况下的应对能力。有用户指出，Waymo在交通灯失灵时表现得过于谨慎，导致车辆缓慢通过路口，反而加剧了拥堵；也有用户认为公众对自动驾驶过于苛刻，人类驾驶同样存在违规，但自动驾驶的微小失误却容易引发过度批评。讨论中提到，停电这类常见场景本应被提前预见，Waymo的应对不足暴露了其系统在边缘案例上的缺陷。部分用户担忧，在重大灾害时此类问题可能阻碍应急服务。此外，有观点质疑监管方应要求公司公开其所能处理的特殊场景清单。整体上，社区虽认同自动驾驶需更完善，但对如何平衡安全性、效率与现实道路复杂性存在分歧。

comments.author: cjsplat
comments.content: I was driving across the east side of SF and hit a patch of lights that were out.The Waymo's were just going really slow through the intersection. It seemed that the "light is out means 4-way stop" dynamic caused them to go into ultra-timid mode. And of course the human drivers did the typical slow and roll, with decent interleaving.The result was that each Waymo took about 4x as long to get through the intersections. I saw one Waymo get bluffed out of its driving slot by cross traffic for perhaps 8 slots.This was coupled with the fact that the Waymos seemed to all be following the same route. I saw a line of about a dozen trying to turn left, which is the trickiest thing to navigate.And of course I saw one driver get pissed off and drive around a Waymo that was advancing slowly, with the predictable result that the Waymo stopped and lost three more slots through the intersection.On normal days, Waymos are much better at the 4-way stops than they used to be a few years back, by which I mean they are no longer dangerously timid. The Zoox (Amazon) cars are more like the Waymos used to be.I expect there will be some software tweaks that will improve this situation, both routing around self-induced congestion and reading and crossing streets with dead lights.Note that I didn't see any actually dead Waymos as others have reported here. I believe this is an extreme failsafe mode, and perhaps related to just too much weirdness for the software to handle.It would be interesting to see the internal post mortem.
comments.content_cn:
我驾车穿过旧金山东区时，遇到一片交通灯失灵的路段。Waymo自动驾驶车在通过路口时速度非常缓慢。似乎是“信号灯失灵即视为全向停车”的规则触发了它们的极端谨慎模式。而人类司机则照常缓慢滑行通过，车辆交替通行也较为顺畅。结果每辆Waymo通过路口的时间大约是人类车辆的四倍。我曾看到一辆Waymo被横向车流逼退，可能连续错过了八个通行时机。

另一个情况是这些Waymo似乎都在遵循相同路线。我看到约十几辆车排成长队试图左转——这本身就是最具挑战性的驾驶操作。当然，我还目睹一位司机因不耐烦而超车绕过缓慢前进的Waymo，结果可想而知：那辆Waymo立即停车，又错过了三个通行时机。

在日常情况下，Waymo在全向停车路口的处理能力已比几年前进步很多，至少不再因过度谨慎而引发危险。相比之下，Zoox（亚马逊旗下）车辆的表现更接近早期的Waymo。

预计软件优化将改善这种状况，既能规避自动驾驶车造成的拥堵，也能更好应对信号灯失灵的路口。需要说明的是，我并未像其他网友所说看到完全瘫痪的Waymo。我认为这属于极端安全模式，可能是系统遇到过多异常状况时的应对机制。

若能看到……

comments.author: ssl-3
comments.content: I've been through long blackouts.My own experience has given me a somewhat more-nuanced take.At first, it's akin to the path of evil.  Way too many people just zoom through intersections with dark traffic lights like they're cruising unimpeded down the Interstate, obvious to their surroundings.  Some people get grumpy and lay on the horn as if to motivate those in front of them to fly through themselves.But many people do stop, observe, and proceed when it is both appropriate and safe.After awhile, it calms down substantially.  The local municipality rounds up enough stop signs to plant in the middle of the intersections that people seem to actually be learning what to do (as unlikely as that sounds).By day 2 or 3, it's still somewhat chaotic -- but it seems "safe" in that the majority of the people understand what to do (it's just stop sign -- it may be a stop sign at an amazingly-complex intersection, but it's still just a stop sign) and the flyers are infrequent-enough to look out for.By day 5 or 6, traffic flows more-or-less fine and it feels like the traffic lights were never necessary to begin with.  People stop.  They take turns.  They use their turn signals like their lives depend on it.  And the flyers apparently have flown off to somewhere else.  It seems impossible to behold, but I've seen it.But SF's outage seems likely to be a lot shorter than that timeline, and I definitely agree with Waymo taking the cautious route.(but I also see reports that they just left these cars in the middle of the road.  That's NFG.)
comments.content_cn:
我曾经历过长时间停电。个人经历让我对此有了更细致的看法。起初，这有点像通往混乱的道路。太多人在交通信号灯熄灭的路口飞驰而过，仿佛在高速公路上畅通无阻地巡航，完全无视周围环境。有些人变得暴躁，不停按喇叭，好像这样就能催促前面的人冲过去。但也有很多人会停下来观察，在合适且安全的时候再通过。

一段时间后，情况会大幅好转。当地市政部门在路口中央设置了足够多的停车标志，人们似乎真的学会了该怎么做（尽管听起来不太可能）。到了第二天或第三天，虽然仍有些混乱——但感觉上已经“安全”了，因为大多数人明白该怎么做（这不过是个停车标志——可能是在异常复杂的路口，但终究只是个停车标志），而那些横冲直撞的司机也少到足以让人留意防范。

到了第五六天，交通基本顺畅，感觉好像红绿灯从来就不需要似的。人们会停车，会轮流通过，打转向灯时认真得像性命攸关。那些横冲直撞的司机显然也消失到别处去了。这听起来不可思议，但我亲眼见过。

但旧金山的停电时间似乎远短于这个周期，我完全同意Waymo采取谨慎行事的做法。（不过我也看到报道说他们只是撤离了……）

comments.author: namibj
comments.content:
Huh, here in Germany we have street signs (mostly of a "you are the priority road" 45° rotated square yellow-on-white "sunny side up egg" sign and the "you are not the priority road" down-pointing white-on-red triangle; for 3-way if the priority road isn't the straight road or the concept of straight is ambiguous, there's a supplemental sign depicting the path of the priority road) permanently on traffic lights; it's also common enough for non-major roads to have the lights turned off at night so drivers tend to be familiar with falling back to the signs when the lights are off.In absence of priority roads there is also the "right before left" rule which means that the car coming from the right if they would conflict in time is the car that has priority.

posts.title: History LLMs: Models trained exclusively on pre-1913 texts
posts.author: iamwil
posts.title_cn: 历史专用大语言模型：仅基于1913年前文本训练的模型
posts.abstract: 该讨论围绕一个仅使用1913年前文本训练的历史语言模型展开。核心话题是这种时间锁定模型能否提供独特的历史视角，以及其训练数据限制带来的特性。有人认为这类模型能避免现代知识的“后见之明污染”，更真实地体现历史语境；也有用户指出其训练数据量相对较小却效果显著，证明质量可能比数量更重要。讨论中提到模型对一战等后续事件一无所知，这种“惊讶感”是现代模型无法复现的。分歧点在于技术实现：用户好奇模型如何解释自身存在（如被问及计算机原理时的反应），以及如何通过监督微调构建对话能力而不破坏预训练获得的历史判断。普遍认同的是，这种非主流探索极具价值，其生成文本因脱离现代语料而更难被识别为AI所写。还有用户设想用它探索科学史，例如模型能否基于1905年狭义相对论论文逐步推导出广义相对论。

comments.author: saaaaaam

It can be surprised by your questions in ways modern LLMs cannot.”“Modern LLMs suffer from hindsight contamination. GPT-5 knows how the story ends—WWI, the League's failure, the Spanish flu.”This is really fascinating. As someone who reads a lot of history and historical fiction I think this is really intriguing. Imagine having a conversation with someone genuinely from the period, where they don’t know the “end of the story”.

comments.author: kazinator
comments.content: > Why not just prompt GPT-5 to "roleplay" 1913?Because it will perform token completion driven by weights coming from training data newer than 1913 with no way to turn that off.It can't be asked to pretend that it wasn't trained on documents that didn't exist in 1913.The LLM cannot reprogram its own weights to remove the influence of selected materials; that kind of introspection is not there.Not to mention that many documents are either undated, or carry secondary dates, like the dates of their own creation rather than the creation of the ideas they contain.Human minds don't have a time stamp on everything they know, either. If I ask someone, "talk to me using nothing but the vocabulary you knew on your fifteenth birthday", they couldn't do it. Either they would comply by using some ridiculously conservative vocabulary of words that a five-year-old would know, or else they will accidentally use words they didn't in fact know at fifteen. For some words you know where you got them from by association with learning events. Others, you don't remember; they are not attached to a time.Or: solve this problem using nothing but the knowledge and skills you had on January 1st, 2001.> GPT-5 knows how the story endsNo, it doesn't. It has no concept of story.  GPT-5 is built on texts which contain the story ending, and GPT-5 cannot refrain from predicting tokens across those texts due to their imprint in its weights. That's all there is to it.The LLM doesn't know an ass from a hole in the ground. If there are texts which discuss and distinguish asses from holes in the ground, it can write similar texts, which look like the work of someone learned in the area of asses and holes in the ground. Writing similar texts is not knowing and understanding.
comments.content_cn:
为什么不直接让GPT-5“角色扮演”1913年呢？因为它会基于晚于1913年的训练数据权重进行标记补全，且无法关闭此功能。我们无法要求它假装自己未曾训练过那些1913年不存在的文档。大型语言模型无法通过自我重编程来消除特定材料对其权重的影响——这种内省能力尚不存在。更何况许多文档要么未标注日期，要么带有次要日期（如文档本身的创建时间而非其中思想的产生时间）。人类心智也不会为所有认知内容标注时间戳。如果我要求某人“仅使用你十五岁生日时所掌握的词汇与我交谈”，他们也无法做到：要么勉强使用五岁孩童都懂的极端保守词汇，要么无意中用到十五岁时实际并未掌握的词语。有些词汇你能通过关联学习事件追溯来源，另一些则毫无时间印记——你根本不记得何时习得。同理：若要求“仅运用2001年1月1日前掌握的知识技能解决此问题”，人类同样难以实现。

> GPT-5知道故事结局
不，它并不知道。它根本没有“故事”的概念。GPT-5的构建基于包含故事结局的文本，而这些文本已烙印在其权重中，导致模型无法避免基于这些文本进行标记预测。仅此而已。大型语言模型连基本辨识能力都……

comments.author: libraryofbabel
comments.content: I used to teach 19th-century history, and the responses definitely sound like a Victorian-era writer. And they of course sound like writing (books and periodicals etc) rather than "chat": as other responders allude to, the fine-tuning or RL process for making them good at conversation was presumably quite different from what is used for most chatbots, and they're leaning very heavily into the pre-training texts. We don't have any living Victorians to RLHF on: we just have what they wrote.To go a little deeper on the idea of 19th-century "chat": I did a PhD on this period and yet I would be hard-pushed to tell you what actual 19th-century conversations were like. There are plenty of literary depictions of conversation from the 19th century of presumably varying levels of accuracy, but we don't really have great direct historical sources of everyday human conversations until sound recording technology got good in the 20th century. Even good 19th-century transcripts of actual human speech tend to be from formal things like court testimony or parliamentary speeches, not everyday interactions. The vast majority of human communication in the premodern past was the spoken word, and it's almost all invisible in the historical sources.Anyway, this is a really interesting project, and I'm looking forward to trying the models out myself!

comments.author: EvgeniyZh
comments.content: It's worth noting that this is "compute-bound optimal", i.e., given fixed compute, the optimal choice is 20:1.Under Chinchilla model the larger model always performs better than the small one if trained on the same amount of data. I'm not sure if it is true empirically, and probably 1-10B is a good guess for how large the model trained on 80B tokens should be.Similarly, the small models continue to improve beyond 20:1 ratio, and current models are trained on much more data. You could train a better performing model using the same compute, but it would be larger which is not always desirable.
comments.content_cn: 值得注意的是，这是“计算受限下的最优解”，即在固定计算资源下，20:1的比例是最优选择。根据Chinchilla模型，若在相同数据量上训练，大模型的表现总是优于小模型。我不确定这一结论是否经得起实证检验，但基于800亿词元训练时，模型规模在10亿到100亿之间可能是一个合理的估计范围。同样，小模型在超过20:1的比例后仍能持续提升，而当前模型通常使用更多数据进行训练。虽然利用相同计算资源可以训练出性能更优的模型，但这往往意味着模型规模更大，而大模型并非总是理想选择。

We haven't seen what these researchers are doing to release -- and from what I can tell, they haven't said yet. At the moment I see "Repositories (coming soon)" on their GitHub page.

posts.title: Flock Exposed Its AI-Powered Cameras to the Internet. We Tracked Ourselves
posts.content: Archive Link: https://archive.ph/IWMKeAlso: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=vU1-uiUlHTo – This Flock Camera Leak is like Netflix For Stalkers
posts.author: chaps
posts.title_cn: Flock将其AI摄像头暴露于互联网。我们追踪了自己。
posts.content_cn:
存档链接：https://archive.ph/IWMKe
另附：https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=vU1-uiUlHTo – 此次Flock摄像头数据泄露堪比偷窥者的“奈飞”盛宴
posts.abstract:
该HackerNews帖子讨论了Flock公司AI监控摄像头暴露在互联网上的安全漏洞事件。核心话题聚焦于公共监控技术的隐私风险与安全缺陷。

社区讨论呈现明显分歧。部分用户严厉批评Flock的安全漏洞，认为其默认设置可能导致儿童失踪等严重后果，甚至存在刑事过失嫌疑。有用户指出，这类系统虽因“公共场所无隐私期待”而合法，但公众对持续追踪与数据永久化缺乏认知。也有用户提出，若监控不可避免，公开访问权限或许能分散权力并提高公众警惕性。

讨论中形成共识的是对监控社会化的深切忧虑。多位用户引用《1984》隐喻，强调真正的威胁来自“互相监视”的社会常态化，尤其在硬件成本降低与软件激励结合的背景下，监控网络正快速扩张。视频报告者与FlockCEO将安全研究者称为“恐怖组织”的激烈反应，进一步加剧了社区对科技公司权力失衡的担忧。

comments.author: dogman144
comments.content: Was fortunate to talk to a security lead who built the data-driven policing network for a major American city that was an early adopter. ALPR vendors like Flock either heavily augment and/or anchor the tech setups.What was notable to me is the following, and it’s why I think a career spent on either security researching, or going to law school and suing, these vendors into the ground over 20 years would be the ultimate act of civil service:1. It’s not just Flock cams. It’s the data eng into these networks - 18 wheeler feed cams, flock cams, retail user nest cams, traffic cams, ISP data sales2. All in one hub, all searchable by your local PD and also the local PD across state lines who doesn’t like your abortion/marijuana/gun/whatever laws, and relying on:3. The PD to setup and maintain proper RBAC in a nationwide surveillance network that is 100%, for sure, no doubt about it (wait how did that Texas cop track the abortion into Indiana/Illinois…?), configured for least privilege.4. Or if the PD doesn’t want flock in town, they reinstall cameras against the ruling (Illinois iirc?) or just say “we have the feeds for the DoT cameras in/out of town and the truckers through town so might as well have control over it, PD!”Layer the above with the current trend in the US, and 2025 model Nissan uploading stop-by-stop geolocation and telematics to cloud (then, sold into flock? Does even knowing for sure if it does or doesn’t even matter?)Very bad line of companies. Again all is from primary sources who helped implement it over the years. If you spend enough time at cybersecurity conferences you’ll meet people with these jobs.
comments.content_cn:
有幸与一位安全主管交谈，他为一个早期采用此技术的美国大城市构建了数据驱动的警务网络。像Flock这样的自动车牌识别供应商极大地增强和/或支撑了这些技术架构。令我印象深刻的是以下几点，这也正是为什么我认为，用二十年时间从事安全研究，或攻读法律并起诉这些供应商直至其破产，将成为最高形式的公共服务：

1. 这不仅仅是Flock摄像头。关键在于将这些网络的数据工程化——包括18轮卡车的车载摄像头、Flock摄像头、零售用户的Nest摄像头、交通摄像头，以及互联网服务提供商的数据销售。
2. 所有数据汇集于一个中心枢纽，不仅可由本地警察部门搜索，也可被其他州界外不认同你所在州关于堕胎/大麻/枪支等法律的警察部门访问，且这一切依赖于：
3. 警方在一个全国性监控网络中建立并维护适当的基于角色的访问控制——该系统必须（等等，那个德克萨斯警察是如何追踪堕胎记录到印第安纳/伊利诺伊州的……？）百分之百确保按最小权限原则配置。
4. 或者，如果当地警方不希望Flock进入城镇，他们会违反规定（如果没记错是伊利诺伊州？）重新安装摄像头，或直接声称“我们已经掌握了进出城的交通部摄像头及穿越城镇的卡车司机数据流，警方不如直接接管控制权！”

结合上述情况与当前美国趋势，以及2025款日产汽车将逐站地理定位和远程信息数据上传至云端（然后是否售给Flock？即使确切知道是否如此又有何意义？），这类公司的发展路径极为糟糕。重申，所有信息均来自公关……

comments.content: I would love to watch a shorter version of this video that just discussed the deltas between the status quo and Flock, rather than breathlessly reporting the implications of cameras as if they were distinctive to Flock. He'll spend 30 seconds talking about how you can see every activity and every person on the camera --- yeah, that's how cameras work. There are thousands of public IP cameras on the Internet, aimed at intersections, public streets, houses, playgrounds, schools; most of them operated that way deliberately.There are Flock-specific bad things happening here, but you have to dig through the video to get to them, and they're not intuitive. The new Flock "Condor" cameras are apparently auto-PTZ, meaning that when they detect motion, they zoom in on it. That's new! I want to hear more about that, and less about "I had tears in my eyes watching this camera footage of a children's playground", which is something you could have done last week or last year or last decade, or about a mental health police wellness detention somewhere where all the cops were already wearing FOIA-able body cams.If open Flock cameras gave you the Flock search bar, that would be the end of the world. And the possibility that could happen is a good reason to push back on Flock. But that's not what happened here.
comments.content_cn: 我更希望看到一个精简版视频，直接讨论现状与Flock监控系统的差异，而不是用夸张语气渲染摄像头的监控意义——仿佛这是Flock独有的特性。视频花了30秒讲述如何通过摄像头看到所有活动和每个人，但这不过是摄像头的基本功能。互联网上现有成千上万的公共IP摄像头对准十字路口、街道、住宅、游乐场和学校，其中绝大多数本就为此设计。Flock真正存在的问题需要深挖视频内容才能发现，且并不直观。新款Flock"Condor"摄像头显然具备自动云台变焦功能，能在检测到动静时自动放大追踪——这才是新特性！我更想多了解这方面信息，而不是听那些"观看儿童游乐场监控录像时我热泪盈眶"的叙述，这种监控体验十年前就能实现；或是谈论早已配备执法记录仪的警局心理健康拘留案例。如果开放的Flock摄像头直接配备搜索栏功能，那将引发严重后果，这种可能性正是抵制Flock的合理理由，但当前视频并未触及核心问题。

posts.title: You’re not burnt out, you’re existentially starving
posts.author: thanedar
posts.title_cn: 你不是精疲力竭，而是存在性饥饿
posts.abstract:
该讨论围绕一篇关于职业倦怠与存在性空虚的文章展开。核心话题是探讨现代人感到疲惫的深层原因是否源于缺乏人生意义，而非单纯工作过度。多数用户认同文章部分观点，认为寻找生活意义对缓解倦怠有积极作用，但也指出其分析存在局限。

讨论中提到，有人认为文章提出的“周一早晨兴奋度测试”忽略了享乐适应现象，即即使有意义的工作也会随时间变得平淡。也有用户指出，真正的职业倦怠常源于过度工作或生活压力，例如照顾家庭或应对繁琐行政事务，而非仅因缺乏目标。部分用户批评文章后半段偏向自我推销，削弱了说服力。

社区共识在于区分倦怠与抑郁症，强调若出现持续无力感应寻求专业帮助。分歧点主要在于对文章价值的评判：一些用户认为其引发了有益反思，另一些则认为其解决方案过于简化现实困境。

comments.author: yoan9224
comments.content: The premise is interesting but feels incomplete. The "Monday morning excitement test" doesn't account for the hedonic treadmill - even meaningful work becomes mundane once your brain adjusts to it.Also, many people are genuinely burnt out from overwork, not just existential malaise. When you're juggling demanding work, family responsibilities, and barely have time for basic self-care, the problem isn't finding your "highest purpose" - it's structural.That said, I agree that meaning matters. But meaning doesn't always come from work. Sometimes the healthiest thing is treating work as necessary fuel for a meaningful life outside of it - relationships, hobbies, community involvement.The "go into politics" solution is fascinating though. Zero-sum games as existential fulfillment feels counterintuitive.
comments.content_cn:
这个前提很有趣但感觉不完整。"周一早晨兴奋度测试"没有考虑到享乐适应现象——即使是意义深远的工作，一旦大脑适应后也会变得平淡。此外，很多人确实是因过度工作而精疲力竭，不仅仅是存在性焦虑。当你同时应付高强度工作、家庭责任，连基本自我照顾的时间都没有时，问题不在于寻找"最高人生目标"，而是结构性困境。

不过，我认同意义很重要。但意义并不总是来自工作。有时最健康的方式是把工作视为维持工作外有意义生活的必要燃料——比如人际关系、兴趣爱好、社区参与。

但"从政"这个解决方案很有意思。把零和博弈当作存在意义的实现方式，这似乎有违直觉。

comments.author: thanedar
comments.content: You get off the hedonic treadmill by getting into something deeper like politics.I do feel like I'm an example of someone who's juggled marriage, kids, startups, etc. where how I finally got a clean source of sustainable energy was having a part of my life to truly chase my highest potential. And to me that's politics, and specifically anticorruption and Positive Politics.Glad that the "go into politics" ideas piqued your interest!
comments.content_cn: 摆脱享乐主义跑步机的方法是投身于更深层次的事物，比如政治。我确实觉得自己是一个兼顾婚姻、子女、创业等事务的例子，而我最终获得可持续的纯粹能量来源，正是通过让生活的一部分去真正追逐自己的最高潜能。对我来说，这就是政治，特别是反腐败和积极政治。很高兴“投身政治”的想法引起了你的兴趣！

comments.author: AlexB138
comments.content: This first half of this definitely struck a chord. I spent the first three quarters of this year taking care of a terminally ill parent, then seeing them through hospice. If that sort of experience doesn't make a person step back from their life and question what they're doing nothing will.I decided to step away from my job as an engineering VP and try something I actually wanted to do. It's terrifying, especially in this economy, but I wake up and feel excitement in the morning instead of dread for the first time in as long as I can remember.
comments.content_cn: 这段话的前半部分确实引起了我的共鸣。今年前三个季度，我一直在照顾一位身患绝症的父亲，并陪伴他走完临终关怀的全过程。如果这样的经历都不能让一个人停下脚步、反思自己的生活，那恐怕再也没有什么能让人醒悟了。我决定辞去工程副总裁的职位，去尝试自己真正想做的事。这令人惶恐，尤其是在当前的经济环境下，但长久以来第一次，我清晨醒来时感受到的是兴奋而非恐惧。

comments.author: aster0id
comments.content: I agree with the premise but take issue with the measure for "success": do you feel excited to get up and work on Monday?We're humans and no matter what you're pursuing, you'll hit a point where your brain will adjust to the new reality and things will start feeling mundane. This is called the hedonic treadmill.To me, what has helped is developing hobbies and relationships outside of work. We're social animals and need connection with others to feel fulfilled. Personally, my own life feels way more fulfilled right now than when I was just working on interesting projects at work or on my startup (that went nowhere).
comments.content_cn: 我认同这个前提，但对衡量“成功”的标准有异议：周一早晨你是否会兴奋地起床工作？我们是人类，无论追求什么，总会到达某个临界点——大脑会适应新的现实，一切开始变得平淡。这就是所谓的享乐适应现象。对我而言，真正有帮助的是培养工作之外的爱好和人际关系。我们是社会性动物，需要与他人建立联系才能获得满足感。就个人体验来说，比起曾经埋头于有趣的工作项目或创业尝试（最终无果而终），现在的生活让我感受到更充实的满足。

comments.author: jcims
comments.content: I've been in an engineering manager role on and off for the past 7 years at two different companies.  Both of which are highly regulated and incur a ton of audits, attestations and this impenetrable knot of distributed dependencies for segregation of duty and other 'stuff'.  As a result I'm in meetings 75% of my working hours and rarely get involved with anything close to the actual technology my team delivers.In the past two months I've been on two 4-6 hour incident management calls due to failures in our service providers and it's been quite some time since I felt that good about a day's work.  No meetings, no planning, no bullshit...just raw collaboration and tactical problem solving.  Even got to flex some of the skills that have been dormant for far too long.Feelsgoodman.
comments.content_cn: 过去七年里，我在两家不同公司断断续续担任工程经理职务。这两家公司都受到高度监管，需要应对大量审计、鉴证，以及因职责分离等要求形成的错综复杂的分布式依赖关系。因此，我75%的工作时间都在开会，很少有机会接触团队实际交付的技术工作。最近两个月，我参与了两次因服务提供商故障而召开的4-6小时事件管理会议——已经很久没有像这样对一天的工作感到如此满足了。没有会议，没有规划，没有空谈……只有纯粹的协作和实战问题解决。甚至还能重新施展那些尘封已久的技能。感觉真好。

comments.author: jwrallie
comments.content: The article started well until it changed from "you" to "I". After that, it felt like a mix of bragging and trying to sell a book.I think its OK if some people don't get to live their dream jobs, some dreams have no equivalent in real life, and some people need to do the mundane, boring underground jobs that keep things together.
comments.content_cn: 文章开头不错，但后来从“你”转为“我”之后，读起来就像是在自夸和推销书籍。我认为有些人没能从事梦想的工作也没关系，有些梦想在现实中并无对应，有些人就是需要做那些平凡、枯燥但维持社会运转的基础工作。

comments.content_cn: 一本自助书籍的奇怪广告，涉及政治交叉点，读起来几乎像是在用错误的方式拼命努力，你只需要用正确的方式努力，而他会教你所有诀窍。黄色的高亮部分并没有帮助建立可信度。

comments.author: davelaing
comments.content: I like John Vervaeke's meaning-in-life questions (potentially mildly paraphrasing, because it has been a while since I came across them):- what is it that I want there to be more of in the world, even after I'm gone?- what am I doing right now that is trying to help there be more of it?From memory most people don't have answers to them - and that's fine, but it is handy to reflect on them and perhaps work toward finding answers if you don't have them - and the people who do have answers to these questions typically have higher life satisfaction then the people who don't.
comments.content_cn:
我喜欢约翰·维尔瓦克关于人生意义的问题（可能略有转述，因为距离我上次接触它们已经有一段时间了）：
- 我希望世界上在我离开后能留下更多什么？
- 我现在正在做什么来帮助实现这个目标？
根据记忆，大多数人对这些问题没有答案——这没关系，但反思这些问题很有帮助，如果你没有答案，或许可以努力寻找答案——而那些对这些问题有答案的人，通常比没有答案的人拥有更高的人生满足感。

comments.author: marcus_holmes
comments.content: Please note that depression != burn-out. If you really can't get out of bed on a Monday morning, can't face the day, or muster any enthusiasm for anything, then you might not need a purpose, you might need medical assistance.Be kind to yourselves, people.
comments.content_cn: 请注意，抑郁不等于倦怠。如果你真的在周一早上无法起床，无法面对新的一天，或对任何事情都提不起兴趣，那么你可能需要的不是人生目标，而是医疗帮助。请善待自己，朋友们。

I feel a strong sense of purpose caring for my family, but don't have enough time to meet life's demands. Maybe other people relate more to this post because they more money and no kids.
comments.content_cn: 我筋疲力尽，因为我既要抚养两个年幼的孩子，又要从事一份要求很高的全职工作，而每天仅剩的一两个小时空闲时间，我还得打理家务并努力照顾自己。照顾家庭让我深感使命在肩，却没有足够的时间应对生活的种种要求。或许其他人更能对这条帖子产生共鸣，因为他们有更多金钱且没有孩子。

comments.content: As an aside, I really don't like these kinds of titles. They presume a lot about the (potential) reader without knowing anything about them. comments.content_cn: 顺便说一句，我实在不喜欢这类标题。它们在对潜在读者一无所知的情况下就预设了许多立场。而且听起来像是在陈述某种事实，实则不然。不同的人受不同问题困扰，不能就这样一概而论。

comments.content_cn: 可能无济于事的是，我们生命中三分之一到一半的时间都在为某个混蛋创造财富。

comments.author: parpfish
comments.content: One thing that I always try to bring up in these discussions is that “burnout” and “overwork” are two different problems, and I think this author would agree with me.If your problem could be fixed with a raise or a nice vacation, that’s overwork. 996 schedules, crunch time, and a high cost of living make overwork.Burnout is when you stat asking yourself “what’s the point of doing any of this?” and your life is overwhelmed with apathy and anhedonia. Closer to a career-induced bout of major depression.
comments.content_cn: 在这些讨论中，我总想强调一点：“职业倦怠”和“过度劳累”是两个不同的问题，我认为本文作者也会同意我的观点。如果你的问题可以通过加薪或一次愉快的假期解决，那属于过度劳累。996工作制、项目冲刺期和高生活成本会导致过度劳累。而职业倦怠是你开始自问“做这些事的意义何在？”，生活被冷漠和快感缺失淹没的状态，更接近于职业引发的重度抑郁发作。

comments.author: kledru
comments.content: the number of comments indicates that MANY OF US crave for some wise words about burnout... but the text we are presented with feels strangely empty of substance -- as if the author just wants to make some money with a book on a hot topic...
comments.content_cn: 评论数量表明，我们许多人渴望获得关于职业倦怠的智慧之言……但眼前的文字却奇怪地空洞无物——仿佛作者只是想借热门话题出书赚钱……

comments.author: thr0waway001
comments.content: I gotta say even though not having kids seems like the most economically sane thing to me, it often makes me wonder, what will be the point of life after retirement. I have no wife, g/f or kids. Right now my only 'why' is to not disappoint my family and cause a couple of them could use my help financially. Other than that, I don't see a long term 'why'.  My only compelling short term 'why' is that I don't want to be homeless. But that's pretty much a working to live and living to work type of reason to exist.Oh that and that the dog will miss me. But as we all know they don't live for long.
comments.content_cn: 我得承认，虽然不要孩子在我看来是最经济理性的选择，但这常常让我思考：退休后生活的意义何在？我没有妻子、女友或子女。目前我唯一的“动力”是不让家人失望，因为其中几位在经济上需要我的帮助。除此之外，我看不到长远的“目标”。眼下最迫切的理由只是不想无家可归，但这本质上成了为生存而工作、为工作而生存的循环。哦对了，还有我的狗会想念我——虽然我们都知道它们的生命很短暂。

comments.author: llmslave2
comments.content: Maybe this hits for millennials and older but as a gen-z I think it's safe to say we're burnt out because everything we want is simply too expensive, our degrees are useless, dating and relationships have become damaged because of the apps, and we are inheriting a world that is broken and continues to shatter.The older generations have everything and still feel burnt out and unhappy? Cool. Cool cool cool. That will certainly help with the nihilism.
comments.content_cn: 也许这能引起千禧一代及以上人群的共鸣，但作为Z世代，我认为可以说我们精疲力尽是因为想要的一切都太昂贵，我们的学位毫无用处，约会和恋爱因社交软件而变质，并且我们继承的是一个破碎且持续崩坏的世界。老一辈人拥有了一切却仍感到倦怠和不快乐？好吧。真是妙极了。这无疑会助长虚无主义。

comments.author: HPsquared
comments.content: I think a lot of people work on their career kind of "on credit", assuming it'll pay back in lifestyle improvements somehow. If this isn't forthcoming, the credit runs out.
comments.content_cn: 我认为很多人是在用“赊账”的方式经营自己的事业，总以为将来能通过改善生活方式来偿还。如果这种回报迟迟不来，信用额度也就耗尽了。

comments.author: randallsquared
comments.content: I think the described problem is real, but I'm astonished at the "went into politics" solution. I would expect that the lab work was a much more concrete, achievable, and lasting good than anything that will come of engaging with zero-sum or negative-sum games.I also wonder about the "now it's time to lift everyone else into abundance" earlier in the article. I don't disagree that this is valuable, but it doesn't solve the existential "why", it just puts it off for a few decades until the poorest humans are as rich as wealthy Americans are now. "What a problem to have!" one might say, but literally that is the problem that the article is about, right? Going back to power-level everyone else doesn't actually solve the problem of what to do when someone reaches the level cap.Ultimately there is nothing that is obviously and provably more important than the individual reading or writing this, as there kinda was in previous eras. Some candidates include religion, panhuman expansion or thriving (Musk), building a successor entity or entities (Altman), and the State or politics (the OP). I don't know of any argument better than personal preference, at the moment.
comments.content_cn:
我认为文中描述的问题确实存在，但对"投身政治"的解决方案感到惊讶。与参与零和或负和博弈可能带来的结果相比，实验室工作本应是更具体、可实现且持久的善举。我也对文章前半部分"现在是时候让所有人都进入富足状态"的说法存疑。我并非否认其价值，但这并未解决根本性的"存在意义"问题，只是将问题推迟了几十年——直到最贫困的人群达到当今美国富人的财富水平。"这算什么难题！"或许有人会这么说，但这恰恰是文章探讨的核心问题，不是吗？回过头来提升所有人的水平，实际上并未解决当个体达到能力上限后该如何自处的问题。

归根结底，当前已不存在像过去时代那样明显且可证明比阅读或书写此文的个体更重要的事物。可能的选项包括宗教信仰、全人类扩张或繁荣（马斯克倡导）、构建继承性实体（阿尔特曼主张），以及国家或政治（原文作者观点）。就目前而言，我认为任何论点都无法超越个人偏好的说服力。

comments.author: hackboyfly
comments.content: I like the overall message of this since I can deeply relate.I have been looking for meaningful work since I was 18, started in sales went on to marketing and ended up in engineering as a data scientist.Even though I feel closer than ever I still feel that I am not where I am suppose to be. One of my biggest problem is having to many options, to many callings. And they constantly keep changing, and perhaps that’s normal.It’s easy and dangerous to get stuck in the idea or quest of finding the ultimate purpose and try to translate that into actual work.
comments.content_cn: 我很认同这个观点，因为深有同感。从18岁起我就在寻找有意义的工作，从销售起步，转到市场营销，最后成为数据科学家进入工程领域。虽然感觉比以往更接近目标，但仍觉得自己尚未抵达应属之地。最大的困扰之一是选择太多、召唤太多，而且它们还在不断变化——或许这很正常。人们很容易陷入寻找终极目标的执念，并试图将其转化为实际工作，这种想法既简单又危险。

comments.author: justchad
comments.content: This resonates with me right now. I helped build a unicorn startup over the last 10 years but feel empty and burnt out when I’m working now. I feel like I’m wasting my time in exchange for a paycheck. I recently turned in my notice, I’m going on sabbatical. I’m hoping to find my passion and follow that. comments.author: godelski
comments.content: As someone medicated I actually fully agree with you.Depression is also a broad spectrum condition (much like autism). Years ago I watched this lecture by Sapolsky[0] and it really helped. Breaking down the different classifications is really helpful. The SSRIs always made me feel worse, and this (along with a lot of other research) helped make sense of it. A few years back I was diagnosed with ADHD and a psychologist friend encouraged me to give Adderall a try. It was the first time that medication "worked" and it really made a big difference in my life. The big reason why being that psychomotor retardation and anhedonia were my biggest symptoms. When coupled with an anxiety disorder it creates a strong negative feedback loop.But here's the thing: medication isn't the cure. For me it alleviates (not eliminates) symptoms but at the end of the day it still requires work from me to ensure I create a positive feedback loop and don't let myself fall into that destructive loop. This is all stuff I had to learn on my own and through reading and seeking out friends with people who are more experts in the area. That's where I think our care system fails.The best thing I can recommend to people is to be introspective. Each journey is personal, but whatever your issues are try to find the early warning signs. For me it can be little things like the dishes piling up or my desk getting messy (these seem you be common). Things like depression build up, so look for the signs. And most importantly, open up. This was the hardest for me and makes me feel demasculated and embarrassed much of the time. But I've also found it to help build stronger relationships with my partner and friends. That it helps open a door to communicate both ways. Maybe you open the door for you, but you also open a door many are too nervous to open themselves. It's worth the discomfort and gets easier with time. (Talking behind a handle is a great way to start too. So make alt accounts if you need to. posts.title: Show HN: Jmail – Google Suite for Epstein files
posts.content: Hi everyone! My name's Luke and I made the original Jmail here alongside Riley Walz. We had a ton of friends collaborate on building out more of the app suite last night in lieue of DOJ's "Epstein files" release.Please AMA!
posts.author: lukeigel
posts.title_cn: "Show HN: Jmail – 爱泼斯坦文件谷歌套件"
posts.content_cn: 大家好！我是Luke，我和Riley Walz共同开发了最初的Jmail。昨晚，在司法部发布“爱泼斯坦文件”之际，我们邀请了许多朋友一起协作，扩展了更多应用套件。欢迎随时提问！
posts.abstract:
该HackerNews帖子讨论了用户Luke和Riley Walz开发的“Jmail – Google Suite for Epstein files”项目，这是一个基于爱泼斯坦案件公开文件构建的应用套件。核心话题围绕该工具的技术实现、文件内容的完整性以及案件背后的社会政治意义展开。

社区观点多元：有人对团队快速克隆高成本软件套件表示赞赏，并指出移动端体验优于谷歌原生产品；也有用户强调文件信息量巨大，其中90%为新发布的照片，但部分内容经过编辑。在文件完整性方面，用户提到瑞典媒体质疑信息被大量审查，可能涉及掩盖。政治层面，有观点认为案件被用作烟雾弹，转移公众对政府政策的注意力。讨论中还提到文件中精英阶层的社会联系令人惊讶，例如史蒂夫·班农与诺姆·乔姆斯基的合影。

共识在于肯定项目的技术价值和对信息可视化的贡献，但分歧集中在文件透明度、政治动机以及案件的社会影响上。用户建议增加“垃圾文件夹”功能管理未公开文件，体现了对工具实用性的关注。

As someone from the other side of the pond, I have to ask: what do people expect from all of this?It feels like this is a big smoke screen used by the current admin, first to be reelected, and now to distract people from what they are actually doing (like repeating they decreased drugs price by 600%, that they ended dozens of wars while dropping bombs daily all around the World...).It also looks like it allows everyone to peek in other's people lives, which feels quite disturbing.
Sure, some of them were/are terrible people.
But there's also the victims here.
Furthermore, is it how justice should work?
Share everything to the world, and let everyone make their own judgement based on what they see?Is there going to be some actual outcome? Both for the victims and for their offenders?Or is it just a show where everyone can see them as detective/judge?Just to add a bit more context: after years of trials, one of our former President finally went to jail for a few weeks.
And now, they're invited by media all over the country so they can complain about how unfair it was, they published a book about it, sold in the tens of thousands, their son is the new TV's favorite...So I'm wondering: is it actual justice at work, or just a distraction while nothing change and nobody is actually held accountable?
comments.content_cn:
作为一个来自大洋彼岸的人，我不得不问：人们到底期待从这一切中得到什么？这感觉像是现任政府使用的一大烟幕弹，最初是为了连任，现在则是为了转移人们对他们实际行为的注意力（比如反复宣称降低了600%的药价，声称结束了数十场战争，却每天都在世界各地投掷炸弹……）。这似乎也让每个人都能窥探他人的生活，令人相当不安。

当然，其中一些人过去或现在确实很糟糕。
但这里也有受害者。
更重要的是，正义应该以这种方式实现吗？
向全世界公开一切，让每个人根据所见做出自己的判断？是否会有实际的结果？无论是为受害者还是为加害者？或者这只是一场秀，让每个人都能扮演侦探或法官的角色？

再补充一点背景：经过多年的审判，我们的一位前总统终于入狱了几周。
而现在，他们被全国媒体邀请，抱怨这是多么不公平，还出版了相关书籍，销量数万册，他们的儿子成了电视新宠……所以我在想：这真的是正义在发挥作用，还是只是一场转移注意力的表演，一切照旧，没有人真正承担责任？

comments.content: The cost optimization here is impressive - $10 for millions of visitors using Next.js + Vercel + Cloudflare R2 (free egress).I'm building an analytics SaaS with a similar stack and this validates our architecture choices. A few questions:1. How are you handling ISR vs full static generation? You mentioned migrating to generateStaticParams - did you pre-generate all email pages or use on-demand ISR?2. Did you hit any Vercel function limits with the email processing, or is everything cached aggressively enough that it doesn't matter?3. R2's free egress is a game-changer - are you using Cloudflare's image transformations or handling resizing client-side?The caching strategy here is the real MVP. Most people underestimate how far good caching with Next.js can take you before you need Redis or more complex infrastructure.
comments.content_cn: 这里的成本优化令人印象深刻——使用Next.js + Vercel + Cloudflare R2（免费出口流量）即可为数百万访客服务仅需10美元。我正在用类似技术栈构建分析型SaaS，这验证了我们的架构选择。有几个问题：1. 您如何处理增量静态再生与完全静态生成？您提到迁移到generateStaticParams——是预生成所有邮件页面还是按需使用增量静态再生？2. 邮件处理是否触及Vercel函数限制？还是所有内容都通过积极缓存避免了这个问题？3. R2的免费出口流量改变了游戏规则——您在使用Cloudflare的图像转换功能还是在客户端处理尺寸调整？这里的缓存策略才是真正的核心优势。大多数人低估了Next.js良好缓存方案的潜力，其实在需要Redis或更复杂基础设施之前，它能发挥巨大作用。

comments.author: lukeigel
comments.content: Thank you!The original site was on Railway and written in Pug! It crashed after Riley's tweet first went viral, then Riley did the heroic work of caching it all with Cloudflare after waking up to the site being down. After millions of unique visitors we racked up about $10 in costs.This time we switched to Next.js 16 + Vercel, used Cloudflare R2 for asset hosting, and used Neon as the db. R2 has free egress, and Vercel + Next is cheap if cached correctly.A special someone at Vercel gave us some tips on caching this one earlier today. We started by just using unstable_cache all over the place, and now we're migrating to ISR + full static pre-generation of as many pages as we can via generateStaticParams.
comments.content_cn: 感谢！原网站部署在Railway平台并使用Pug语言编写。当Riley的推文首次爆红后网站就崩溃了，随后Riley在发现网站宕机后英勇地通过Cloudflare完成了全站缓存。在承受数百万独立访客访问后，我们仅产生了约10美元的成本。这次我们切换到了Next.js 16 + Vercel技术栈，采用Cloudflare R2托管静态资源，并使用Neon作为数据库。R2提供免费出站流量，而正确缓存情况下Vercel + Next的组合成本极低。今天早些时候，Vercel的一位特别人士为我们提供了缓存优化建议。我们最初在所有地方都使用了unstable_cache，现在正逐步迁移到增量静态再生（ISR）模式，并通过generateStaticParams尽可能实现全站页面的静态预生成。

posts.title: A guide to local coding models
posts.author: mpweiher
posts.title_cn: 本地编码模型指南
posts.abstract:
该讨论围绕本地编程模型的使用展开，核心话题是评估本地部署AI编码工具在成本、性能与实用性方面的权衡。多数用户认同本地模型在节省订阅费用和保护隐私方面具有优势，尤其适合个人项目或非编码任务（如文本处理）。有人认为，对于简单项目或预算有限的爱好者，低成本甚至免费的本地方案（如Ollama、LM Studio）已足够实用，且随着推理成本下降，这将成为趋势。

然而，在性能方面存在明显分歧。有用户指出，当前本地模型（即使是30B-80B参数规模）在代码生成质量、响应速度和上下文窗口上仍远不如Claude Code、GPT等云端服务，在处理复杂任务时可能浪费开发时间。也有用户强调，延迟和迭代速度是本地部署的关键瓶颈，云端服务的即时响应和大上下文窗口能显著提升效率。讨论中提到，部分工具（如Cline、VSCode插件）已能较好支持本地模型，但尚未达到云端服务的“开箱即用”体验。整体上，社区共识是本地模型适用于成本敏感、隐私要求高的轻量场景，但在生产环境或复杂编程需求中，云端模型仍占优势。

The OpenAI one in particular is a great deal, because Codex is charged a whole lot lower than Claude.The time to cough up $100 or $200/month is when you've exhausted your $20/month quota and you are frustrated at getting cut off. At that point you should be able to make a responsible decision by yourself.

I use local models + openrouter free ones.My monthly spend on ai models is < $1I'm not cheap, just ahead of the curve. With the collapse in inference cost, everything will be this eventuallyI'll basically do    $ man tool | <how do I do this with the tool>

or even    $ cat source | <find the flags and give me some documentation on how to use this>

Things I used to do intensively I now do lazily.I've even made a IEITYuan/Yuan-embedding-2.0-en database of my manpages with chroma and then I can just ask my local documentation how I do something conceptually, get the man pages, inject them into local qwen context window using my mansnip llm preprocessor, forward the prompt and then get usable real results.In practice it's this:    $ what-man "some obscure question about nfs" 
    ...chug chug chug (about 5 seconds)...

    <answer with citations back to the doc pages>

Essentially I'm not asking the models to think, just do NLP and process text. They can do that really reliably.It helps combat a frequent tendency for documentation authors to bury the most common and useful flags deep in the documentation and lead with those that were most challenging or interesting to program instead.I understand the inclination it's just not all that helpful for me
comments.content_cn:
我主要使用本地模型和OpenRouter的免费服务。每月在AI模型上的花费不到1美元。这并非吝啬，而是走在趋势前沿。随着推理成本的大幅下降，未来一切都会朝这个方向发展。

现在我会直接执行：
$ man 工具名 |

甚至：
$ cat 源代码 |

过去需要深度处理的任务，现在可以轻松完成。我甚至用chroma为我的手册页创建了IEITYuan/Yuan-embedding-2.0-en数据库，这样就能直接向本地文档库提问概念性操作，获取手册页内容，再通过自建的mansnip预处理工具将内容注入本地千问模型的上下文窗口，提交提示后就能获得切实可用的结果。

实际操作如下：
$ what-man "关于nfs的冷门问题"
...系统处理中（约5秒）...

本质上，我不要求模型进行复杂思考，只需完成自然语言处理和文本处理任务——它们在这方面表现非常稳定。这种方式能有效解决文档编写者常有的倾向：把最常用、最实用的参数说明深埋在文档底层，却把编程时最具挑战性或趣味性的内容放在显眼位置。我理解这种写作倾向，但对我而言实际帮助有限。

comments.author: yoan9224
comments.content: The cost analysis here is solid, but it misses the latency and context window trade-offs that matter in practice. I've been running Qwen2.5-Coder locally for the past month and the real bottleneck isn't cost - it's the iteration speed. Claude's 200k context window with instant responses lets me paste entire codebases and get architectural advice. Local models with 32k context force me to be more surgical about what I include.That said, the privacy argument is compelling for commercial projects. Running inference locally means no training data concerns, no rate limits during critical debugging sessions, and no dependency on external API uptime. We're building Prysm (analytics SaaS) and considered local models for our AI features, but the accuracy gap on complex multi-step reasoning was too large. We ended up with a hybrid: GPT-4o-mini for simple queries, GPT-4 for analysis, and potentially local models for PII-sensitive data processing.The TCO calculation should also factor in GPU depreciation and electricity costs. A 4090 pulling 450W at $0.15/kWh for 8 hours/day is ~$200/year just in power, plus ~$1600 amortized over 3 years. That's $733/year before you even start inferencing. You need to be spending $61+/month on Claude to break even, and that's assuming local performance is equivalent.
comments.content_cn:
这里的成本分析很扎实，但忽略了实际应用中至关重要的延迟和上下文窗口权衡问题。过去一个月我本地运行Qwen2.5-Coder时发现，真正的瓶颈不是成本，而是迭代速度。Claude的20万上下文窗口配合即时响应，让我能直接粘贴整个代码库获取架构建议。而本地模型32k的上下文窗口迫使我必须精挑细选输入内容。

不过对于商业项目而言，隐私性这个论点很有说服力。本地运行推理意味着无需担心训练数据问题，关键调试阶段不受速率限制影响，也不依赖外部API的可用性。我们正在开发Prysm（分析型SaaS）时曾考虑为AI功能采用本地模型，但在复杂多步推理的准确度差距实在太大。最终采用了混合方案：简单查询用GPT-4o-mini，分析任务用GPT-4，敏感个人信息处理则可能采用本地模型。

总拥有成本计算还应纳入GPU折旧和电费因素。以每天运行8小时计算，450W功耗的4090显卡在每度电0.15美元的情况下，仅电费每年就约200美元，加上三年分摊约1600美元的硬件成本，每年基础支出就达733美元。这意味着每月需要在Claude上花费超过61美元才能实现盈亏平衡，这还是假设本地模型性能相当的前提下。
