comments.author: baconner
comments.content: There are a couple of decent approaches to having a planning/reviewer model set (eg. claude, codex, gemini) and an execution model (eg. glm 4.6, flash models, etc) workflow that I've tried. All three of these will let you live in a single coding cli but swap in different models for different tasks easily.- claude code router - basically allows you to swap in other models using the real claude code cli and set up some triggers for when to use which one (eg. plan mode use real claude, non plan or with keywords use glm)- opencode - this is what im mostly using now. similar to ccr but i find it a lot more reliable against alt models. thinking tasks go to claude, gemini, codex and lesser execution tasks go to glm 4.6 (on ceberas).- sub-agent mcp - Another cool way is to use an mcp (or a skill or custom /command) that runs another agent cli for certain tasks. The mcp approach is neat because then your thinker agent like claude can decide when to call the execution agents, when to call in another smart model for a review of it's own thinking, etc instead of it being explicit choice from you. So you end up with the mcp + an AGENTS.md that instructs it to aggressively use the sub-agent mcp when it's a basic execution task, review, ...I also find that with this setup just being able to tap in an alt model when one is stuck, or get review from an alt model can help keep things unstuck and moving.
comments.content_cn:
我尝试过几种不错的方法来建立规划/评审模型集（如Claude、Codex、Gemini）与执行模型（如GLM 4.6、Flash模型等）的工作流。这三种方式都能让你在单一编码命令行环境中工作，同时轻松切换不同模型以应对不同任务。

- Claude代码路由器：本质上允许你在真实的Claude代码命令行中切换其他模型，并设置触发条件来决定何时使用哪个模型（例如规划模式用真实Claude，非规划模式或含关键词时用GLM）。
- Opencode：这是我目前主要使用的工具。类似CCR，但我觉得它对替代模型的可靠性更高。思考型任务交给Claude、Gemini、Codex，次要执行任务则交给GLM 4.6（运行在Ceberas上）。
- 子代理MCP：另一种很酷的方式是使用MCP（或技能/自定义命令）来为特定任务运行另一个代理命令行。MCP方式的巧妙之处在于，像Claude这样的思考代理可以自主决定何时调用执行代理、何时调用其他智能模型来评审自身思考过程，而不需要你显式选择。最终你会形成"MCP+AGENTS.md"的组合，通过文档指导其在基础执行任务、评审等场景下积极调用子代理MCP。

我还发现，这种设置能让你在某个模型卡住时随时切入替代模型，或从替代模型获取评审意见，有助于打破僵局并推动工作进展。

posts.title: CO2 batteries that store grid energy take off globally
posts.author: rbanffy
posts.title_cn: 储存电网能源的二氧化碳电池在全球兴起
posts.abstract:
该讨论围绕全球新兴的二氧化碳电池储能技术展开，核心话题是评估其作为电网级储能方案的可行性与优缺点。社区普遍认同该技术具有设备简单、成本较低的优势，且能通过存储压缩热提升效率，但对其实际竞争力存在分歧。

有人认为，相比锂离子电池90%的往返效率，二氧化碳电池60-75%的效率虽较低，但电网储能需综合考量投资成本、寿命周期和降解问题，锂离子的成本下降趋势可能削弱二氧化碳电池的当前价格优势。也有用户指出，该技术适合中短时储能，但电网真正缺乏的是能持续数月的长时储能方案，而非仅几小时的存储。讨论中提到，技术潜在缺陷包括压缩热管理问题——若不能有效存储利用，将造成能源浪费；同时，其设备规模与气体储存容器的成本缩放也是关键挑战。部分用户对其过于美好的描述持怀疑态度，认为需更全面分析其隐藏限制。总体而言，社区期待该技术能与锂离子电池形成互补，但对其长期经济性和技术成熟度仍持审慎态度。

I think it should be megawatt-hours, not megawatts. If this is true, this is a big yikes for something coming out of the Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers.

comments.author: yoan9224
comments.content: The round-trip efficiency comparison (60-75% vs lithium-ion's ~90%) is interesting but somewhat misleading without context. For grid-scale storage, the relevant question isn't efficiency in isolation - it's lifecycle economics including capex, degradation, and replacement cycles.Lithium-ion has superior efficiency but degrades significantly after 5,000-7,000 cycles, typically reaching 80% capacity in 7-10 years. If CO2 batteries can maintain performance for 20+ years with minimal degradation (which the article suggests), the lower efficiency becomes less relevant. You're trading 15-25% energy loss for potentially 2-3x longer operational life and no lithium supply chain dependencies.The real breakthrough is duration-flexible storage. Lithium-ion economics break down beyond 4-hour discharge rates because you're paying for both energy capacity and power capacity. CO2 systems decouple these - the turbine size determines power output, the storage tank size determines duration. That makes them ideal for seasonal storage patterns where you might charge for days during high renewable production and discharge slowly over weeks during winter lulls.What's missing from the article: what's the round-trip efficiency at different discharge rates? Does efficiency drop significantly when discharging over 12 hours vs 4 hours? That would determine whether these make sense for daily solar smoothing vs weekly wind intermittency vs seasonal storage.
comments.content_cn:
往返效率对比（60-75%对比锂离子电池的约90%）虽然有趣，但脱离背景讨论会有些误导性。对于电网级储能而言，关键问题并非孤立的效率指标，而是包含资本支出、衰减特性和更换周期的全生命周期经济性。锂离子电池虽效率更高，但在经历5000-7000次循环后会出现显著衰减，通常在7-10年内容量会降至80%。如果二氧化碳电池能如文章所言保持20年以上性能且衰减极低，那么较低的效率就变得不那么重要了——这是用15-25%的能量损耗换取可能延长2-3倍的使用寿命，同时摆脱对锂供应链的依赖。

真正的突破在于时长灵活的储能特性。锂离子电池在放电时长超过4小时后经济性就会恶化，因为需要同时为能量容量和功率容量付费。二氧化碳系统则实现了二者的解耦——涡轮机规模决定功率输出，储罐规模决定储能时长。这使其特别适合季节性储能场景：可在可再生能源高产期连续数日充电，在冬季间歇期缓慢放电数周。

文章未提及的关键信息是：不同放电速率下的往返效率如何？12小时放电与4小时放电相比效率是否显著下降？这将决定该技术更适合日常光伏平滑、周级风电间歇调节还是季节性储能场景。

comments.content: I wonder how much Google is factoring in the implicit cooling cycle? When you consider how much of the power input of a datacenter is typically used for cooling, compressed gas storage could be useful even if there was zero electric recovery (just time-shifting the power consumption for cooling to a time with better energy availability)
comments.content_cn: 我在想谷歌究竟在多大程度上考虑了隐含的冷却循环？因为任何加压气体储能系统要么包含某种先进的热能储存技术，要么就只能将压缩过程中产生的热量直接排放（德国古老的亨托夫设施就因此臭名昭著，能源浪费极其严重）。通常我们希望保存这些热量，在减压时将其重新注入压缩介质中，并希望储热过程中的损失不会太大。但如果附近有冷却需求场景，就可以利用这些低强度热量来弥补储热损失，甚至实现超额补偿。考虑到数据中心通常有多少电力输入被用于冷却，即使压缩气体储能的电能回收率为零（仅将冷却耗能转移到能源供应更充裕的时段），这种技术也可能具有实用价值。

comments.author: Perseids
comments.content: To cite and expand on lambdaone below [1]:> Clearly power capacity cost (scaling compressors/expanders and related kit) and energy storage cost (scaling gasbags and storage vessels) are decoupled from one another in this designLambdaone is differentiating between the costs to store energy (measured in kWh or Joules) and the costs to store energy per time (which is power, measured in Watts). If you want to store the whole excess energy that solar panels and wind turbines generate on a sunny, windy day, you need to have a lot of power storage capability (gigawatts of power generated during peak power generation). This can be profitable even if you only have a low energy storage capability, e.g. if you can only store a day worth of excess solar/wind energy, because you can sell this energy in the short term, for example in the next night, when the data centers are still running, but solar panels don't produce power. This is what batteries give you -- high power storage capabilities but low energy storage capacities.Of course, you can always buy more batteries to increase the energy storage capacities, but they are very expensive per energy (kWh) stored. In contrast, these CO2 "batteries" are very cheap per energy (kWh) stored -- "just" build more high pressure tanks -- but expensive per power (Watts) stored, because to store more power, you need to build more expensive compressors, coolers etc. This ability to scale out the energy storage capability independently of the power storage capability is what Lambdaone was referring to with the decoupling.For what is this useful? For shifting energy over a larger amount of time. Because energy storage costs of batteries are so high, they are a bad fit for storing excess energy in the summer (lots of solar) and releasing it in the winter (lots of heating). I'm not sure if these "CO2" batteries are good for such long time frames (maybe pressure loss is too high), but the claim most certainly is that they can shift energy over a longer time frame than is possible with batteries in an economically profitable fashion.[1] https://news.ycombinator.com/item?id=46347251

引用并扩展lambdaone在下面的观点[1]：>显然，在这种设计中，功率容量成本（扩展压缩机/膨胀机及相关设备）与储能成本（扩展气囊和储存容器）是相互分离的。Lambdaone区分了储存能量的成本（以千瓦时或焦耳衡量）和单位时间内储存能量的成本（即功率，以瓦特衡量）。如果你想储存太阳能电池板和风力涡轮机在阳光充足、风力强劲的日子里产生的全部过剩能量，你需要具备大量的功率储存能力（峰值发电时产生吉瓦级的功率）。即使你的储能能力较低，例如只能储存一天的多余太阳能/风能，这仍然可能是有利可图的，因为你可以在短期内出售这些能量，比如在数据中心仍在运行但太阳能电池板不发电的夜晚。这就是电池所提供的——高功率储存能力但低能量储存容量。

当然，你总是可以购买更多电池来增加能量储存容量，但每储存一度电（千瓦时）的成本非常昂贵。相比之下，这些二氧化碳“电池”每储存一度电（千瓦时）的成本非常低——“只需”建造更多高压储罐——但每储存一瓦特功率的成本却很高，因为要储存更多功率，你需要建造更昂贵的压缩机、冷却器等设备。这种能够独立于功率储存能力扩展能量储存能力的特点……

comments.content: > For example I expect recycling costs to be significantly worse for the Li-Ion.I think there's a good argument for the opposite.Recycling costs for Li-Ion once we are doing it at scale should be significantly negative. There are valuable materials you get to extract, they aren't in that complex a blend to extract them from, and there's a lot of basically the same blend. The biggest risk in this claim is, I think, the implicit claim that we won't figure out how to extract the same materials from the earth much cheaper in the meantime cratering the end of life value of batteries - but in that event the CO2 battery technology is underwater anyways and the chemical batteries win on not wasting R&D costs.By contrast while there's some value in the steel that goes into building tanks and pumps and so on, the material cost if a much lower fraction of the cost of the device. Most of the cost went into shaping it into those complex shapes. I don't know for sure what the cost breakdown of the CO2 plant looks like but if a lot of the cost is something else it's probably something like concrete or white paint that actually costs money to dispose of.
comments.content_cn: 例如，我预计锂离子电池的回收成本会显著更高。但我认为有充分理由持相反观点。一旦我们大规模进行锂离子电池回收，其成本实际上应为显著负值。因为可以提取有价值的材料，这些材料并非难以从复杂混合物中分离，且存在大量基本相同的混合物组合。这一论断的最大风险在于，它隐含地假设我们不会在此期间找到更廉价的地球原料提取方法——若真如此，电池的报废价值将暴跌，但那种情况下二氧化碳电池技术本身已失去竞争力，而化学电池则因避免了研发浪费而胜出。相比之下，虽然制造储罐和泵体等设备的钢材有一定价值，但材料成本在设备总成本中占比很低，大部分成本都投入了将这些材料加工成复杂形状的工序中。我不确定二氧化碳储能工厂的具体成本构成，但如果其中大部分成本来自其他方面，那很可能是混凝土或特种涂料等实际需要付费处理的材料。

comments.content: Pumped hydro is just not a valid comparison. I wish people would understand that already… it’s only good for long term storage in certain key geographical regions. posts.title: Privacy doesn't mean anything anymore, anonymity does
posts.author: ybceo
posts.title_cn: 隐私已无意义，匿名才是关键
posts.abstract: 该讨论围绕“隐私已无意义，匿名才是关键”这一观点展开。用户主要探讨了网络服务中隐私保护的实际意义与局限性。有人认为，许多公司虽声称保护隐私，但仍会记录IP地址等数据，其隐私政策可能缺乏透明度；也有用户指出，即使采用加密货币等技术，匿名性也可能因交易记录公开而受限，真正的匿名难以实现。讨论中提到，过度追求隐私反而可能增加用户被“指纹识别”的风险，且依赖Cloudflare等中间服务商会削弱匿名性。部分用户质疑企业认证（如ISO27001）的真实性，认为无法验证的隐私承诺价值有限。共识在于，现有技术环境下完全匿名极为困难，而分歧主要体现在对匿名实现方式及企业承诺可信度的不同判断上。

comments.content: You're thinking about browser fingerprinting (client-side), but my post is about service-level anonymity (server-side).Browser fingerprinting: "Your unique combination of extensions/settings makes you identifiable among other users."Service anonymity: "There are no other users to compare you against because we don't collect identifying data."When you sign up with just a random 32-char string, there's nothing to fingerprint. No email to correlate. No IP logs to analyze. No usage patterns to build a profile from.Fingerprinting matters when services collect behavioral data. We architected our way out of having that data to begin with.
comments.content_cn:
你考虑的是浏览器指纹识别（客户端层面），而我讨论的是服务级别的匿名性（服务器层面）。  
浏览器指纹识别指：“你独特的扩展组合和设置使你在其他用户中可被识别。”  
服务匿名性则意味着：“没有其他用户可供对比，因为我们不收集身份数据。”  
当你仅使用随机32位字符串注册时，不存在可提取的指纹信息：没有关联邮箱、没有IP记录可供分析、也没有使用习惯可构建用户画像。

posts.title: If you don't design your career, someone else will (2014)
posts.author: TheAlchemist
posts.title_cn: 如果你不规划自己的职业生涯，别人就会替你规划（2014）
posts.abstract: 该讨论围绕2014年文章《如果你不规划职业生涯，别人就会替你规划》展开，核心探讨职业发展是否应主动设计。有人认为主动规划至关重要，可借鉴汉明“目标导向”的比喻，避免像醉酒水手般随机漫步；也有用户指出，过度规划可能忽略偶然机遇的重要性，许多成功源于在机会出现时恰好能行动。讨论中提到，年轻一代面临职业路径碎片化的现实，传统规划方式已不适用；同时，部分用户将职业视为谋生手段而非人生重心，更追求工作与生活的分离。分歧集中在规划与机遇的平衡上：一方强调目标导向的主动性，另一方则认为灵活应对变化更为实际。共识在于，完全被动接受外界期望可能导致自我与现实的割裂，但具体实现方式存在代际和价值观差异。

comments.author: Swizec
comments.content: My favorite lens on this comes from Hamming:> It is well known the drunken sailor whos taggers to the left or right n independent random steps will, on the average, end up about sqrt(n) steps from the origin. But if there is a pretty girl in one direction, then his steps will tend to go in that direction and he will go a distance proportional to n. In a lifetime of many, many independent choices, small and large, a career with a vision will get you a distance proportional to n, while no vision will get you only the distance sqrt(n). In a sense, the main difference between those who go far and those who do not is some people have a vision and others do not and therefore can only react to the current events as they happen.Just a tiny bit of bias towards a direction will get you very far very fast.I once modeled+visualised this with a bit of javascript[1] and it's quite surprising to see the huge difference from even a tiny multiplication factor on each random/probabilistic decision.[1] https://swizec.com/blog/your-career-needs-a-vision/

comments.author: yoan9224
comments.content: This advice remains relevant but I think it misses an important nuance about how career design actually works in practice. The metaphor of "design" implies you're building something from scratch with full control, but career development is more like gardening - you can influence conditions but not force outcomes.The key insight is recognizing the misalignment between your goals and your manager's goals. Your manager optimizes for team output and organizational needs. Your career growth is a secondary concern - important, but not primary. This creates a fundamental principal-agent problem. The solution isn't to become adversarial, it's to be explicit about your goals and negotiate actively rather than hoping they'll be noticed.Practically, this means: (1) Having quarterly conversations where you explicitly state "I want to work on X technology" or "I'm aiming for senior by Q3" rather than assuming good work will be rewarded automatically. (2) Building skills outside your job scope through side projects, open source, or internal tools that solve real problems. (3) Being willing to change companies when growth stalls - the biggest salary/title jumps come from job changes, not promotions.The dangerous flip side is over-optimization. I've seen engineers obsess over "career design" to the point where they won't touch any task that doesn't directly ladder to their promotion case. That creates fragile specialists who can't adapt when their niche technology becomes obsolete. Better approach: have a direction, but maintain broad skills and genuine curiosity. The most interesting career paths come from unexpected opportunities you recognized because you had wide exposure, not rigid planning.

关键是要认识到你的目标与你经理的目标之间存在错位。你的经理优先考虑团队产出和组织需求。你的职业成长是次要关切——重要，但并非首要。这造成了根本性的委托-代理问题。解决方法不是变得对立，而是明确表达你的目标并积极协商，而不是指望它们会被注意到。

实际上，这意味着：（1）进行季度对话，明确说明“我想从事X技术工作”或“我计划在第三季度前达到高级职位”，而不是假设出色的工作会自动得到回报。（2）通过副业项目、开源或解决实际问题的内部工具，培养工作范围之外的技能。（3）当成长停滞时愿意更换公司——最大的薪资/职级跃升来自跳槽，而非内部晋升。

comments.author: jvanderbot
comments.content:
After ~15 years, I've realized that no good things come to you without sustained focus / attentiveness, and gentle pressure in the direction of attention. What everyone here is saying is "be closed loop", vs the drunkards "open loop". Combined with a bit of progress every day, it's (so far, at least) magical what happens.Another bit to consider:
It took a long time to realize that basically everyone wants basically everyone to succeed, as long as incentives align. It was very easy to imagine I was swimming upstream early in my career - especially my early mentors urging me to specialize to find success. My initial temptation was to "specialize" in hot/attractive topics in an effort to be the "indispensable X authority". But my PhD advisor urged me to "not swim in red water", where the incentives are inherently conflicting - everyone wants to be "the X person".Much better to find a team working on a good problem somewhat like the ones you want to solve and just push along with them. You can save yourself a lot of energy by slotting yourself into a system that aligns with your preferred direction of travel, even if only a little bit. The current carries you.
comments.content_cn: 经过大约15年，我意识到没有持续专注和朝着关注方向施加温和压力，好事不会自动降临。这里大家所说的"形成闭环"，与醉汉般的"开环"状态截然不同。结合每天的一点进步，产生的效果（至少到目前为止）堪称神奇。另一点值得思考的是：我花了很长时间才明白，只要激励一致，基本上每个人都希望彼此成功。职业生涯早期，我很容易觉得自己在逆流而上——尤其是当初的导师们敦促我专精以求成功。我最初的冲动是追逐热门/吸引人的领域，试图成为"不可或缺的X领域权威"。但我的博士导师告诫我"不要在红海中挣扎"，那里的激励机制本质上是冲突的——人人都想成为"那个X专家"。更好的选择是找到一个团队，他们正在处理与你理想课题相近的好问题，然后与他们共同推进。即使只是略微契合，将自己嵌入与心之所向同频的系统，也能为你节省大量精力。水流自会载你前行。

posts.title: Rue: Higher level than Rust, lower level than Go
posts.author: ingve
posts.title_cn: Rue：比Rust更高级，比Go更低级
posts.abstract:
该帖子讨论了新兴编程语言Rue的定位，其目标是成为比Rust更高级、比Go更低级的语言。核心话题围绕Rue如何实现内存安全而不依赖垃圾回收或手动内存管理，目前这仍是进行中的设计。

社区观点多元：有人认为内存管理方案尚不明确，缺乏详细解释，因此持观望态度；也有用户指出其设计提案包含多种类型模式，并采用类似Swift的inout参数传递机制，而非Rust的借用系统。讨论中提到，部分Go开发者希望有比Go表达力更强、且能兼容Go编译模型和库的语言，而一些受困于Rust生命周期复杂性的用户则期待更面向对象的替代方案。此外，有用户关注语法细节（如->符号的直观性），并建议参考博客和代码库以获取更全面的介绍。

目前共识是Rue仍处于早期阶段，尚未准备好投入实际使用。主要分歧在于对其内存管理实现方式的不同猜测（如基于ARC、所有权或其他创新机制），以及它能否在表达力、安全性和易用性之间找到平衡点。

No one really knows a sane way to do it otherwise, unless you also want to drop the general-purpose systems programming language requirement.I'll be Very Interested if they find a new unexplored point in the design space, but at the moment I remain skeptical.Folks like to mention Ada. In my understanding, Ada is not memory safe by contemporary definitions. So, this requires relaxing the definition. Zig goes in this direction: "let's make it as safe as possible without being an absolutist"

comments.author: rayiner
comments.content: If you look at the Github, there's a design proposal (under docs/design) for that.It looks like the idea at the present time is to have four modes: value types, affine types, linear types, and rc types. Instead, of borrowing, you have an inout parameter passing convention, like Swift. Struct fields cannot be inout, so you can't store borrowed references on the heap.I'm very interested in seeing how this works in practice--especially given who is developing Rue. It seems like Rust spends a lot of work enabling the borrow checker to be quite general for C/C++-like usage. E.g. you can store a borrowed reference to a struct on the stack into the heap if you use lifetime annotations to make clear the heap object does not outlive the stack frame. On the other hand it seems like a lot of the pain points with Rust in practice are not the lifetime annotations, but borrowing different parts of the same object, or multiple borrows in functions further down the call stack, etc.

comments.author: est31
comments.content: I have mostly been writing Rust in the last 10 years, but recently (1 year) I have been writing Go as well as Rust.The typical Go story is to use a bunch of auto generation, so a small change quickly blows up as all of the auto generate code is checked into git. Like easily a 20x blowup.Rust on the other hand probably does much more such code generation (build.rs for stuff like bindgen, macros for stuff like serde, and monomorphized generics for basically everything). But all of this code is never checked into git (with the exception of some build.rs tools which can be configured to run as commands as well), or at least 99% of the time it's not.This difference has impact on the developer story. In go land, you need to manually invoke the auto generator and it's easy to forget until CI reminds you. The auto generator is usually quite slow, and probably has much less caching smartness than the Rust people have figured out.In Rust land, the auto generation can, worst case, run at every build, best case the many cache systems take care of it (cargo level, rustc level). But still, everyone who does a git pull has to re-run this, while with the auto generation one can theoretically only have the folks run it who actually made changes that changed the auto generated code, everyone else gets it via git pull.So in Go, your IDE is ready to go immediately after git pull and doesn't have to compile a tree of hundreds of dependencies. Go IDEs and compilers are so fast, it's almost like cheating from Rust POV. Rust IDEs are not as fast at all even if everything is cached, and in the worst case you have to wait a long long time.On the other hand, these auto generation tools in Go are only somewhat standardized, you don't have a central tool that takes care of things (or at least I'm not aware of it). In Rust land, cargo creates some level of standardization.You can always look at the auto generated Go code and understand it, while Rust's auto generated code usually is not IDE inspectable and needs special tools for access (except for the build.rs generated stuff which is usually put inside the target directory).I wonder how a language that is designed from scratch would approach auto generation.
comments.content_cn:
过去十年我主要使用Rust编程，但最近一年也开始接触Go语言。Go语言的典型工作流涉及大量自动生成代码，因此微小的改动常因所有自动生成代码被提交至git仓库而迅速膨胀，轻松达到20倍的规模。相比之下，Rust实际上可能进行更多代码生成操作（例如通过build.rs处理bindgen类工具、通过宏实现serde等功能，以及几乎所有场景下使用的单态化泛型）。但这些代码几乎从不提交到git仓库（除部分可配置为命令行运行的build.rs工具外），至少99%的情况下不会提交。

这种差异直接影响开发体验。在Go生态中，开发者需手动调用自动生成工具，且容易遗忘操作直至持续集成系统发出提醒。这类生成工具通常运行缓慢，其缓存机制也远不如Rust社区开发的方案智能。而在Rust生态中，自动生成代码最差情况会在每次编译时运行，最佳情况则由多级缓存系统（cargo层级、rustc层级）自动处理。但即便如此，每个执行git拉取的操作者仍需重新生成代码；而Go的自动生成模式理论上只需实际修改生成代码的开发者运行生成工具，其他人通过git拉取即可获得更新。

因此在Go语言中，执行git拉取后集成开发环境可立即就绪，无需编译数百个依赖项构成的树状结构。Go的集成开发环境和编译器速度极快，几乎如同……

comments.author: yoan9224
comments.content: The positioning is interesting - claiming Rust's performance with Go's simplicity is basically every new systems language's promise since 2015. The key differentiator seems to be "zero-cost exceptions" which I assume means compile-time Result types without runtime unwinding overhead? That's compelling if true, since Rust's Result ergonomics can get verbose in deeply nested error chains.But the real test is compile times and cognitive overhead. Rust's borrow checker is theoretically elegant but practically brutal when you're learning or debugging. If Rue can achieve memory safety without lifetime annotations everywhere, that's genuinely valuable. However, I'm skeptical - you can't eliminate tradeoffs, only move them around. If there's no borrow checker, what prevents use-after-free? If there's garbage collection, why claim "lower level than Go"?The other critical factor is ecosystem maturity. Rust's pain is partially justified by its incredible crate ecosystem - tokio, serde, axum, etc. A new language needs either (1) seamless C FFI to bootstrap libraries, (2) a killer feature so valuable that people rewrite everything, or (3) 5+ years for the ecosystem to develop. Which path is Rue taking?I'd love to see real-world benchmarks on: compile time for a 50k line project, memory usage of a long-running web server compared to Rust/Go, and cold start latency for CLI tools. Those metrics matter more than theoretical performance claims. The "fun to write" claim is subjective but important - if it's genuinely more ergonomic than Rust without sacrificing performance, that could attract the "Python developers wanting systems programming" demographic.
comments.content_cn:
这个定位很有意思——声称兼具Rust的性能与Go的简洁性，基本上是2015年以来每个新兴系统语言的共同承诺。关键差异点似乎是“零成本异常处理”，我猜这意味着编译期Result类型无需运行时解包开销？如果属实确实很有吸引力，毕竟Rust的Result机制在深层错误链中会变得冗长。

但真正的考验在于编译时间和认知负荷。Rust的借用检查器理论优雅，但在学习或调试时实际体验堪称残酷。如果Rue能在不处处标注生命周期的情况下实现内存安全，那确实很有价值。不过我持怀疑态度——你无法消除权衡，只能转移代价。如果没有借用检查器，如何防止悬垂指针？如果有垃圾回收，又凭什么声称“比Go更底层”？

另一个关键因素是生态成熟度。Rust的痛苦某种程度上被其卓越的crate生态所抵消——tokio、serde、axum等。新语言要么需要（1）无缝的C语言FFI来快速构建库生态，（2）具备让人愿意重写所有代码的杀手级特性，要么（3）等待5年以上培育生态。Rue选择哪条路径？

我期待看到实际场景的基准测试：5万行项目的编译时间、与Rust/Go对比的长时运行Web服务器内存占用、CLI工具的冷启动延迟。这些指标比理论性能主张更有说服力。“编写乐趣”的说法虽主观但很重要……

comments.author: onlyrealcuzzo
comments.content: Also working on a language / runtime in this space.It transpiles to Zig, so you have native access to the entire C library.It uses affine types (simple ownership -> transfers via GIVE/TAKES), MVCC & transactions to safely and scalably handle mutations (like databases, but it scales linearly after 32 cores, Arc and RwLock fall apart due to Cache Line Bouncing).It limits concurrent complexity only to the spot in your code WHERE you want to mutate shared memory concurrently, not your entire codebase.It's memory and liveness safe (Rust is only memory safe) without a garbage collector.It's simpler than Go, too, IMO - and more predictable, no GC.But it's nearly impossible to beat Go at its own game, and it's not zero overhead like Rust - so I'm pessimistic it's in a "sweet spot" that no one will be interested in.Time will tell.
comments.content_cn: 我也在这个领域开发一门语言/运行时。它可转译为Zig，因此能原生访问整个C语言库。该系统采用仿射类型（通过GIVE/TAKES实现简单所有权转移）、MVCC和事务机制，以安全且可扩展的方式处理数据变更（类似数据库，但在超过32核后仍能保持线性扩展，而Arc和RwLock会因缓存行冲突失效）。它将并发复杂性严格限制在代码中需要并发修改共享内存的特定位置，而非整个代码库。该语言具备内存安全性和活性安全性（Rust仅保证内存安全），且无需垃圾回收机制。在我看来，它比Go更简洁，也更可预测——因为没有GC。但要在Go的主场超越它几乎不可能，且它不像Rust那样实现零开销——因此我对其处于"无人问津的甜蜜点"持悲观态度。时间会证明一切。

comments.author: pron
comments.content: > Where type system complexity entails a tradeoff between the complexity of the language and how powerful the language is in allowing you to define abstractions.I don't think that's right. The level of abstraction is the number of implementations that are accepted for a particular interface (which includes not only the contract of the interface expressed in the type system, but also informally in the documentation). E.g. "round" is a higher abstraction than "red and round" because the set of round things is larger than the set of red and round things. It is often untyped languages that offer the highest level of abstraction, while a sophisticated type system narrows abstraction (it reduces the number of accepted implementations of an interface). That's not to say that higher abstraction is always better - although it does have practical consequences, explained in the next paragraph - but the word "abstraction" does mean something specific, certainly more specific than "describing things".How the level of abstraction is felt is by considering how many changes to client code (the user of an interface) is required when making a change to the implementation. Languages that are "closer to the underlying machine" - especially as far as memory management goes - generally have lower abstraction than languages that are less explicit about memory management. A local change to how a subroutine manages memory typically requires more changes to the client - i.e. the language offers a lower abstraction - in a language that's "closer to the metal", whether the language has a rich type system like Rust or a simpler type system like C, than a language that is farther away.
comments.content_cn:
当类型系统的复杂性需要在语言复杂性与语言在定义抽象能力方面的强大程度之间做出权衡时，我认为这种观点并不准确。抽象层次指的是特定接口所接受的实现数量（这不仅包括类型系统所表达的接口契约，还包括文档中非正式说明的部分）。例如，“圆形”比“红色且圆形”的抽象层次更高，因为圆形物体的集合大于红色且圆形物体的集合。通常，无类型语言提供最高层次的抽象，而复杂的类型系统反而会限制抽象（它减少了接口可接受的实现数量）。这并不是说更高的抽象总是更好——尽管它确实具有实际影响，下一段将对此进行解释——但“抽象”一词确实有特定含义，肯定比“描述事物”更具体。

抽象层次的感受方式在于考虑当对实现进行更改时，客户端代码（接口的使用者）需要做出多少修改。那些“更接近底层机器”的语言——尤其是在内存管理方面——通常比那些对内存管理不那么明确的语言具有更低的抽象层次。对子程序内存管理方式的局部更改通常需要对客户端进行更多修改——也就是说，这种语言提供的抽象层次较低……

posts.title: Show HN: Books mentioned on Hacker News in 2025
posts.author: seinvak
posts.title_cn: 《展示 HN：2025 年 Hacker News 上提及的书籍》
posts.abstract:
该帖子汇总了Hacker News社区在2025年提及的书籍榜单，引发用户对推荐内容和方法论的讨论。核心话题围绕榜单的构成意义及技术实现方式展开。

多数用户对项目表示赞赏，认为榜单体现了社区广泛的阅读兴趣，既包含《SICP》《代码整洁之道》等技术经典，也收录了《1984》《沙丘》等科幻文学作品。有人认为这打破了外界对HN用户只关注技术的刻板印象，也有用户指出榜单中《银河系漫游指南》恰好出现42次，堪称有趣的巧合。

讨论中主要分歧集中在数据方法论上。有用户建议应对比2024年数据以突显年度变化，否则榜单仅反映长期热门书籍；也有用户指出当前统计方式未能区分书籍是被随意提及还是被明确推荐，可能影响参考价值。此外，部分用户提到书籍匹配存在误差，如将《龙书》误列为《The Book of Dragons》。

普遍共识是该项目为社区提供了有价值的阅读参考，但需优化数据抓取与分类逻辑，以更精准地反映社区讨论趋势。

comments.author: yoan9224
comments.content: This is a clever aggregation project, but I think the methodology might miss some important signal-to-noise distinctions. A book mentioned once in passing ("oh yeah, like in [book]") carries very different weight than a book recommended explicitly ("you should read [book] if you want to understand X"). Are you parsing comment sentiment or just doing keyword extraction?The real value would be in clustering books by topic and showing which ones appear together in discussions. If someone mentions "Designing Data-Intensive Applications" and "Database Internals" in the same comment, that's a stronger signal than two isolated mentions. You could build a recommendation engine from that co-occurrence data.Also curious about the temporal aspect - tracking which books surge during certain news cycles. For example, did "Chip War" mentions spike when the AI compute restrictions hit? That contextual analysis would make this way more useful than a static ranked list. Would definitely use this if it had those features.
comments.content_cn:
这是一个巧妙的聚合项目，但我觉得方法论可能忽略了某些重要的信噪比区分。一本被顺带提及的书（比如“哦对，就像[某书]里那样”）与明确推荐的书（“如果你想理解X，应该读读[某书]”）具有完全不同的权重。你们是在解析评论情感还是仅做关键词提取？

真正的价值在于按主题对书籍进行聚类，并展示哪些书在讨论中同时出现。如果有人在同一条评论中提到《数据密集型应用系统设计》和《数据库内核》，这比孤立提及两本书的信号更强。你们可以利用这种共现数据构建推荐引擎。

另外对时间维度很好奇——追踪哪些书在特定新闻周期中激增。例如，当AI计算限制政策出台时，《芯片战争》的提及量是否激增？这种情境分析会让这个项目比静态排名列表有用得多。如果具备这些功能，我肯定会使用它。

沉浸于幻想与科幻作品能帮助我们理解自我与周遭世界，发现真正触动心灵的事物，教会我们憧憬一个更美好的未来世界。

comments.author: threethirtytwo
comments.content: What Le Guin is expressing is a beautiful idea, but it is a false beauty. It feels like truth because it aligns with how narrative engages the human mind, not because it accurately explains what stories are or why they exist. The sense that fiction reveals destiny, inner depth, or essential humanity is an illusion created by evolved cognitive machinery, not evidence of genuine insight.From an evolutionary and cognitive standpoint, imaginative fiction is not a privileged tool for understanding who we are. It is a byproduct of more basic adaptations. The human brain evolved as a prediction engine optimized for survival in social groups. Its primary function is to anticipate outcomes, model other agents, and reduce uncertainty well enough to reproduce. Narrative arises because the brain naturally organizes experience into causal sequences involving agents, not because stories convey deeper truths about the self.Fiction works by hijacking the same neural systems used for social reasoning, memory, and planning. When reading a story, the mind runs simulations of social situations. This feels like insight, but feeling insight is not the same as acquiring accurate models of reality. Fantasy and science fiction are not special forms of wisdom. They are simply inputs that exaggerate certain variables, making simulations emotionally vivid rather than epistemically reliable.Le Guin’s claim that someone without stories would be ignorant of their emotional or spiritual depths is not supported by biology. Emotions are not learned through narrative. They are innate regulatory systems shaped by natural selection. Fear, attachment, anger, desire, and joy exist prior to language and independently of story exposure. Stories can name, frame, or intensify these states, but they do not create or deepen them in any fundamental sense.The universality of storytelling also does not imply that it is an adaptive route to understanding. Evolution does not favor truth or self knowledge. It favors fitness. Many of the most persistent stories humans tell are systematically false. Myths, religious narratives, romantic ideals, and national legends endure because they exploit cognitive biases like agency detection, pattern completion, and emotional salience. Their spread demonstrates susceptibility, not insight.Fantasy and science fiction do not teach us to imagine better worlds. They teach us to imagine compelling ones. A narrative can feel profound while being completely disconnected from reality. Inspiration and accuracy are orthogonal. The persuasive power of stories comes from their alignment with evolved psychological vulnerabilities, not from their correspondence with truth.So the correct technical framing is this. Stories are not tools invented to gain understanding of humanity or destiny. They are artifacts produced by brains shaped for survival under uncertainty. They can be pleasurable, motivating, or culturally stabilizing. They can sometimes illuminate patterns of behavior. But their beauty should not be confused with truth. The feeling of depth they produce is an illusion, not a discovery.

posts.title: Claude Code gets native LSP support
posts.author: JamesSwift
posts.title_cn: Claude Code 获得原生 LSP 支持
posts.abstract: 该讨论围绕Claude Code新增原生LSP支持展开，核心话题是AI编程工具与开发环境的整合趋势。多数用户肯定LSP支持能提升编码效率，但也存在争议：有人认为JetBrains等传统IDE错失AI集成良机，功能落后于Cursor等新兴工具；也有用户指出当前LSP实现不完善，如缺少实时错误诊断，仍需依赖外部检查工具。讨论中部分用户对CLI形态的AI工具表示困惑，质疑其相比GUI/IDE的优势；另有用户反馈Claude Code存在自动更新故障、缺乏重命名符号等基础功能。共识在于LSP支持是重要进步，但分歧集中在工具形态选择（CLI vs IDE）、传统厂商转型速度以及功能完整性上。

comments.author: ramoz
comments.content:
I haven't come across a case where it has used the LSP yet.Opus 4.5 is fairly consistent in running QA at proper times. Lint checks and all are already incorporated into a standard & native processes outside of IDE. I think lookup can be useful when definitions are hidden deep in hard to reach places on my disk... hasn't been a problem though the agent usually finds what it needs.Anyway, here is what it stated it could do:    > Do you have access to an lsp tool?

     Yes, I have an LSP tool with these operations:

    - goToDefinition - Find where a symbol is defined
    - findReferences - Find all references to a symbol
    - hover - Get documentation/type info for a symbol
    - documentSymbol - Get all symbols in a file
    - workspaceSymbol - Search for symbols across the workspace
    - goToImplementation - Find implementations of an interface/abstract method
    - prepareCallHierarchy - Get call hierarchy item at a position
    - incomingCalls - Find what calls a function
    - outgoingCalls - Find what a function calls
comments.content_cn:
我还没遇到过需要使用LSP的情况。Opus 4.5在合适的时间运行质量检查方面相当稳定。代码检查等功能都已经集成到IDE之外的标准原生流程中了。我觉得当定义隐藏在我磁盘上难以访问的深处时，查找功能可能会很有用……不过目前还没遇到问题，代理程序通常都能找到所需内容。总之，以下是它声称能实现的功能：

    > 您是否可以使用lsp工具？

     是的，我拥有具备以下操作的LSP工具：

    - 转到定义 - 查找符号定义位置
    - 查找引用 - 查找符号的所有引用
    - 悬停提示 - 获取符号的文档/类型信息
    - 文档符号 - 获取文件中的所有符号
    - 工作区符号 - 在整个工作区搜索符号
    - 转到实现 - 查找接口/抽象方法的实现
    - 准备调用层次结构 - 获取指定位置的调用层次项
    - 传入调用 - 查找调用函数的对象
    - 传出调用 - 查找函数调用的对象

comments.author: rane
comments.content: You don't want to run tests after every file change, because that will distract Claude from finishing whatever it's doing and add noise to the context window. Of course the tests will be broken if Claude hasn't finished the full change yet.Running tests makes most sense on the Stop hook event, but personally I've found CLAUDE.md instruction of "Run `just check` after changes" to be effective enough. The Stop hook has the issue that it will run the checks every time Claude stops responding, even after without any changes.
comments.content_cn: 你不希望每次文件更改后都运行测试，因为这会分散Claude完成手头工作的注意力，并给上下文窗口增加干扰。如果Claude尚未完成全部修改，测试自然会失败。在停止钩子事件时运行测试最为合理，但就个人经验而言，我发现CLAUDE.md中"修改后运行`just check`"的指令已经足够有效。停止钩子的问题在于，它会在Claude每次停止响应时都运行检查，即使没有任何更改也是如此。

comments.author: eterm
comments.content: I completely agree. Likewise I'm amazed Microsoft hasn't done it themselves for Roslyn and Copilot. Roslyn analyzers are so incredibly powerful, and it's being ignored.An explainer for others:Not only can analyzers act as basic linters, but transformations are built right in to them. Every time claude does search-and-replace to add a parameter I want to cry a little, this has been a solved science.Agents + Roslyn would be productive like little else. Imagine an agent as an orchestrator but manipulation through commands to an API that maintains guard rails and compilability.Claude is already capable of writing roslyn analyzers, and roslyn has an API for implementing code transformations ( so called "quick fixes" ), so they already are out there in library form.It's hard to describe them to anyone who hasn't used a similarly powerful system, but essentially it enables transforms that go way beyond simple find/replace. You get accurate transformations that can be quite complex and deep reworks to the code itself.A simple example would be transforming a foreach loop into a for loop, or transforming and optimizing linq statements.And yet we find these tools unused with agentic find/replace doing the heavy lifting instead.Whichever AI company solves LSP and compiler based deep refactoring will see their utility shoot through the roof for working with large codebases.
comments.content_cn:
我完全同意。同样让我惊讶的是微软没有为Roslyn和Copilot自行实现这一点。Roslyn分析器的能力如此强大，却被忽视了。

为其他人解释一下：分析器不仅能充当基础代码检查工具，其内部本就内置了代码转换功能。每次看到Claude用查找替换方式添加参数时，我都有些无奈——这明明已是成熟的技术方案。

智能体与Roslyn的结合将带来无与伦比的生产力。想象一个作为协调器的智能体，通过向API发送命令来操控代码，同时保持规范约束和可编译性。

Claude已经能够编写Roslyn分析器，而Roslyn本身就提供了实现代码转换的API（即所谓的“快速修复”功能），这些工具早已以库的形式存在。

对于未接触过类似强大系统的人很难描述其精妙，但本质上它能实现远超简单查找替换的代码转换。你可以进行精确的代码重构，完成相当复杂深度的代码重组。

举个简单例子：将foreach循环转换为for循环，或者对LINQ语句进行转换优化。

然而我们发现这些工具未被充分利用，反而是智能体主导的查找替换承担着重任。

任何能解决LSP和基于编译器的深度重构的AI公司，在处理大型代码库时都将获得飞跃性的实用价值提升。

posts.title: I program on the subway
posts.author: evakhoury
posts.title_cn: 我在地铁上编程
posts.abstract: 该讨论围绕“在地铁上编程”这一核心话题展开，探讨通勤时间用于编程工作的可行性与体验。许多用户分享了个人经历，认为地铁环境能有效隔绝干扰，提升专注度，尤其适合无网络依赖的编程任务；也有用户指出，通勤时的身体状态（如疲惫、拥挤）或网络延迟可能影响效率。讨论中提到，随着移动网络改善（低延迟、稳定连接），在地铁上进行联网工作已变得更加便利。分歧点主要在于通勤环境是否真正适合高效工作：部分用户视其为宝贵的专注时间，另一些则强调拥挤、疲劳等因素会降低生产力。共识是，地铁编程的可行性高度依赖个人习惯、通勤条件及任务类型，而无网络环境反而被部分人视为促进深度工作的契机。

comments.author: dackle
comments.content: Here is a description of the daily commute by Michael Milken, 1980s junk bond king, as told in "Predator's Ball" by Connie Bruck:At 5:30am each weekday in the early 1970s, a bus pulled up to a stop in Cherry Hill, New Jersey, and a young man lugging a bag that bulged with papers mounted its steps. He was making the two-hour commute to New York City, where he worked at the investment­ banking firm of Drexel Firestone. The train would have provided a more comfortable and faster ride; but, for those very reasons, it also offered more opportunity to meet other Wall Street acquaintances. They would want to engage in the kind of idle small talk that commuters share to pass the time. The thought must have been intolerable. He did not wish to be rude, but he wanted no interrup­tion.As soon as he had settled into his seat, being sure to take one with an empty one adjacent, he unloaded a mountain of prospectuses and 10ks (annual Securities and Exchange Commission filings) onto the seat next to him. On winter mornings the sky was still pitch black and the light on the bus was too dim for him to be able to read. He wore a leather aviation cap with the earflaps down; he had been bald for years, and although he wore a toupee his head always felt cold on these frosty mornings. Now over his aviation cap he fitted a miner's headlamp -- strapped around the back of his head, with a huge light projecting from his forehead.
comments.content_cn:
以下是康妮·布鲁克在《掠食者之舞》中描述的20世纪80年代垃圾债券之王迈克尔·米尔肯的日常通勤场景：

20世纪70年代初，每个工作日的清晨5点30分，一辆巴士会停靠在新泽西州樱桃山的一个站点，一位手提鼓鼓囊囊文件袋的年轻人登上车门。他正踏上前往纽约市的两小时通勤路，在那里的德崇证券投资银行工作。火车本可提供更舒适快捷的旅程；但正因如此，它也带来了更多偶遇华尔街熟人的机会。那些人总会进行通勤者之间消磨时间的闲谈。这种想法想必令他难以忍受。他并非有意失礼，只是不愿被打扰。

一找到座位——他总会特意选旁边有空位的——他便将堆积如山的招股说明书和10-K年报（美国证券交易委员会年度备案文件）摊放在邻座上。冬日的天空仍漆黑如墨，巴士灯光过于昏暗无法阅读。他头戴一顶耳罩垂下的皮质飞行帽；早年秃顶的他虽戴着假发，严寒清晨仍觉头顶冰凉。此刻他在飞行帽外又套上了矿工头灯——灯带绕过后脑，硕大的光源从前额投射而出。

comments.content: 17 years ago I went to a summer vacation with my family (still a teenager). That meant 10 days without any internet connectivity. I just got my first laptop and I was allowed to take it with me. I was reverse engineering MSN Messenger's user to user and profile picture exchange protocol from TCP dumps. MSN Messenger did not use any encryption. Before I went to the vacation I recorded a bunch of sessions with Wireshark (maybe it was still Ethereal back then). Then for 10 days I was just trying to figure out from the dumps how the binary protocol worked and was writing the code without any way to test it. When I came back I just had to fix some minor bugs and it worked. Fun times.
comments.content_cn: 17年前，我和家人一起度暑假（那时还是个青少年）。这意味着整整10天没有任何网络连接。我刚拿到第一台笔记本电脑，被允许带上它。当时我正在通过TCP数据包逆向分析MSN Messenger的用户间通信及头像交换协议。MSN Messenger没有使用任何加密技术。出发度假前，我用Wireshark（可能那时还叫Ethereal）记录了一系列会话数据。接下来的十天里，我仅凭这些数据包试图解析二进制协议的工作原理，并编写代码，期间完全无法测试。回来后只稍作调试就成功运行了。真是段有趣的时光。

comments.author: komali2
comments.content: > they would have to do it at a station, where they could immediately get off the train. I think, though, that this would be risky, given that subway stops generally have a lot of people getting on/off the train in the first place.I've seen a phone jacking in this exact scenario and nobody moved to stop the guy running. Nobody on the train can help cause the doors have closed, and nobody on the platform has any idea anything just happened, or if they do the guy is well gone before they can put two and two together.For me I always pocket my phone or e-reader at each stop, unless I'm in Japan or Taiwan.
comments.content_cn: 他们必须在车站下手，这样能立刻下车逃跑。但我认为这很冒险，毕竟地铁站本身就有大量上下车人群。我亲眼见过在这种场景下的手机抢夺案，根本没人阻拦逃跑者。车厢里的人帮不上忙，因为车门已关闭；站台上的人则完全不知道发生了什么，就算意识到也为时已晚——等他们反应过来，歹徒早已逃之夭夭。所以我每到一个站点都会把手机或电子阅读器收进口袋，除非是在日本或台湾。

comments.author: don-code
comments.content: Doing connected work from the subway has gotten much, much easier in the last few years. I attribute that to three things:1. Cell service has become low-latency. This is very different from "fast", which it has also become! When I started working from the train (on HSPA+), pings in the hundreds of milliseconds were the norm. My first step was usually to SSH to a remote machine, and let just the text lag on me. Nowadays, I can run a Web browser locally without issue.2. Cell service has, at the same time, become ubiquitous in subway tunnels. When I started, there were some areas that dropped down to EDGE (unusable), and some areas that had no service at all. Now, there is exactly one place on the Boston transit system - Back Bay Station - where I lose cell service.3. Noise cancelling tech has gotten better. It's not just about noise cancelling headphones: both of my laptops (a 2024 MBP and a ThinkPad P14s) have microphones that can filter out screeching wheels and noisy teenagers quite well. That means I can take meetings without making them miserable for the people on the other end.These, honestly, are a huge game-changer for me. The ability to take a 30 minute meeting while commuting, where otherwise I would've had to get in early or stay late at work, actually does wonders for my ability to have a life outside of work.
comments.content_cn: 过去几年在地铁上进行联网工作变得容易多了。我认为这主要归功于三点：1. 蜂窝网络延迟显著降低。这与"网速快"是不同概念——当然网速也确实变快了！早年我在火车上用HSPA+网络工作时，几百毫秒的延迟是常态。我通常要先SSH连接到远程主机，忍受文字传输的滞后。如今我本地运行网页浏览器都毫无压力。2. 地铁隧道里的信号覆盖已无处不在。最初有些区域会降级到EDGE网络（基本不可用），还有些区域完全没信号。现在整个波士顿地铁系统里，只有后湾站这一个地方会失去信号。3. 降噪技术大幅进步。不仅是降噪耳机，我的两台笔记本电脑（2024款MBP和ThinkPad P14s）都配备了能有效过滤车轮摩擦声和青少年喧哗的麦克风。这意味着我可以随时开会，而不会让电话那头的人受噪音折磨。说实话这些改变彻底解放了我。通勤途中能处理30分钟会议，不必再为此提前到岗或加班，这确实让我在工作之外拥有了更多生活可能。

comments.author: nathell
comments.content: A few years ago, I spotted a guy on the underground in Warsaw, hacking on some code in a language I didn't recognize, but it was definitely assembly of some sort. Being shy, I resorted to throwing curious glimpses at his laptop for a few stations, but eventually curiosity got the better of me and I asked ‘sorry, is this ARM’? To which the guy replies, smiling, ‘ah no, it’s MIPS!’Now I program casually in public spaces, including the underground, on my GPD Micro PC [0]. It, too, has attracted numerous glimpses and been a conversation starter on some occasions.[0]: https://blog.danieljanus.pl/2022/08/18/i-love-my-gpd-micro-p...
comments.content_cn: 几年前，我在华沙地铁上看到一个家伙在用一种我不认识的语言写代码，但肯定是某种汇编语言。由于害羞，我只好在几个站台间偷偷瞄他的笔记本电脑，但最终好奇心占了上风，我问道：“不好意思，这是ARM吗？”那人笑着回答：“啊不，是MIPS！”现在我也常在公共场所（包括地铁上）用我的GPD Micro PC [0]随意编程。它也吸引了不少好奇的目光，有时还成了开启对话的契机。[0]: https://blog.danieljanus.pl/2022/08/18/i-love-my-gpd-micro-p...

comments.author: abstractspoon
comments.content: Back in the 80s I would work on stacks of fanfold code printouts on my trips on the London underground to and from work
comments.content_cn: 八十年代时，我常带着成堆的折叠式代码打印件，在伦敦地铁通勤路上工作。

comments.author: mid-kid
comments.content: I used to commute 1h40m one way, which accounted for 50mins in a train (+10min avg waiting). While I ususally did pull out my laptop, the productivity just wasn't there - I can't consistently work while groggy/vitamin-d deficient during winter mornings, or in the evening being cooked after having worked for 8 hours (I have an office job, but not programming). The seats are cramped and uncomfortable, not being able to raise my arms enough to use the keyboard without bothering the passanger next to me, so I'd have to put it away during the crowded parts of the ride, and I'd be very frustrated if the train was unusually crowded. Having your "flow" be broken by arriving at the end stop and having to rush to pack your things is awful. The only conversation someone's struck up with me was a guy who insisted he'd never understand what I was doing even if he tried.Suffice to say, after almost two years of this, I was extremely tired and sleep deprived as this ate away at my available time more than what is reasonable. Using the time for personal projects didn't compensate for it. Never again, it's really not worth it.
comments.content_cn: 我曾每天单程通勤1小时40分钟，其中50分钟在火车上（平均还需等待10分钟）。虽然我通常会拿出笔记本电脑，但工作效率实在不高——冬日清晨昏昏欲睡又缺乏维生素D时，或是晚上完成8小时办公室工作后精疲力尽时（我从事文职工作，非编程类），我很难持续专注工作。火车座位狭窄不适，抬起手臂使用键盘就会碰到邻座乘客，因此在拥挤路段不得不收起电脑。若遇到异常拥挤的车厢，我会非常烦躁。最糟糕的是当沉浸在工作状态时，突然到站不得不匆忙收拾物品打断节奏。唯一一次有人搭话，是个坚持说“就算尝试也永远看不懂我在做什么”的男士。可以说，近两年这样的生活让我极度疲惫且睡眠不足，通勤吞噬的时间远超合理范围。即便利用通勤时间做个人项目也无法弥补这种消耗。我再也不会选择这种生活了，真的不值得。

comments.author: decafninja
comments.content: Proponents of public transportation often say how they love to be able to use it as peaceful downtime to read, work, meditate, etc.All my experience with public transportation is having to roll the dice and more often than not losing - having to stand while packed liked sardines into a bus or subway.
comments.content_cn: 公共交通的支持者常说他们喜欢利用通勤时间作为宁静的休息时刻来阅读、工作或冥想。但根据我的经验，乘坐公共交通更像是一场赌博，而且多数时候都会输——不得不像沙丁鱼一样挤在公交车或地铁里站着。

comments.author: incanus77
comments.content: About 20 years ago, I landed my first real, high-impact job at an upstart consulting agency in Washington DC that came from the ashes of the Howard Dean campaign. Unfortunately, I had also just signed a lease on an apartment in the town I lived in, a two hour drive from downtown DC.I spent the first year at that job commuting into DC 2-3 days/week, which involved about an hour drive, then an hour regional commuter train, then some Metro transfer and walking — then back again in the evening. I spent that train time offline (as it was 2004) learning the Apple Cocoa frameworks, as in another twist of fate, the company was entirely Apple laptop-based, which was fairly rare for 2004, and I built tools for the team and myself. The focus possible because I was offline, with comprehensive docs, was pretty intense and was a huge part of many aspects of my career to follow.
comments.content_cn: 大约二十年前，我在华盛顿特区一家新兴咨询机构找到了第一份真正具有重要影响力的工作，这家机构脱胎于霍华德·迪恩竞选团队的余烬。不巧的是，我刚在居住的城镇签下公寓租约，那里距离特区市中心有两小时车程。工作的第一年，我每周通勤前往特区2-3天，过程包括约一小时驾车、一小时区域通勤列车，再换乘地铁并步行一段——傍晚再原路折返。通勤列车上的时间因当时是2004年无法联网，我便借此学习苹果Cocoa框架——命运的另一处巧合是，这家公司全员使用苹果笔记本，这在2004年相当罕见。我为团队和自己开发工具。由于离线环境配合完整的文档，我能高度专注地投入学习，这段经历对我后续职业生涯的诸多方面产生了深远影响。

comments.author: nicbou
comments.content: My entire stack is meant to let me work offline in random locations. Until recently it was meant to run smoothly on a 12" Macbook. The output is also made for users on spotty internet connections. This comes from years of working while travelling. I can work offline for weeks if needed.I sometimes do "iPad work", which is essentially researching, reviewing and annotating content on my iPad Mini. I will hop on my bike and work an hour or two in different locations, over coffee or in the sun. It's a relaxing break from working on a computer at a desk.I do think that people should work in different places. Perhaps we'd have apps that work better on slow internet.
comments.content_cn: 我的整个技术栈都是为了让我能在任意地点离线工作。直到最近，这套系统还旨在12英寸Macbook上流畅运行。其输出也考虑到了网络不稳定的用户需求，这源于我多年旅行工作的经验。如有需要，我可以离线工作数周。我有时会进行“iPad工作”，主要是在iPad Mini上研究、审阅和批注内容。我会骑上自行车，在不同地点工作一两个小时，边喝咖啡或沐浴阳光。这是对桌前电脑工作的一种放松调剂。我确实认为人们应在不同场所工作。或许我们该开发在低速网络下运行更流畅的应用。

comments.author: ziofill
comments.content: When I was living in Paris I had a 20 min ride from home to work each day. I picked up the habit to read during those 40 total minutes and I was going through books like I had never been able to, because while 40 min is not a lot, it’s about 150h per year. One easily underestimates the power of consistency.
comments.content_cn: 在巴黎生活时，我每天上下班各有20分钟的通勤时间。我养成了在这总共40分钟里阅读的习惯，阅读量达到了前所未有的水平——虽然40分钟看似不多，但一年累计下来约有150小时。人们很容易低估坚持的力量。

comments.author: teddyh
comments.content: Many years ago, before mobile internet was reasonable and before wireless internet was available, and before even electrical outlets were something which could be counted on to be present on trains, I took a 6 hour train ride.  I had no laptop.  I printed out, on paper, the entire source code of the project I was working on, and brought a red pen.  I read through the whole thing, from start to finish.  Many subtle bug fixes, refactorings, and efficiency improvements were made that day.
comments.content_cn: 多年前，在移动互联网尚未普及、无线网络还未出现，甚至火车上连电源插座都难以保证的时代，我曾乘坐一趟六小时的火车。当时我没有笔记本电脑，便将手头项目的全部源代码打印在纸上，随身带了一支红笔。我逐字逐句通读了整份代码，那天我修正了许多细微的错误，进行了重构，并提升了代码效率。

comments.author: macNchz
comments.content: I recently bought a GPD MicroPC 2, a 7” laptop with a real keyboard. It runs Linux just fine, and it has been a fun experience of having a “real” computer with me much more often than I otherwise would. My version of programming on the subway has been programming on a park bench—it fits in a jacket pocket, or even the back pocket of some of my pants.  The keyboard is tiny but easy  enough to use with thumbs, or, with some practice, two-handed touch typing on a flat surface.It’s nice to be less tethered to a desk, while also not having to carry a backpack and heavier full laptop, but still able to remote in and do what I need to do. I really enjoy having a fully capable Linux PC in my pocket vs a smartphone.
comments.content_cn: 最近我入手了一台GPD MicroPC 2，这是一款带实体键盘的7英寸笔记本电脑。它运行Linux系统毫无压力，让我能更频繁地随身携带一台“真正”的电脑，体验非常有趣。以往我在地铁上编程，现在变成了在公园长椅上编程——它能轻松装进外套口袋，甚至我某些裤子的后袋。键盘虽小，但用拇指操作很方便，经过练习后也能在平面上双手触控打字。摆脱桌面的束缚感觉很好，既不用背着沉重的背包和全尺寸笔记本，又能远程处理所需事务。比起智能手机，我真的很享受口袋里装着一台功能完备的Linux电脑的感觉。

comments.author: saagarjha
comments.content: I used to do work on Caltrain, which used to be like 3 hours of my commute and didn't have any internet, so I would carefully plan what I could do beforehand. My code deploys to a machine that's very different from my laptop, but I had a Docker container set up to cross compile things and loaded up the docs beforehand, so as long as I planned out what I wanted to do.These days Caltrain is faster and has occasionally frustrating, but fairly good Wi-Fi, so now my constraints are that I don't have a large monitor but not really much else.
comments.content_cn: 以前我在加州火车上工作时，通勤时间大约三小时，而且车上没有网络，所以我得提前仔细规划好能做的事情。我的代码需要部署到一台与笔记本电脑环境差异很大的机器上，但我事先设置了Docker容器来进行交叉编译，并提前加载了文档，因此只要我规划好要完成的任务就能应对。如今加州火车提速了，虽然Wi-Fi偶尔会出问题但总体还算不错，所以现在我的限制条件主要是没有大屏幕显示器，其他方面倒没有太多不便。

comments.author: anonzzzies
comments.content: I program and did program anywhere; unlike OP, I thrive in (human) noise: if it's quiet, I cannot focus, so working at home with multi monitor setups etc works against me (music doesn't help: not random enough and I cannot talk to people when I feel the need). I prefer subways, busses, airplanes, lounges, coffeeshops, pubs etc. Offices strangely do not work as I already know those people so I get bored and creativity plummets. My setup now is the best I had ever: a rugged android tablet with week-long battery, running termux with full desktop linux (not rooted) which can run all I want. I run several llms offline on it as well to fix the workflow when I don't have my nice foldable full keyboard out (if no space). I can run everything in our framework, online and offline; when I come back online, I just sync (code AND data) and voila.
comments.content_cn: 我编程，而且随处可编；与楼主不同，我在（人声）嘈杂中反而高效：环境太安静时我无法集中注意力，所以在家用多显示器等设备工作反而适得其反（音乐也没用：不够随机，而且当我需要时无法与人交谈）。我更喜欢地铁、公交车、飞机、休息室、咖啡馆、酒吧等场所。奇怪的是办公室并不适合我，因为我已经认识那些人，会感到无聊，创造力骤降。我目前的设备是有史以来最好的：一台电池续航长达一周的坚固安卓平板，运行Termux并搭载完整的桌面Linux系统（未root），可以运行我所需的一切。我还在上面离线运行多个大语言模型，以便在无法展开便携折叠全键盘时（如果空间不足）优化工作流程。我可以在线和离线运行我们框架中的所有内容；当我重新联网时，只需同步（代码和数据）即可完成。

comments.author: sedatk
comments.content: What I miss about my long commutes on public transportation in early 2000’s was the serenity of doing absolutely nothing.It was essentially forced meditation, and it helped me a lot in reorganizing my thoughts.I had moved next to the office later, and noticed that I’d really missed those meditative hours. I saved maybe 1.5 hours of commute every day but my net productivity had declined.I don’t think it would be as easy to achieve the same effect today as it was back then. We now have phones and interactive ads, and that dopamine driven economy.I miss that about those times.
comments.content_cn: 我怀念21世纪初乘坐公共交通长途通勤的时光，那种什么都不做的宁静感。那本质上是一种被迫的冥想，对我整理思绪大有裨益。后来我搬到办公室附近，却发现自己真的很怀念那些冥想时刻。虽然每天节省了约1.5小时通勤时间，但我的净工作效率反而下降了。如今要获得同样的效果恐怕没那么容易——手机、互动广告，还有那些多巴胺驱动的经济模式。那个时代特有的宁静，正是我最怀念的。

comments.author: btreesOfSpring
comments.content: When I was part of a team developing a highly durable texting protocol, those of us in NYC would regularly test messaging while riding the subway. Between stations, you didn't have network access but different devices upon entering the next station would handle and recover from the interruptions in various ways.The subway produced so many repeatable network connection edge case problems. It was fantastic.
comments.content_cn: 当初我们团队开发高耐用性短信协议时，纽约的成员经常在地铁上测试消息传输。列车在站间行驶时完全没有网络信号，但不同设备在进入下一站时会以各种方式处理并恢复中断连接。地铁环境产生了大量可复现的网络连接边界案例问题，这真是太棒了。

comments.author: cadr
comments.content: I used to get so much done on my BART commute.  Also learned piano on a little 25 key midi keyboard until the program I was learning from started needing a 26th key.
comments.content_cn: 以前我乘BART通勤时效率特别高。还曾用25键的小型MIDI键盘学钢琴，直到后来教程需要用到第26个键。

comments.author: alexfoo
comments.content: Late 90’s I had a ~90 minute commute for a while (50min train with seat, 20min London Underground seat mostly, 15min train crammed, 10min walk).The longer train I would use my laptop, same with the 20min underground section on the journey in (going home no chance), but for the packed train and the walk I listened to music (I still have my Diamond Rio PMP300, no idea if it still works, just remember downsampling music to 32kbps to get more on a memory card, quality was less important than quantity - I must have listened to David Gray’s album _White Ladder_ many hundreds of times).Toshiba laptops (Satellite? I think they were before the Tecras), heavy and the battery life wasn’t much more than 90 minutes but it was just enough. Dual booting Windows and Linux. (Linux for dev work on the go…)Obviously no mobile connectivity back then, I had to have a plan for what I was going to work on and that also involved backup plans if I ran into a blocker on the primary. Same for the way home.A bit later I could get GPRS data rates via Infra-Red to my mobile and that just felt like magic.I found the times I couldn’t be on my laptop (walking or on the packed train) were great for thinking problems through and often had to stop to scribble down thoughts/ideas/solutions in a notebook that I kept in the laptop bag.Wrote so much useful code in that 18 months without the distractions of the Internet or emails or whatever.Now I somehow find I have less time despite having virtually no commute. Technology has vastly increased the number of distractions and I have let myself succumb to them. Where I had no real choice in what music I listened to now I have too much choice. There’s always one last thing to check before I get on with a bit of work. Sometimes I wish for simpler times.
comments.content_cn:
九十年代末，我曾有过一段约90分钟的通勤时光（50分钟火车有座，20分钟伦敦地铁基本有座，15分钟火车拥挤不堪，10分钟步行）。在较长的火车行程中我会使用笔记本电脑，去程时那20分钟地铁段也是如此（回程则完全没机会），但在拥挤的火车和步行时段我会听音乐（我至今还留着那台戴蒙德·里奥PMP300播放器，不知是否还能用，只记得当时常把音乐下采样至32kbps以在存储卡里存更多歌曲——数量远比质量重要，大卫·格雷的专辑《白梯》我恐怕听了不下数百遍）。东芝笔记本电脑（是Satellite系列吗？我记得它们在Tecra系列之前），机身沉重且电池续航刚过90分钟，但勉强够用。我装了Windows和Linux双系统（Linux用于途中开发工作……）。

那时显然没有移动网络，我必须提前规划好工作内容，甚至为主任务遇到阻碍时准备备用方案。回家路上也是如此。稍晚些时候，我通过红外线连接手机实现了GPRS数据传输，那种体验堪称神奇。

我发现无法使用笔记本电脑的时段（步行或挤在车厢里）非常适合深入思考问题，常常需要停下脚步，从电脑包里掏出笔记本匆匆记下灵感、构思或解决方案。在那十八个月里，没有网络、邮件等干扰，我写出了大量实用代码。

如今我几乎无需通勤，却莫名感到时间更少了。

posts.title: Measuring AI Ability to Complete Long Tasks
posts.author: spicypete
posts.title_cn: "评估AI完成长任务的能力"
posts.abstract: 该讨论围绕AI执行长任务能力评估展开。核心话题是衡量当前大语言模型（如Claude Opus、GPT-5.1）在需要多步骤推理的复杂任务中的实际表现。有人认为AI已能高效处理陌生领域的开发任务，例如用户分享其通过简单指令让AI自动完成向量搜索功能的完整搭建；也有用户指出当前测试基准存在局限，认为模型在现实场景中完成几分钟人类任务的成功率远未达到研究声称的接近100%。讨论中提到性能优化可作为评估AI智能的有效基准，同时有分歧存在于如何定义“长任务”——例如有观点认为“训练对抗性鲁棒的图像模型”并不属于此类。共识方面，用户普遍认同需要更细化的评估指标（如95%与99%成功率的对比数据）以及纳入更多模型（如Gemini 3.0 Pro）进行测试，以更好理解AI在边界任务中的可靠性差异。

comments.author: subdavis
comments.content: I recently asked Opus to just “Add vector search” to my current hobby project, a topic I know very little about. It set up manticore, pulled an embedding model, wrote a migration tool for my old keyword indices, and built the front end. I’m not exaggerating much either: the prompt was the length of a tweet.I think it would easily have taken me 4+ hours to do that.  It ran in 15 minutes while I played Kirby Air Riders and worked on the first try.Afterward, I sort of had to reflect on the fact that I learned essentially nothing about building vector search. I wanted the feature more than I wanted to know how to build the feature. It kept me learning the thing I cared about rather than doing a side quest.

comments.content: After spending many hours optimizing some routines I now think performance optimization is a great benchmark for identifiying how generally smart an AI is at helping with some specific piece of code.Solutions are quite easy to verify with differential testing and produce a number for direct comparison.Less code is usually better and you generally can't "cheat" by adding more cruft so it nullifies the additive bias. Good optimization requires significant understanding of the underlying structures. Everything has performance tradeoffs so it requires systemic thinking and not just stringing independent pieces together.So far I've found that Gemini Pro 3 was the best at reasoning about tricky SIMD code but the results with most models were pretty underwhelming.
comments.content_cn: 经过长时间优化某些例程后，我认为性能优化是衡量AI在协助特定代码方面通用智能程度的绝佳基准。通过差分测试可以轻松验证解决方案，并得出可直接比较的数值。代码越少通常越好，且无法通过堆砌冗余内容来“作弊”，这消除了累积偏差。优秀的优化需要对底层结构有深刻理解。所有决策都存在性能权衡，因此需要系统性思维，而非简单拼接独立模块。目前我发现Gemini Pro 3在处理复杂SIMD代码的推理上表现最佳，但多数模型的结果仍不尽如人意。

comments.author: yoan9224
comments.content: The key insight from this benchmark is using "human-equivalent hours" rather than actual AI execution time. It's measuring capability complexity, not speed.What's interesting is the 50% vs 80% reliability gap. At 50% success rate on a 4-hour task, you're essentially gambling. If it fails, you've potentially wasted the 4 hours plus the time debugging why it failed.This is why I think the current "agent" paradigm needs human checkpoints at regular intervals. Let the AI work for 30 minutes, then review progress. Repeat. This way you catch drift early before it compounds.The other thing missing from these benchmarks: recovery ability. When the AI gets stuck on hour 3 of a 4-hour task, can it recognize the problem and backtrack? Or does it confidently continue down the wrong path?
comments.content_cn:
这项基准测试的关键洞见在于采用“人类等效工时”而非实际AI执行时间。它衡量的是能力复杂度，而非速度。

有趣的是50%与80%可靠性之间的差距。对于一项4小时的任务，若成功率仅为50%，本质上就像在赌博。一旦失败，你不仅可能浪费这4小时，还要额外花费时间调试失败原因。

因此我认为当前的“智能体”范式需要定期设置人工检查点：让AI工作30分钟后复核进度，如此循环。这样能在问题累积前及早发现偏差。

这些基准测试还遗漏了另一个维度：恢复能力。当AI在4小时任务的第3小时陷入困境时，它能否识别问题并回溯修正？还是继续在错误道路上盲目推进？

comments.author: TobiasJBeers
comments.content:
The “50% time horizon” feels most actionable when you pair it with an expected-value model.
For a given task: EV ≈ (human_time_saved × $/hour) − (p_fail × cost_of_failure) − (iteration/oversight cost).
A model crossing 4h-at-50% might be hugely useful for low failure-cost work, and still net-negative for anything where rollback/debug is expensive. The missing piece is how p_fail scales with task length + how recoverable failures are.
comments.content_cn: 将“50%时间阈值”与期望价值模型结合使用时最具可操作性。对于特定任务：期望价值≈（节省的人工时间×时薪）−（失败概率×失败成本）−（迭代/监督成本）。达到50%阈值且耗时4小时的模型对于低失败成本的工作可能极具价值，但对于回滚/调试成本高昂的任务仍可能产生净负收益。关键在于失败概率如何随任务时长变化，以及故障的可恢复性如何。

posts.title: Indoor tanning makes youthful skin much older on a genetic level
posts.author: SanjayMehta
posts.title_cn: 室内美黑在基因层面加速皮肤老化。
posts.abstract:
该讨论围绕室内美黑对皮肤衰老的基因层面影响展开。核心话题是美黑床的紫外线照射会加速皮肤老化，并可能增加皮肤癌风险。

社区普遍认同紫外线会损害皮肤，有用户指出研究显示美黑床使用者的皮肤基因突变甚至超过年长一倍的非使用者。讨论中提到，美黑本质上是在加速皮肤损伤，且许多地区因日晒文化导致人群皮肤更早出现皱纹和色斑。

主要争议点在于美黑与维生素D补充的利弊权衡。有人认为美黑床中的UVB能促进维生素D合成并提升多巴胺水平，带来愉悦感；也有用户指出这不如直接服用补充剂安全，并质疑为追求肤色加深而承受健康风险的文化现象。此外，对于美黑是否影响整体死亡率，用户提及相关研究结论尚不明确。

部分用户以讽刺态度看待美黑行为，将其类比为对牙齿过度美白或注射唇填充物等可能带来长期负面效应的审美趋势。

comments.author: pazimzadeh
comments.content: Funny timing, I just went to a tanning salon for the first time yesterday. I asked for the weakest bed (level 1), which has the most UVB (for vitamin D production). They were shocked that I wanted to use level 1, apparently no one uses it. They also suggested starting at 5 mins instead of the 1-2 minutes I wanted to do. The machine itself has a notice saying not to go over 3 mins for the first week.I was following the protocol from this paper, which started people at 2 mins and used low wattage UVB-heavy bulbs.Sunbeds with UVB radiation can produce physiological levels of serum 25-Hydroxyvitamin D in healthy volunteershttps://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC5821157/Unfortunately the Science Advances paper being discussed is epidemiological and doesn't distinguish between the type of bulb, length of time, and other parameters used while tanning. However it is safe to say that the average tanner cares more about getting dark than anything else.I think there would actually be a market for vitamin D centered "healthy tanning" where only low wattage, high-UVB bulbs are used particularly in cloudy areas or where the winter is long. I'm that guessing the operating costs for that kind of business would be cheaper than your average tanning salon, too.
comments.content_cn: 时机真巧，我昨天第一次去了美黑沙龙。我要求使用最弱的晒黑床（1级），这种床的UVB含量最高（有助于维生素D合成）。他们对我选择1级感到惊讶，显然没人会用这个级别。他们还建议从5分钟开始，而不是我原本计划的1-2分钟。机器本身贴有提示，注明第一周使用不要超过3分钟。我其实是按照某篇论文的方案操作的，该研究让参与者从2分钟开始，并使用低瓦数、高UVB的灯管。这篇论文指出：使用含UVB辐射的晒黑床可使健康志愿者血清25-羟基维生素D达到生理水平（相关论文链接已省略）。可惜正在讨论的《科学进展》期刊论文是流行病学研究，没有区分灯管类型、照射时长和美黑时的其他参数。但可以肯定的是，普通美黑者最在意的还是肤色变深的效果。我认为以维生素D为核心的"健康美黑"市场其实存在潜力，特别是在多云地区或冬季漫长的区域，可以专门使用低瓦数、高UVB的灯管。我猜这类业务的运营成本也会比普通美黑沙龙更低。

comments.author: cpncrunch
comments.content: Link to study: https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC12700204/Although I think the more interesting question is whether sunbed use increases or decreases overall mortality. The only study I can find is Lindqvist's:https://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/pdf/10.1111/joim.12251?g...Overall, sunbed use reduced the all-cause mortality by a ratio of 0.77 or 0.87 depending on the model used. It increased the risk of developing MM, and the risk of dying from MM, although all-cause mortality was not increased even in patients diagnosed with MM. (This seems to be because there is a very low overall risk of MM mortality, but UV light exposure seems to provide a greater overall health benefit than the small risk of increased MM risk).
comments.content_cn: 研究链接：https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC12700204/虽然我认为更有趣的问题是使用日光浴床是否会增加或降低总体死亡率。我能找到的唯一研究是林德奎斯特的：https://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/pdf/10.1111/joim.12251?g...总体而言，根据所用模型的不同，使用日光浴床可将全因死亡率降低0.77或0.87的比例。它增加了患恶性黑色素瘤的风险以及死于该病的风险，但即使在被诊断为恶性黑色素瘤的患者中，全因死亡率也没有增加。（这似乎是因为恶性黑色素瘤死亡率的总体风险非常低，而紫外线照射似乎带来的整体健康益处大于其略微增加的恶性黑色素瘤风险）。

And that is for a much larger area of the skin than the one mentioned.Also I wonder about the quote that a mutated cell can never go back. The immune system could kill the mutated cells and thereby promote the unmutated ones. Though nothing is perfect of course. https://www.ucl.ac.uk/news/2020/jan/analysis-protective-lung...

comments.author: yoan9224
comments.content: The UV damage from tanning beds has been well documented for decades, but what's novel here is the genetic methylation analysis showing accelerated aging at the DNA level.What's wild to me is the economics. Tanning salons charge $30-50/month to give you skin cancer. Meanwhile vitamin D supplements cost $10/year and achieve the same health benefit people claim to seek from tanning.The only rational argument I've heard for controlled UV exposure is building a base tan before vacation to prevent burning. But even then, 1-2 minutes in a low-wattage bed would suffice - not the 20+ minute sessions people actually do.
comments.content_cn: 日光浴床的紫外线伤害已有数十年充分记录，但这次的新颖之处在于基因甲基化分析揭示了DNA层面的加速老化。最令我惊讶的是经济账：美黑沙龙每月收费30-50美元让你得皮肤癌，而维生素D补充剂每年仅需10美元就能实现人们声称通过美黑追求的健康益处。我听过唯一合理的紫外线照射理由是度假前建立基础肤色以防晒伤，但即便如此，低功率日光浴床照射1-2分钟就足够——绝非人们实际进行的20多分钟疗程。

comments.author: voidmain
comments.content: There's a history of finding really strong correlations between vitamin D levels and (many kinds of) health, and then disappointing results for RCTs of vitamin D supplementation. There are lots of possible explanations of this, but it seems like a plausible one is that there are some good things sunlight does for you other than produce vitamin D. So I'm a little nervous about everyone eliminating all sun exposure and then taking vitamin D geltabs to compensate, even though sunlight carries some risks. (But obviously too much ionizing radiation is also a problem, and it sounds like most users of tanning beds are getting a lot of intense exposure)
comments.content_cn: 历史上经常发现维生素D水平与（多种）健康之间存在极强的相关性，但维生素D补充剂的随机对照试验结果却令人失望。对此有许多可能的解释，但一个看似合理的解释是，阳光除了产生维生素D外，还能带来其他益处。因此，我对人们完全避免日晒、然后服用维生素D软胶囊来弥补的做法有些担忧，尽管阳光确实存在一些风险。（但显然，过多的电离辐射也是个问题，而且听起来大多数日光浴床使用者都接受了大量高强度照射。）

comments.content: Many people with inflammatory disease like IBD can't absorb oral vitamin D properlyEven in healthy people, oral vitamin D is not always sufficient (there was a study done in Japan where sunlight is low but Vitamin D from fish is high - can't find it right now) and sunlight exposure might have other benefits than vitamin D anywayhttps://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0022202X2...

comments.author: crazygringo
comments.content: > I estimated that 1 minute of artificial tanning is comparable to the 10-15 minutes of sun a day that is recommended.That doesn't seem right. If you only tan in a strong tanning bed for 10 min (or 15 min in a weaker one), it's equivalent to only about an hour in the real sun around noon. I.e. if you've only been going to a tanning bed, you'll start to burn outdoors shortly after that. (And I'm talking about high-UVB bulbs that develop the long-lasting tan that protects against sunburn, just like the sun itself generates.)So the difference factor is more like 4-6x, not 10-15x. Honestly, 15x would be insane. Tanning beds aren't as strong as some fearmongerers suggest. And that's assuming full-body exposure.When you say you artificially tan at home for 1 minute, how? Did you buy your own entire tanning bed? Because if you use the small portable devices (like a Sperti), they're providing only a tiny fraction of what a tanning bed provides, since they're so small.
comments.content_cn:
我估计人工日光浴1分钟相当于建议的每日晒太阳10-15分钟。这似乎不对。如果你只在强效日光浴床上晒10分钟（或在较弱设备上晒15分钟），实际只相当于正午真实阳光下约1小时的照射量。也就是说，如果你只进行日光浴床照射，之后在户外很快就会晒伤。（我指的是能产生持久保护性古铜色、类似太阳本身产生的高UVB灯管。）所以实际差异系数更接近4-6倍，而非10-15倍。说实话，15倍会非常夸张。日光浴床的强度并不像某些危言耸听者说的那么强。这还是假设全身照射的情况。

你说在家人工日光浴1分钟，具体如何操作？是购买了整套日光浴床设备吗？如果使用小型便携设备（如Sperti型），由于照射面积很小，其效果仅为日光浴床的极小部分。

comments.author: kens
comments.content: The popularity of tanning is attributed to fashion designer Coco Chanel, who accidentally got too much sun on a Mediterranean cruise in 1923. Since she was a fashion icon, this made the tanned look fashionable.As an aside, the chemistry behind UV damage is interesting. You can think of DNA as a sequence of four letters: C, G, A, and T. If there are two neighboring T's, UV can move a bond, linking the two T's together (i.e. thymine dimerization). If you're in the sun, each skin cell gets 50-100 of these pairs created per second. Enzymes usually fix these errors, but sometimes the errors will cause problems during DNA replication and you can end up with mutations. Enough of the wrong mutations can cause skin cancer. So wear sunscreen!https://pdb101.rcsb.org/motm/91

comments.author: Theodores
comments.content: You might be interested in the British history of Vitamin D supplementation. It all started with kids in the cities getting rickets because the pollution (smog) was that bad that they never got to see further than a metre or two during the worst of it. The way to get around was by taking the tram as that had rails to guide it through the 'pea soupers'.So they put the kids on trains and took them off to the seaside.But then...The railway also allowed milk to be brought into the cities. So they added vitamin D to milk. That was how the rickets was solved. In time milk became free at school, usually it was warm by morning break, which was when it would get consumed, from mini-milk bottles, that would get reused.I am only piecing together this history, no definitive source, unless you include my elderly neighbour. However, food history is fascinating, once you get away from celebrated brands to the unsung heroes of the vegetable aisle.What I can't work out is why the children were so vulnerable to rickets when the adults weren't. Workers weren't being sent out to the countryside or beach to get some sun, just the kids. Rickets doesn't affect adults with grown bones, in theory, the adults should have had really painful joints and osteoporosis, but maybe this was not understood at the time.In time the clean air zones were setup and the smog was banished to a certain extent, by which time it became uncommon to fortify milk with vitamin D. Finally we had Margaret Thatcher, famously the 'milk snatcher', for stopping free school milk.In the UK we do get vitamin D randomly added to processed foods (what else?) and this is a scattergun approach to fortifying the population. If you don't eat processed foods then you are not going to get any of that processed food fortification goodness.Then there are the animal corpse sources, as in oily fish and whatnot. If you eat any diet except for whole-food-plant-based vegan, then you are going to get vitamin D either through dead animal or fortification. Vegetarians just have to eat maaassivve blocks of cheese, which they will, with a few eggs and some breakfast cereal to get their vitamin D needs roughly covered. Junk-food vegans should get some vitamin D goodness from fortifications too, particularly if they consume things like 'oat milk' (as if oats have mammary glands). Pure junk food, a.k.a. 'Standard American Diet', should also be pretty good for vitamin D.So this only really leaves the whole-food, plant-based, everything-cooked-from-scratch vegan diet as lacking, at least as far as the winter months is concerned. Was this a problem historically? I don't think so. Since people used to work the fields, they had plenty of vitamin D to carry over for winter.Before we had 'modern day racism' in the UK, we had a situation where the aristocracy had white skin and everyone else had leathery brown skin, from working outside. White skin was proof that you didn't have to work the fields and therefore, you were higher status. Racism pre-dated racism, if you get my drift, it was mere class-based xenophobia back then. To be 'truly white' you had to have no tan.Since meat was hard to come by, peasants were 95% vegan by default, yet working the fields, so vitamin D deficiency was not a problem, for the 1% aristocracy (since they had their oily fish, red meat and dairy) or for the 99% that had to spend lots of time outdoors.I am not sure where you are coming from regarding the Gulf Stream and cereals. The Fertile Crescent was where farming began for Europe, with wheat not actually growing in the UK and other grains (barley) being the chosen grain. It was only with the Norman Conquest that wheat made it to the UK.When the Romans made it to the UK they were perplexed at what they found. There were two tribes, the nomadic cattle types and the hill fort living grain growers that were not nomadic. The hill forts got in the way of the migration routes between pastures. The Romans were disgusted by the milk drinking since nobody would do that in Rome, where everyone was lactose intolerant, unlike the Celts.

comments.author: lenerdenator
comments.content: If there was one critical miscalculation the West (particularly the US) made in the last 40 years, it was thinking that investment in China would equal liberalization and democratic reforms. There was a mistaking of capitalism for human rights. While it is a human right to own property and use it to rationally pursue one's self-interests, that does not mean that capitalism in its current form is conducive to that for the greatest number of people, or to the evolution of other human rights in the societies in which capitalism is practiced.If investment was the key to liberalization, we would have seen far greater investment behind the then-fallen Iron Curtain, where countries had actively turned their backs on command economies. The cynic in me thinks that capital didn't like just how that had turned out. If a country's people could either violently (Romania) or peacefully (almost everywhere else) remove such totalitarian systems of politics and economics, they could also reject methods of accumulating capital that might run afoul of their values.China, on the other hand, had not moved away from command economics at the time. Instead, the result was state capitalism. People were free to try new things that could create economic expansion, but only in a way that served the needs of the state. Anything else would be handled with the same totalitarian methods that political dissidents and class enemies were once handled with under Mao. While this has ebbed and flowed over the years, it essentially remains the system in place.Lai is a victim of this miscalculation.
comments.content_cn:
如果说西方（尤其是美国）在过去四十年里犯了一个关键误判，那就是认为对华投资会带来自由化和民主改革。这种观点错误地将资本主义等同于人权。虽然拥有财产并合理追求个人利益是一项人权，但这并不意味着当前形式的资本主义能为最广泛人群实现这一目标，也不意味着在实行资本主义的社会中能促进其他人权的发展。如果投资真是自由化的关键，那么当时铁幕倒塌后的国家本应获得更多投资——这些国家已主动摒弃了计划经济体制。我内心深处的怀疑论者认为，资本并不喜欢那种转型结果。如果一个国家的人民能够通过暴力（如罗马尼亚）或和平方式（如几乎其他所有地区）推翻那种极权政治经济体系，他们同样可能抵制违背其价值观的资本积累方式。

而中国当时并未脱离计划经济体制，结果反而形成了国家资本主义模式。人们可以自由尝试能促进经济扩张的新事物，但前提是必须服务于国家需求。任何越界行为都会遭到与毛泽东时代处理政治异见者和阶级敌人相同的极权手段。尽管这种情况在岁月流转中时起时伏……

posts.title: Ruby website redesigned
posts.author: psxuaw
posts.title_cn: Ruby 网站重新设计
posts.abstract: 该讨论围绕Ruby官方网站改版展开。多数用户对新设计表示赞赏，认为其视觉美观、内容清晰，特别是首页用大字体直接介绍Ruby特色的方式获得好评，有人指出这激发了他们重新尝试Ruby的兴趣。技术实现方面存在争议：有用户批评网站加载缓慢、图片未优化、过度依赖JavaScript和Tailwind，认为这不符合现代前端最佳实践；也有用户反驳称加载速度与HackerNews相当且体验良好。讨论中提到新加入的在线尝试功能受到欢迎，但部分用户认为应优先加载静态内容再逐步增强交互。此外，有用户指出网站未收录Ruby社区重要人物Sandi Metz的推荐语。整体而言，社区肯定设计方向的创新性，但对技术执行细节存在分歧。

comments.author: ttepasse
comments.content: Back in the 2000s in the web standards development community there were multiple web development strategies called "progressive enhancement", "graceful degradation" and "unobtrusive javascript":https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Progressive_enhancementThere were a lot of practical reasons for that: The browser landscape was much more diverse, different browsers had different support of standard Javascript, some browsers didn't even support JS and some people still kept text-only browsers like lynx/links in mind. Also browsers were not evergreen, so a large part of the audience could be on some older versions. Another thing were sometimes brittle network connection, especially over mobile. Depending on JS could in the case of corruption mean non-functioning websites.For a lot whose exposure to web development and the discussions abound that, that reason will be stuck in their head, even if in the last decade of React ets the "best practices" will have changed.There is also an aesthetic thing: There is a thing of beauty in simply curling an url and piping it into grep or such to get the thing you need, instead of having so have an headless browser. In my mind that is still how the web should work.
comments.content_cn:
回溯到2000年代的网页标准开发社区，曾存在多种网页开发策略，分别称为“渐进增强”、“优雅降级”和“无侵入式JavaScript”。这背后有许多实际考量：当时的浏览器环境更为多样化，不同浏览器对标准JavaScript的支持程度各异，有些浏览器甚至不支持JS，部分用户仍在使用如lynx/links这样的纯文本浏览器。此外，浏览器并非自动更新，因此大量用户可能仍在使用旧版本。另一个因素是当时网络连接不稳定，尤其在移动端。若过度依赖JavaScript，一旦出现故障就可能导致网站无法正常运行。

对于许多接触过网页开发及相关讨论的人来说，这些原因已深植脑海，尽管过去十年间随着React等技术的兴起，“最佳实践”已发生变化。这里还存在一种美学考量：直接通过curl获取URL并用grep等工具处理所需内容，而非依赖无头浏览器，本身具有一种简洁之美。在我看来，这仍是网络应有的工作方式。

posts.abstract: 该讨论围绕“史上最大CRT显示器索尼PVM-4300”展开，用户们分享了各自对大型CRT设备的回忆与看法。有人认为这款43英寸的显示器在当今平板电视标准下虽显小巧，但在当时已是庞然大物，并推测其因近距离观看SD画质不佳而应用场景有限。也有用户指出这可能并非最大CRT，并举出曾见过60英寸索尼特丽珑显示器的经历。讨论中提到许多用户对搬运重型CRT的困扰记忆犹新，并怀念早期显像管技术的独特体验。部分用户建议直接观看相关维修视频而非阅读转述文章。整体上，社区普遍认同大型CRT在历史上具有特殊地位，但其体积和重量确实带来了巨大不便。

So we decided to throw it away. I had never picked it up before and had forgotten how heavy CRTs could be. I ended up having to get two friends to come help me move it to the curb, it was well over 250 lbs. comments.author: jsheard
comments.content: The Sony FW900 was the peak of desktop CRT monitors, and it came out in 1999 so it or one of its rebadges might have been what you saw. That was much smaller than the PVM-4300 at 24" but with a much higher max resolution of 2304x1440@85hz, roughly what we'd now call 1440p, about eight years before the first 1080p LCDs arrived.Those were still sought after well into the LCD era for their high resolution and incredible motion clarity, but I think LCDs getting "good enough" and the arrival of OLED monitors with near-zero response times has finally put them out to pasture as anything but a collectors item.
comments.content_cn: 索尼FW900是桌面CRT显示器的巅峰之作，于1999年问世，你当时看到的很可能就是它或其贴牌型号。这款24英寸显示器虽比PVM-4300小得多，但最高分辨率可达2304x1440@85hz，接近现今的1440p标准——这比首批1080p液晶显示器早了约八年。直到液晶时代，人们仍因其高分辨率和惊人的动态清晰度而追捧它，但随着液晶技术达到“足够好”的水平，以及响应时间近乎零的OLED显示器出现，这类产品最终退出了实用舞台，仅作为收藏品存在。
