comments.author: ssl-3
comments.content: Projectors (front/rear/enclosed/whatever) could produce a huge image, but they had their own issues.In a bright room, the contrast was typically lacking.Even on relatively late versions like the Toshiba 57HX93 (a 57" 16x9 doghouse from ~20 years ago with an integrated scaler and a 1080i input), which I personally spent some time with both in Toshiba form and as $10k Runco-branded units.  Things got washed out in a bright room compared to a direct-view CRT.And viewing angle is an issue, too:  Whether front- or rear-projection, one of the tricks to improve brightness (and therefore potential contrast) is to reduce the angle of light transmission from the screen.  Depending on the room layout, this can mean that people in seats off to the side might get a substantially darker image than those near the middle.  (This applies to all projectors; film, CRT, DLP, LCD, front, rear, whatever -- there can be a lot of non-obvious tech that goes into a projection screen.)And CRT projectors were fickle.  Their color convergence would change based on external magnetic fields (including that produced by the Earth itself), so they needed to be set up properly in-situ.  A projection set that was set up properly while facing East would be a different thing when rotated 90 degrees to instead face North:  What once was carefully-adjusted to produce 3 overlapping images that summed to be pure white lines would be a weird mix of red, blue, and green lines that only sometimes overlapped.The CRT tubes themselves were generally quite impressively small for the size of the image that they'd ultimately produce.  This meant pushing the phosphor coatings quite hard, which translated into an increased opportunity for permanent image retention ("screen burn") from things like CNN logos and video game scores.Plus:  They'd tend to get blurry over time.  Because they were being pushed hard, the CRTs were liquid-cooled using glycol that was supposed to be optically-clear.  But stuff would sometimes grow in there.  It was never clear whether this was flora or [micro]fauna or something else, but whatever it was liked living in a world filled with hot, brightly-lit glycol.  Service shops could correct this by changing the fluid, but that's an expense and inconvenience that direct-view CRTs didn't have.And they were ungainly things in other ways.  Sure, they tended to be lighter (less-massive) because they were full of air instead of leaded glass, but a rear-projection set was generally a big floor-standing thing that still had plenty of gravity.  Meanwhile, a front-projection rig ~doubled the chance of someone walking by occluding the view and came with the burden of a hard-to-clean screen (less important these days, but it used to be common for folks to smoke indoors) and its own additional alignment variables (and lens selection, and dust issues, and, and).So a person could deal with all that, or -- you know -- just get a regular direct-view CRT.Even today where projectors use friggin' laser beams for illumination and produce enormous, bright images with far fewer issues than I listed above, direct-view tech (like the flat LCD and *LED sets at any big-box) is still much more popular.(But I do feel your pain.  When I was a teenager, my parents came home from shopping one wintry night with a 36" Sony WEGA for me to help unload.  Holy hell.)
comments.content_cn:
投影机（无论前投/背投/封闭式）能够呈现巨大画面，但存在固有缺陷。在明亮环境中，其对比度通常不足。即使像东芝57HX93这类较晚期机型（约20年前推出的57英寸16:9"狗屋式"设计，内置缩放器并支持1080i输入——我本人曾深度体验过东芝原厂版和Runco品牌价值1万美元的版本），在明亮房间中画面也会比直视型CRT显得泛白。视角也是问题所在：无论前投或背投，提升亮度（从而增强潜在对比度）的常用技巧是缩小屏幕的光线传输角度。根据房间布局，这可能导致侧座观众看到的图像比中间座位暗得多。（此现象适用于所有投影技术：胶片、CRT、DLP、LCD、前投、背投等——投影幕本身可能蕴含大量隐性技术。）

CRT投影机尤其娇贵。其色彩汇聚会受外部磁场（包括地球自身磁场）影响而改变，因此需要现场精确调校。一台朝东方向调试完美的投影设备，若旋转90度改为朝北方向，原本精心调整至三色重叠形成纯白线条的图像，就会变成红蓝绿三色线条杂乱交织、仅偶然重叠的状态。CRT显像管……

comments.author: mjg59
comments.content: The limiting factor is the horizontal refresh frequency. TVs and older monitors were around 15.75kHz, so the maximum number of horizontal lines you could draw per second is around 15750. Divide that by 60 and you get 262.5, which is therefore the maximum vertical resolution (real world is lower for various reasons). CGA ran at 200 lines, so was safely possible with a 60Hz refresh rate.If you wanted more vertical resolution then you needed either a monitor with a higher horizontal refresh rate or you needed to reduce the effective vertical refresh rate. The former involved more expensive monitors, the latter was typically implemented by still having the CRT refresh at 60Hz but drawing alternate lines each refresh. This meant that the effective refresh rate was 30Hz, which is what you're alluding to.But the reason you're being downvoted is that at no point was the CRT running with a low refresh rate, and best practice was to use a mode that your monitor could display without interlace anyway. Even in the 80s, using interlace was rare.
comments.content_cn: 限制因素在于水平刷新频率。电视和旧式显示器的水平刷新频率大约为15.75kHz，因此每秒能绘制的最大水平线数约为15750。将其除以60得到262.5，这就是最大垂直分辨率（实际由于各种原因会更低）。CGA标准运行在200线，因此在60Hz刷新率下可以稳定实现。若想获得更高的垂直分辨率，要么需要具有更高水平刷新率的显示器，要么需要降低有效垂直刷新率。前者涉及更昂贵的显示器，后者通常通过保持CRT以60Hz刷新但每次刷新交替绘制行线来实现。这意味着有效刷新率为30Hz，这正是你所提及的情况。但你被点踩的原因在于，CRT从未以低刷新率运行，最佳实践始终是使用显示器能够直接支持的非隔行扫描模式。即使在80年代，隔行扫描的使用也极为罕见。

posts.title: Autoland saves King Air, everyone reported safe
posts.author: bradleybuda
posts.title_cn: "自动着陆系统挽救国王航空飞机，机上人员均报平安"
posts.abstract: 该讨论围绕Garmin SafeReturn自动着陆系统成功挽救一架比奇空中国王飞机的事件展开。核心话题是自动安全系统在航空领域的应用价值及未来发展。多数用户对这项技术表示赞赏，认为它能有效应对飞行员失能等紧急情况，有用户指出类似系统或可避免历史上因舱压骤降导致的事故。讨论中提到系统虽能感知地形、天气和燃油状况，但尚无法判断跑道状态。对于技术细节，有人认为驾驶舱界面、激活机制和跑道选择逻辑值得关注，也有用户期待更清晰的无线电通讯。在技术演进方面，有观点认为这是“自动驾驶”概念的进化终点，另有用户调侃实现自动滑行和起飞后飞行员角色将受挑战。社区普遍认同这类安全系统的重要意义，同时对其功能边界和操作细节存在不同关注点。

comments.author: Animats
comments.content:
This is Garman SafeReturn, and this is its first real save.
Here's a demo.[1] It's been shipping since about 2020, originally on the Cirrus Vision Jet. There's a lot going on. The system is aware of terrain, weather, and fuel, but not of runway status. So it gives the ground a few minutes to get ready, sending voice emergency messages to ATC.
If you watch the flight track, you can see the aircraft circle several times, some distance from the airport, then do a straight-in approach. It sets up for landing, wheels down, flaps down, lands, brakes, and turns of the the engine. It doesn't taxi. Someone from the ground will have to tow or taxi the aircraft off the runway.It's mostly GPS driven, plus a radar altimeter for landing.The system can be triggered by a button in the cockpit, a button in the passenger area, and a system that detects the pilot isn't making any inputs for a long period or the aircraft is unstable and the pilot isn't trying to stabilize it. The pilot can take control back, but if they don't, the airplane will be automatically landed.[1] https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=d-ruFmgTpqA
comments.content_cn:
这是佳明安全返航系统，这是它首次真正完成救援任务。
该系统自2020年起开始配备，最初应用于西锐愿景喷气机。其运作机制较为复杂：系统能感知地形、天气和燃油状况，但无法获取跑道实时状态。因此它会提前数分钟向地面发出语音紧急信号通知空管，为降落准备争取时间。
观察飞行轨迹可见，飞机在机场外围盘旋数周后转入直线进近。系统自动完成降落配置——放下起落架、调整襟翼、实施着陆、启动刹车直至关闭发动机。滑行环节需由地勤人员牵引或驾驶飞机离开跑道。该系统主要依赖GPS导航，辅以雷达高度计进行着陆校准。
触发方式包括：驾驶舱按钮、客舱按钮，以及当系统检测到飞行员长时间无操作或飞机处于不稳定状态且未进行修正时自动启动。飞行员可随时接管控制权，若未进行干预，飞机将执行全自动降落。
[1] 演示视频链接：https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=d-ruFmgTpqA

A system like this, would have detected it and possibly saved them.I wouldn't expect a whole lot more detail, as that airport is often used by defense contractors like Ball Aerospace, who have a large office nearby.

comments.content: I wonder if a human is in the loop. Obviously the software is hardly ever used (a good thing), so you wouldn't need many humans available. If communication is possible, wouldn't you hand control to a pilot on the ground?I don't know that they could actually fly the plane - is latency too high for landing? - but they could make all the decisions and communicate with air traffic control, other planes, and the passengers.
comments.content_cn: 我想知道是否有人参与其中。显然这个软件很少被使用（这是件好事），因此不需要太多人力待命。如果能够进行通讯，难道不应该将控制权交给地面飞行员吗？我不确定他们是否真的能驾驶飞机——延迟对于降落来说会不会太高？——但他们可以做出所有决策，并与空中交通管制、其他飞机以及乘客进行沟通。

comments.content_cn: 乘客是否有选择其他机场的选项？或者空中交通管制能否强制飞机使用次优机场？例如，当跑道正在施工且严重受阻时。

comments.author: silisili
comments.content: This is fascinating.My uncle was a pilot, and I asked him 15 years or so ago about the job.  He was going on and on about computers and autopilot, claiming that pilots were only really needed anymore for takeoffs and landings, and they could sleep during the rest.  Probably realizing the liability in what he said, he was quick to clarify that he didn't, of course.In that short time span we now have a system that can land a plane by itself.  Nothing less than magic, and huge congratulations and thanks to everyone at Garmin who made this happen.
comments.content_cn: 这真是令人着迷。我叔叔曾是一名飞行员，大约15年前我问过他关于这份工作的事。他滔滔不绝地谈论计算机和自动驾驶仪，声称飞行员如今真正需要的只是起飞和降落，其余时间他们都可以睡觉。可能意识到自己言论中的责任问题，他赶紧澄清说他当然不会那么做。在这短短的时间里，我们现在已经有了能够自主降落的系统。这简直是魔法般的成就，衷心祝贺并感谢Garmin所有实现这一突破的团队成员。

comments.author: jshier
comments.content: Even without autoland, I've never understood why there wasn't an emergency system to handle depressurization events when it detects no pilot input. There have been enough ghost flights, even in the last 20 years, that such a system could've saved hundreds of lives. (Helios Air 552) Automatically dropping altitude, or even just changing the transponder to some automatic value, would help.
comments.content_cn: 即便没有自动着陆系统，我也一直不明白为什么没有一种应急系统来处理检测到飞行员无操作时的失压事件。过去发生过太多幽灵航班，哪怕近20年内，这样的系统本可以挽救数百条生命。（以赫利俄斯航空522号班机为例）自动降低高度，甚至只是将应答机调至某个自动设定值，都会有所帮助。

comments.author: wkat4242
comments.content: SafeReturn doesn't detect that as I understand it. It still requires manual activation by one of the passengers.

comments.author: ultrarunner
comments.content: Some of the audio replays I heard had silence cut out, but the aircraft transmits every two minutes, for about twenty seconds each. It does share the information I'd want to hear in an uncontrolled environment, but in a busy towered class delta it likely needs to be shortened. They had plenty of advance warning of this aircraft being inbound and cleared the airspace well before it arrived, but if it had happened with less notice critical instructions may have been "stepped on" at a critical time.
comments.content_cn: 我听到的部分音频回放中静默部分被剪掉了，但飞机每两分钟会发送一次信号，每次持续约二十秒。在非管制环境下，它确实提供了我想听到的信息，但在繁忙的塔台管制D类空域中，这些信息可能需要缩短。他们提前很久就收到了该飞机即将抵达的预警，并在其到达前就清理了空域，但如果通知时间更短，关键指令可能在紧要时刻被"覆盖"。

comments.author: t0mas88
comments.content: The cockpit side is very passenger friendly, it assumes zero aviation knowledge. It's a single button and once pressed the system will show on the screens that it's active, what to expect and where it is going. The passengers just sit and watch, while it tells you via voice and on the screens what's happening. No action required apart from the single button.It uses the navigation database (onboard) and weather data via datalink (ADS-B in the US, satellite in other places) to select an airport/runway. It looks for a long enough runway with a full LPV (GPS) approach available and favorable wind.
comments.content_cn: 驾驶舱一侧对乘客非常友好，它假设使用者没有任何航空知识。只需按下单一按钮，系统便会在屏幕上显示已激活状态、预期操作流程及飞行目的地。乘客只需静坐观看，系统会通过语音和屏幕告知当前情况。除按下按钮外无需其他操作。该系统利用机载导航数据库和通过数据链接收的天气数据（美国使用ADS-B，其他地区使用卫星）来选择机场和跑道。它会寻找具备完整LPV（GPS）进近程序、跑道长度足够且风向有利的降落地点。

comments.author: ultrarunner

I think there is an argument to be made that there should be a pathway to airframe recertification to allow for innovation and improvement to take place in the aviation industry.Instead, the FAA is probably going backwards on this issue and doubling down on the regulatory framework that gave us the MAX-8 situation while narrowing any avenue for smaller firms to innovate [0][0] https://avbrief.com/faa-wants-to-phase-out-ders
comments.content_cn: 这是我在航空领域最感挫败的一点——完成此类改进所需的认证程序极其繁重。认证飞机的基本逻辑就是不允许改动，这使得加装机身降落伞、自动着陆系统，甚至地形感知、发动机监控等改进措施成本高昂。我认为应当建立机身重新认证的途径，以推动航空业的创新与进步。然而，联邦航空管理局在这个问题上可能正在开倒车，他们不仅强化了导致737 MAX-8事故的监管框架，还进一步压缩了小企业的创新空间[0]。

posts.title: Deliberate Internet Shutdowns
posts.author: WaitWaitWha
posts.title_cn: 蓄意互联网中断
posts.abstract:
该讨论围绕“蓄意断网”这一核心话题展开，用户们主要探讨了政府实施互联网关闭的现状、危害及应对方式。有用户指出，互联网关闭作为“骚乱控制”工具已被常态化，2024年全球54个国家发生了296起断网事件，其中缅甸、印度、巴基斯坦和俄罗斯占七成，这种集中化管控趋势令人担忧。讨论中提到，早期“网络将审查视为损害并自动绕行”的理念现已不再成立，断网技术手段往往并不复杂，通常直接要求运营商关闭基础设施。

在应对方案上，有人认为需要发展星链式连接和离网电力以提供备用方案，也有用户提及Meshtastic等去中心化通信工具，它们不依赖互联网，通过P2P LoRa实现私密通信，更难被封锁。同时，有观点强调应减少对持续联网的脆弱依赖，以降低断网影响。讨论中对于“国际社会”这一概念的有效性存在分歧，但普遍共识是反对互联网关闭，并担忧其日益增多的趋势。

comments.author: stego-tech
comments.content: The post is mainly just a CTA against further internet centralization and government control of core infrastructure, which is fine. We need more of these, and we need more examples of their harms for folks to draw on.  HN often gets distilled down to a singular cause - EU's Chat Control, Elon's shutdown of Starlink over Ukraine, a regional outage of a public cloud provider - but generalized topics like these aren't really discussed all too often I find, or are often flagged for a variety of reasons and shutdown.As technologists of multiple stripes and disciplines - programmers, developers, engineers, architects, designers, product managers, etcetera - we need to collaborate more on the direction of our industry as a whole, rather than just specific niches we find appealing.  From my specific perspective in IT, the increasing centralization across every vendor category (three major x86 server manufacturers, two CPU vendors, two GPU makers, three global-scale public clouds, ISP mono- and duopolies, a handful of commercial operating systems, a near-monopoly EUVL supplier - the list goes on) is a dire threat to not just the open internet, but open technology in general.We need to be better advocates for and champions of the technological future we envision, rather than just blindly celebrate startups and tech fads all the time. Mr. Schneier is merely the latest and largest canary in the proverbial coal mine.
comments.content_cn: 这篇文章主要是在呼吁反对互联网进一步中心化以及政府对核心基础设施的控制，这很好。我们需要更多这样的声音，也需要更多实际案例来让人们认识到其危害。Hacker News的讨论常常聚焦于单一事件——比如欧盟的聊天管控、马斯克在乌克兰关闭星链服务、某公有云的区域性故障——但像这类普遍性议题，我觉得讨论得并不够充分，或者常因各种原因被标记甚至关闭。作为来自不同领域的技术从业者——程序员、开发者、工程师、架构师、设计师、产品经理等等——我们需要加强协作，共同思考整个行业的发展方向，而不是仅仅局限于各自感兴趣的小众领域。从我在IT行业的视角来看，各个供应商领域日益加剧的集中化现象（三大x86服务器制造商、两家CPU供应商、两家GPU制造商、三大全球级公有云、垄断或双头垄断的互联网服务提供商、少数商业操作系统、近乎垄断的极紫外光刻供应商……这样的例子不胜枚举）不仅对开放互联网构成严峻威胁，更危及整个开放技术生态。我们需要更积极地倡导和捍卫我们理想中的技术未来，而不是一味盲目追捧初创公司和科技热潮。施奈尔先生不过是这个警世寓言中最新、最醒目的预警信号罢了。

comments.author: yoan9224
comments.content: The normalization of internet shutdowns as a "riot control" tool is deeply concerning, especially given how technically unsophisticated most implementations are. In many cases, governments aren't doing surgical BGP manipulation - they're literally ordering ISPs to turn off infrastructure or block DNS at the national level. This is the equivalent of cutting power to an entire city to stop a protest in one neighborhood.What's particularly insidious is the asymmetry: governments can coordinate offline through military/police radio while citizens lose all communication infrastructure. The $1.5B average economic impact cited in the article is conservative - it doesn't account for destroyed business relationships, lost international contracts, or long-term reputation damage from being seen as "internet shutdown country."The technical countermeasures are evolving but limited. Mesh networks like Briar or Bridgefy work peer-to-peer over Bluetooth but have tiny range. Satellite internet (Starlink) requires hardware that's easy to detect/confiscate. eSIM switching only works if neighboring countries' towers reach across borders. The hardest problem is the "last mile" - even if you can get data out via satellite/mesh, how do you distribute it locally when cellular is down?We need international frameworks treating internet access as critical infrastructure with humanitarian protections, similar to water/electricity during conflicts. The ITU could mandate technical transparency - requiring governments to publicly log shutdown orders with specific geographic/temporal scope rather than blanket national blackouts. That wouldn't prevent shutdowns but would create accountability records.
comments.content_cn:
将互联网关闭作为"骚乱控制"手段的常态化趋势令人深感忧虑，尤其考虑到大多数实施手段在技术上相当粗糙。许多情况下，政府并非进行精准的BGP路由操控，而是直接命令互联网服务提供商在国家层面关闭基础设施或屏蔽DNS解析。这好比为了阻止某个街区的抗议活动而切断整座城市的电力供应。

这种不对称性尤为隐蔽：政府可以通过军警无线电进行线下协调，而公民却完全丧失通信基础设施。文中引用的15亿美元平均经济损失数据仍属保守估计——这尚未计入被摧毁的商业关系、流失的国际合同，以及被视为"断网国家"所带来的长期声誉损害。

技术对抗手段正在发展但仍受限。像Briar或Bridgefy这类网状网络虽能通过蓝牙实现点对点通信，但覆盖范围极小。卫星互联网（星链）需要硬件设备，而这些设备极易被侦测/没收。eSIM切换功能仅在邻国信号塔能跨境覆盖时才有效。最棘手的难题在于"最后一公里"——即使能通过卫星/网状网络传出数据，当蜂窝网络瘫痪时又如何实现本地分发？

我们需要建立国际框架，将互联网接入视为关键基础设施并给予人道主义保护，类似冲突期间的水电供应保障。国际电信联盟可以强制要求技术透明度——例如规定……

comments.author: stego-tech
comments.content: Replying to myself probably breaks some sort of rule somewhere (ye olde double-posting), but I think it's warranted here given the volume of responses this comment of mine has received.I deliberately left out specific guidance because I wanted exactly the kind of responses we've seen here: a healthy mixture of takes from different backgrounds and perspectives, as well as the opportunity for fatalists to out themselves with the well-tread "just how it is"/"nothing we can do" schtick these sorts of posts tend to encourage.  The discussion was the point, and I love seeing the back-and-forth folks have engaged with here over a very broad opinion of mine.What I'll leave everyone here with is something that's kept me afloat during my own dark times, far, far darker times than we see now:Just because everything works that way today, doesn't mean it'll work that way tomorrow. None of today was inevitable yesterday, and none of tomorrow is written in stone today.  One individual can't fix the world, but enough of us together, focused on a glut of smaller changes, targeting specific problems, acting in concert despite being individuals?  That is what drives meaningful change.  That is what defines tomorrow.Don't fret that you can't overturn colossal problems alone. Stop worrying that things have grown too complicated to fix easily.  Focus instead on building a community, a movement, an orchestra of change towards causes you believe in. Build more things and share them with others. Do things specifically because you find value in them, even - and especially - if "free markets" or VCs don't. The more you build that you can share, the wider the audience you can reach with your passions, the easier it is to change things for the better.Immiseration, complexity, monopoly, centralization: they're choices, not inevitabilities.

posts.title: Lotusbail npm package found to be harvesting WhatsApp messages and contacts
posts.author: sohkamyung
posts.title_cn: Lotusbail npm包被发现窃取WhatsApp消息和联系人信息
posts.abstract:
该讨论围绕一个名为Lotusbail的npm包被发现窃取WhatsApp消息和联系人数据的事件展开。核心话题聚焦于npm生态系统的安全风险及开发者应如何应对。

社区观点多元。有用户指出，此类恶意软件常导致安全团队过度限制应用数据访问，可能影响正常功能。也有用户强调，该包并非官方API封装，而是通过逆向工程伪装成WhatsApp客户端，用户容易在不知情中授权。讨论中提到，许多开发者依赖npm谋生，但缺乏有效风险缓解措施，例如在隔离环境中开发。部分用户认为此类攻击是可预见的，npm等包管理器在构建时动态获取依赖的设计本身存在隐患。此外，有观点批评npm依赖泛滥，若将AI生成的包含大量依赖的方案用于生产环境，可能带来巨大责任风险。

共识在于，当前npm生态系统缺乏足够的安全监管。有用户呼吁微软应更好地管理npm，或将其移交基金会维护。分歧体现在责任归属：有人认为开发者过度信任NodeJS，迟早会因无意中分发恶意软件面临法律风险；也有用户建议建立检测滞后排行榜，或推动建立类似Apache Commons的受信任大型JavaScript库，以提升安全性。

comments.author: tekacs
comments.content: Just to talk about a different direction here for a second:Something that I find to be a frustrating side effect of malware issues like this is that it seems to result in well-intentioned security teams locking down the data in apps.The justification is quite plausible -- in this case WhatsApp messages were being stolen! But the thing is... that if this isn't what they steal they'll steal something else.Meanwhile locking down those apps so the only apps with a certain signature can read from your WhatsApp means that if you want to back up your messages or read them for any legitimate purpose you're now SOL, or reliant on a usually slow, non-automatable UI-only flow.I'm glad that modern computers are more secure than they have been, but I think that defense in depth by locking down everything and creating more silos is a problem of its own.
comments.content_cn: 这里我想稍微换个角度谈谈：这类恶意软件问题带来的一个令人沮丧的副作用是，它往往导致善意的安全团队对应用程序中的数据实施封锁。其理由看似合理——比如这次是WhatsApp消息被盗！但问题在于……就算不偷这个，他们也会偷别的。与此同时，封锁这些应用，只允许特定签名的应用读取WhatsApp数据，意味着如果你想备份消息或出于任何正当目的查看它们，现在要么束手无策，要么只能依赖通常缓慢、无法自动化且仅限界面的操作流程。我很高兴现代计算机比以往更安全，但我认为通过封锁一切、制造更多数据孤岛来实现深度防御，这本身也是个问题。

comments.author: cxr
comments.content: At this point, the existence of these attacks should be an expected outcome.  (It should have been expected even without the empirical record we now have and the multiple times that we can now cite.)NPM and NPM-style package managers that are designed to late-fetch dependencies just before build-time are already fundamentally broken.  They're an end-run around the underlying version control system, all in favor of an ill-considered, half-baked scheme to implement an alternative approach to version control of the package manager project maintainers' devising.And they provide cover for attacks like this, because they encourage a culture where, because one's dependencies are all "over there", the massive surface area gets swept under the rug and they never get reviewed (because 56K NPM users can't be wrong).
comments.content_cn: 至此，这类攻击的存在本应是预料之中的结果。（即便没有我们现有的实证记录和如今可多次引证的案例，这也早该被预见。）NPM及类似设计在构建前才延迟获取依赖的包管理器，其基础架构已然存在根本性缺陷。它们绕过了底层的版本控制系统，完全倾向于一种考虑不周、半生不熟的方案，试图以包维护者自行设计的替代方式实现版本控制。这类机制为攻击提供了掩护，因为它们助长了一种文化：由于所有依赖都“在别处”，巨大的攻击面被掩盖起来，从未经过审查（毕竟56万NPM用户总不会全错吧）。

comments.author: sneak
comments.content: Every docker image specified in a k8s yml or docker-compose file or github action that doesn’t end in :sha256@<hash> (ie specifying a label) is one “docker push” away from a compromise, given that tags/labels are not cryptographically specified.  You’re just trusting DockerHub and the publisher (or anyone with their creds) to not rug you.The industry runs on a lot more unexamined trust than people think.They’re deployed automatically by machine, which definitionally can’t even give it a second thought.  The upstream trust is literally specified in code, to be reused constantly automatically.  You could get owned in your sleep without doing anything just because a publisher got phished one day.
comments.content_cn: 在k8s yml文件、docker-compose文件或github action中指定的每个docker镜像，若未以:sha256@结尾（即未指定摘要标签），就存在因一次“docker推送”而遭受攻击的风险，因为标签本身不具备密码学验证机制。你只能盲目信任DockerHub和发布者（或任何掌握其凭证的人）不会背弃你。整个行业建立在远比人们想象中更多的未经审视的信任之上。这些镜像由机器自动部署，而机器本质上甚至无法进行二次确认。上游信任完全通过代码定义，并持续被自动复用。你可能在睡梦中毫无察觉地遭受攻击，仅仅因为某个发布者某天遭遇了钓鱼攻击。

comments.author: tekacs
comments.content: I could certainly see the value in this in principle but sadly the labyrinthine mess that is the Apple permission system (in which they learned none of the lessons of early UAC) illustrates the kind of result that seems to arise from this.A great microcosm illustration of this is automation permission on macOS right now: there's a separate allow dialog for every single app. If you try to use a general purpose automation app it needs to request permission for every single app on your computer individually the first time you use it. Having experienced that in practice it... absolutely sucks.At this point it makes me feel like we need something like an async audit API. Maybe the OS just tracks and logs all of your apps' activity and then:1) You can view it of course.2) The OS monitors for deviations from expected patterns for that app globally (kinda like Microsoft's SmartScreen?)3) Your own apps can get permission to read this audit log if you want to analyze it your own way and/or be more secure. If you're more paranoid maybe you could use a variant that kills an app in a hurry if it's misbehaving.Sadly you can't even implement this as a third party thing on macOS at this point because the security model prohibits you from monitoring other apps. You can't even do it with the user's permission because tracing apps requires you to turn SIP off.

我原则上能理解这种设计的价值，但遗憾的是，苹果那套迷宫般的权限系统（他们完全没有吸取早期UAC的教训）恰恰展示了这种思路可能导致的后果。当前macOS的自动化权限就是个绝佳的缩影：每个应用都需要单独弹窗授权。如果你尝试使用通用自动化工具，首次运行时它必须为电脑上每个应用逐一申请权限。实际体验下来……简直糟透了。

这让我觉得我们可能需要一种异步审计API。或许操作系统可以追踪记录所有应用行为，然后：
1）用户当然可以查看记录；
2）系统能监测应用行为是否偏离全球范围内的常规模式（类似微软SmartScreen？）；
3）用户可授权自有应用读取审计日志，以便按自己的方式分析或增强安全。更谨慎的用户甚至可以采用能在应用异常时快速终止的变体方案。

遗憾的是，目前在macOS上连第三方实现都不可能，因为安全模型禁止监控其他应用。即使用户授权也不行——追踪应用需要关闭系统完整性保护。

comments.author: josephg
comments.content:
> i dont know what the solution here is other than stop using npmPersonally I think we need to start adding capability based systems into our programming languages. Random code shouldn't have "ambient authority" to just do anything on my computer with the same privileges as me. Like, if a function has this signature:    function add(a: int, b: int) -> int

Then it should only be able to read its input, and return any integer it wants. But it shouldn't get ambient authority to access anything else on my computer. No network access. No filesystem. Nothing.Philosophically, I kind of think of it like function arguments and globals. If I call a function foo(someobj), then function foo is explicitly given access to someobj. And it also has access to any globals in my program. But we generally consider globals to be smelly. Passing data explicitly is better.But the whole filesystem is essentially available as a global that any function, anywhere, can access. With full user permissions. I say no. I want languages where the filesystem itself (or a subset of it) can be passed as an argument. And if a function doesn't get passed a filesystem, it can't access a filesystem. If a function isn't passed a network socket, it can't just create one out of nothing.I don't think it would be that onerous. The main function would get passed "the whole operating system" in a sense - like the filesystem and so on. And then it can pass files and sockets and whatnot to functions that need access to that stuff.If we build something like that, we should be able to build something like npm but where you don't need to trust the developers of 3rd party software so much. The current system of trusting everyone with everything is insane.
comments.content_cn:
除了停止使用npm，我不知道这里还有什么解决方案。我个人认为我们需要开始在编程语言中加入基于能力的系统。随机代码不应该拥有"环境权限"，以与我相同的特权在我的电脑上为所欲为。比如，如果一个函数有这样的签名：`function add(a: int, b: int) -> int`，那么它应该只能读取其输入，并返回任意整数。但它不应该获得环境权限来访问我电脑上的任何其他东西。没有网络访问权限。没有文件系统权限。什么都没有。

从哲学角度，我有点把它看作函数参数和全局变量。如果我调用一个函数`foo(someobj)`，那么函数`foo`被明确授予了对`someobj`的访问权限。它还可以访问我程序中的任何全局变量。但我们通常认为全局变量是有问题的。显式传递数据更好。

但整个文件系统本质上就像一个全局变量，任何地方的任何函数都可以访问。并且拥有完整的用户权限。我说不。我希望有一种语言，文件系统本身（或其子集）可以作为参数传递。如果一个函数没有被传递文件系统，它就不能访问文件系统。如果一个函数没有被传递网络套接字，它就不能凭空创建一个。

我不认为这会很繁琐。主函数在某种意义上会被传递"整个操作系统"——比如文件系统等等。然后它可以将文件、套接字等传递给需要访问这些资源的函数……

comments.author: stefan_bobev
comments.content: I am slowly waking up to the realization that we (software engineers) are laughably bad at security. I used to think that it was only NPM (I have worked a lot in this ecosystem over the years), but I have found this to be essentially everywhere: NPM is a poster child for this because of executable scripts on install, but every package manager essentially boils down to "Install this thing by name, no security checks". Every ecosystem I touch now (apart from gamedev, but only because I roll everything myself there by choice) has this - e.g Cargo has a lot of "tools" that you install globally so that you get some capability (like flamegraphs, asm output, test runners etc.) - this is the same vulnerability, manifesting slightly differently. Like others have pointed out, it is common to just pull random Docker images via Helm charts. It is also common to get random "utility" tools during builds in CI/CD pipelines, just by curl-ing random URLs of various "release archives". You don't even have to look too hard - this is surface level in pretty much every company, almost every industry (I have my doubts about the security theatre in some, but I have no first hand experience, so cannot say)The issue I have is that I don't really have a good idea for a solution to this problem - on one hand, I don't expect everyone to roll the entire modern stacks by hand every time. Killing collaborative software development seems like literally throwing the baby out with the bath water. On the other hand, I feel like nothing I touch is "secure" in any real sense - the tick boxes are there, and they are all checked, but I don't think a single one of them really protects me against anything - most of the time, the monster is already inside the house.
comments.content_cn: 我逐渐意识到，我们（软件工程师）在安全方面的表现简直糟糕得可笑。过去我以为这只是NPM的问题（多年来我在这个生态系统中做了大量工作），但我发现这几乎无处不在：NPM因其安装时的可执行脚本而成为典型代表，但每个包管理器本质上都归结为“按名称安装此物，无安全检查”。如今我接触的每个生态系统（除了游戏开发，但那只是因为我选择在那里自己动手做所有事）都存在这个问题——例如Cargo有许多全局安装的“工具”，以获取某些功能（如火焰图、汇编输出、测试运行器等）——这是同样的漏洞，只是表现形式略有不同。正如其他人指出的，通过Helm图表随意拉取Docker镜像很常见。在CI/CD流水线的构建过程中，通过curl各种“发布存档”的随机URL获取随意“实用”工具也很常见。你甚至不需要费劲寻找——这几乎是每家公司的表面现象，几乎每个行业都是如此（我对某些行业的安全表演持怀疑态度，但没有第一手经验，所以无法断言）。我的问题在于，我并没有解决这个问题的好办法——一方面，我不指望每个人每次都手动构建整个现代技术栈。扼杀协作软件开发简直就像把洗澡水和婴儿一起倒掉。另一方面……

posts.abstract:
该帖子展示了用户开发的“HN Wrapped 2025”工具，利用最新Gemini模型分析用户年度HackerNews活动并生成个性化总结、未来首页和漫画形象。核心话题围绕AI生成个人年度回顾的趣味性与准确性展开。

社区反馈呈现多元观点。有人认为工具幽默且洞察力强，如用户称赞其“做得很棒”，并举例生成内容准确有趣；也有用户指出结果存在局限，如过度聚焦近期高赞评论而未能全面概括全年活动，或出现事实错误和图像裁剪问题。讨论中提到，部分用户对AI能轻易分析个人数据感到担忧，认为这可能被用于政治目的或侵犯隐私。

普遍共识是该项目创意有趣且技术实现令人印象深刻。主要分歧在于生成内容的准确性与代表性：一方认为结果生动贴切，另一方则指出其依赖有限数据导致偏差。此外，关于数据隐私的讨论凸显了技术进步与社会风险之间的张力。

comments.author: kqr
comments.content: In contrast to many others, I did not find this particularly interesting.- The comic on is oddly cropped and contains speech attribution errors.- It calls me an "extremist" regarding the wrong thing (I am many kinds of extremist, but certainly not Haskell).- It claims I believe "any software failure is merely a design error" which is a complete misunderstanding of the ideas I presented.- It says things like "the geometric mean of the snack bowl" which doesn't have meaning in English.I feel like it has picked up on certain keywords and then just rolled with its own stereotypes of what those keywords represent, rather than actually taking a good look at what I think. A roast works because the roaster has clearly spent time and effort and care understanding the person roasted. This is way too shallow for that.The 2026 and 2035 predictions (with a few exceptions) don't make sense at all, and the jokes in them fall completely flat. They're not good anti-jokes either. If someone said something like it in a social situation it would be followed by an awkward silence.The vibe check and the time spent were really cool though. Super interesting. I would have loved to see those expanded.I don't mean to be negative. The project is cool. I just wish it would put its focus on the valuable parts, rather than the things it is weak at. I guess this is my 45 % pedantic, 25 % contrarian, 20 % analytical self speaking.
comments.content_cn:
与许多人不同，我并不觉得这特别有趣。
- 漫画的裁剪方式很奇怪，而且存在台词归属错误。
- 它称我为某个错误观点的“极端主义者”（我确实在很多方面很极端，但绝不是关于Haskell）。
- 它声称我认为“任何软件故障都只是设计错误”，这完全误解了我提出的观点。
- 文中还出现了“零食碗的几何平均数”这类在英语中毫无意义的表述。
我感觉它只是抓取了一些关键词，然后按照自己对那些关键词的刻板印象随意发挥，并没有真正花心思去理解我的想法。一个成功的吐槽需要吐槽者投入时间、精力和心思去了解被吐槽的对象。而这篇文章在这方面显得太过肤浅。
其中关于2026年和2035年的预测（除了少数例外）完全说不通，里面的笑话也一点不好笑。它们甚至算不上合格的反笑话。如果在社交场合有人说类似的话，接下来只会是尴尬的沉默。
不过，氛围检查和时间花费的部分真的很酷，超级有趣。我本来很期待看到这些部分能进一步展开。
我并非有意挑剔。这个项目本身很酷。我只是希望它能将重点放在有价值的部分，而不是它不擅长的方面。我想这大概是我那45%的学究气、25%的逆反心理和20%的分析型人格在发言吧。

comments.author: kianN
comments.content:
An aside that I do want to mention here because it is a really unique way for many people to interface with LLMs: many commenters mention the model over indexing on a few comments they made that do not necessarily reflect of the broader themes of their writing. This is not any issue in the author’s engineering but an inherent issue in LLMs. The reason it is so noticeable in this case is because the subject matter is extremely familiar to the user: themselves.LLMs consistently misrepresent information in this exact same way in, more critical applications. Because they are often employed on datasets that engineers and potentially end users are not deeply familiar with, the results often seem exceptional.Disclaimer via my HN wrapped: 
“The Anti LLM Manifesto
You will write a 5,000-word blog post on why a single Bayesian prior is more 'sentient' than GPT-6, and it will be ignored because the summary was generated by a 3B parameter model.”
comments.content_cn:
这里我想特别提一点，因为对许多人来说这是与大型语言模型互动的独特方式：不少评论者提到，模型过度关注他们发表的少数评论，而这些评论未必能反映他们写作的宏观主题。这并非作者工程上的问题，而是大型语言模型固有的缺陷。之所以在此案例中如此明显，是因为主题对用户来说极为熟悉：他们自己。在更关键的应用场景中，大型语言模型也始终以同样的方式曲解信息。由于它们通常处理工程师和潜在终端用户并不深入了解的数据集，结果往往显得异常出色。通过我的Hacker News年度总结声明如下：
“反大型语言模型宣言
你将撰写一篇5000字的博文，论述为何单个贝叶斯先验比GPT-6更具‘感知力’，而这篇博文会被忽视，因为其摘要是由一个30亿参数模型生成的。”

posts.author: amarcheschi
posts.title_cn: 意大利竞争管理局因滥用市场支配地位对苹果处以1.15亿美元罚款
posts.abstract: 该讨论围绕意大利竞争管理局因苹果滥用市场支配地位对其处以1.15亿美元罚款的事件展开。核心争议在于罚款的合理性与动机。部分用户支持罚款，认为苹果应用商店的垄断行为长期损害竞争，尤其是其应用追踪透明度政策被指限制第三方开发者。也有用户指出，欧洲政府频繁对美国科技巨头罚款，可能出于财政需求而非真正维护法律，批评此举缺乏建设性，反映了保护主义倾向。讨论中提到，罚款金额对苹果的巨额利润影响甚微，因此有观点质疑处罚的实际威慑力。尽管存在分歧，但社区普遍认同科技巨头市场权力过大的问题需要监管，只是在监管方式和动机上存在不同立场。

posts.title: A year of vibes
posts.author: lumpa
posts.title_cn: "一年的氛围"
posts.abstract:
该讨论围绕“氛围编程”这一核心话题展开，探讨开发者使用AI编程工具（如LLM）时的体验与挑战。社区普遍认同AI辅助编程能提升效率，但传统代码协作工具（如GitHub PR和Git）在追踪AI生成代码的决策过程上存在不足，许多用户希望PR能包含提示词以方便审查。

主要争议点集中在两方面：一是工具改进方向，有人认为应增强PR信息以追溯AI的修改逻辑，也有用户指出开发者自身应充分理解代码变更，而非依赖提示词；二是人机关系，部分用户提到与AI工具互动可能产生类社交依赖，虽感不适却难以避免，体现了对技术融入工作生活的复杂感受。此外，有开发者从实践角度指出，现有测试方法难以评估AI生成功能的“用户体验感”，需新的质量评估方式。整体上，讨论既认可AI编程的价值，也反思其对开发流程与人际互动的深层影响。

comments.author: simonw
comments.content: I really feel this bit:> With agentic coding, part of what makes the models work today is knowing the mistakes. If you steer it back to an earlier state, you want the tool to remember what went wrong. There is, for lack of a better word, value in failures. As humans we might also benefit from knowing the paths that did not lead us anywhere, but for machines this is critical information. You notice this when you are trying to compress the conversation history. Discarding the paths that led you astray means that the model will try the same mistakes again.I've been trying to find the best ways to record and publish my coding agent sessions so I can link to them in commit messages, because increasingly the work I do IS those agent sessions.Claude Code defaults to expiring those records after 30 days! Here's how to turn that off: https://simonwillison.net/2025/Oct/22/claude-code-logs/I share most of my coding agent sessions through copying and pasting my terminal session like this: https://gistpreview.github.io/?9b48fd3f8b99a204ba2180af785c8... - via this tool: https://simonwillison.net/2025/Oct/23/claude-code-for-web-vi...Recently been building new timeline sharing tools that render the session logs directly - here's my Codex CLI one (showing the transcript from when I built it): https://tools.simonwillison.net/codex-timeline?url=https%3A%...And my similar tool for Claude Code: https://tools.simonwillison.net/claude-code-timeline?url=htt...What I really want it first class support for this from the coding agent tools themselves. comments.author: vunderba
comments.content:
When I find myself in a situation where I’ve been hammering an LLM and it keeps veering down unproductive paths - trying poor solutions or applying fixes that make no difference but eventually we do arrive at the correct answer, the result is often a massive 100+ KB running context.To help mitigate this in the future I'll often prompt:  “Why did it take so long to arrive at the solution? What did you do wrong?”

Then I follow up with:  “In a single paragraph, describe the category of problem and a recommended approach for diagnosing and solving it in the future.”

I then add this summary to either the relevant MD file (CHANGING_CSS_LAYOUTS.md, DATA_PERSISTENCE.md, etc) or more generally to the DISCOVERIES.md file, which is linked from my CLAUDE.md under:  - When resolving challenging directives, refresh yourself with: docs/DISCOVERIES.md - it contains useful lessons learned and discoveries made during development.

I don't think linking to an entire commit full of errors/failures is necessarily a good idea - feels like it would quickly lead to the proverbial poisoning of the well.
comments.content_cn:
当我发现自己处于反复尝试大型语言模型却不断陷入无效路径的情况时——比如尝试糟糕的解决方案或应用毫无作用的修复，但最终我们还是得到了正确答案，结果往往是产生了超过100KB的运行上下文。为了在未来缓解这个问题，我通常会这样提问：“为什么花了这么长时间才找到解决方案？你做错了什么？”

接着我会追问：“请用一段话描述问题的类型，并为未来的诊断和解决推荐一种方法。”

然后我会把这个总结添加到相关的MD文件中（例如CHANGING_CSS_LAYOUTS.md、DATA_PERSISTENCE.md等），或者更一般地添加到DISCOVERIES.md文件中。这个文件在我的CLAUDE.md中有链接，位于以下部分：- 当处理具有挑战性的指令时，请查阅：docs/DISCOVERIES.md - 它包含了开发过程中学到的有用经验和发现。

我认为链接到充满错误/失败的整个提交记录不一定是个好主意——感觉这很快就会导致所谓的“污染源头”。

comments.author: mritchie712
comments.content: tacking on to the "New Kind Of" section:New Kind of QA: One bottle neck I have (as a founder of a b2b saas) is testing changes. We have unit tests, we review PRs, etc. but those don't account for taste. I need to know if the feature feels right to the end user.One example: we recently changed something about our onboarding flow. I needed to create a fresh team and go thru the onboarding flow dozens of times. It involves adding third party integrations (e.g. Postgres, a CRM, etc.) and each one can behave a little different. The full process can take 5 to 10 minutes.I want an agent go thru the flow hundreds of times, trying different things (i.e. trying to break it) before I do it myself. There are some obvious things I catch on the first pass that an agent should easily identify and figure out solutions to.New Kind of "Note to Self": Many of the voice memos, Loom videos, or notes I make (and later email to myself) are feature ideas. These could be 10x better with agents. If there were a local app recording my screen while I talk thru a problem or feature, agents could be picking up all sorts of context that would improve the final note.Example: You're recording your screen and say "this drop down menu should have an option to drop the cache". An agent could be listening in, capture a screenshot of the menu, find the frontend files / functions related to caching, and trace to the backend endpoints. That single sentence would become a full spec for how to implement the feature.
comments.content_cn:
接续“新型”板块内容：

新型质量保证：作为B2B SaaS的创始人，我面临的一个瓶颈是测试变更。我们虽然编写了单元测试、进行代码审查等，但这些无法评估用户体验。我需要知道功能对最终用户来说是否感觉合适。

例如：我们最近调整了用户引导流程。我需要创建新团队并反复体验引导流程数十次。这个过程涉及添加第三方集成（如Postgres、CRM等），每个集成的表现可能略有不同，完整流程可能需要5到10分钟。

我希望在亲自测试前，能有一个智能代理将流程运行数百次，尝试不同操作（比如试图破坏流程）。有些明显问题我在首次测试时就能发现，智能代理应该能轻松识别并找到解决方案。

新型“自我备忘录”：我录制的语音备忘录、Loom视频或笔记（之后会邮件发给自己）很多都是功能创意。如果借助智能代理，这些记录的效果能提升十倍。如果有个本地应用在我阐述问题或功能时录制屏幕，智能代理就能捕捉各种背景信息来完善最终记录。

例如：当你录制屏幕时说“这个下拉菜单应该有个清除缓存的选项”，智能代理可以实时监听，截取菜单截图，找到与缓存相关的前端文件/函数，并追踪到后端接口。这一句话就能转化为完整的功能实现方案。

comments.author: theptip
comments.content: A really interesting point that keeps coming up in discussions about LLMs is “what trade-offs need to be re-evaluated”> I also believe that observability is up for grabs again. We now have both the need and opportunity to take advantage of it on a whole new level. Most people were not in a position where they could build their own eBPF programs, but LLMs canOne of my big predictions for ‘26 is the industry following through with this line of reasoning. It’s now possible to quickly code up OSS projects of much higher utility and depth.LLMs are already great at Unix tools; a small api and codebase that does something interesting.I think we’ll see an explosion of small tools (and Skills wrapping their use) for more sophisticated roles like DevOps, and meta-Skills for how to build your own skill bundles for your internal systems and architecture.And perhaps more ambitiously, I think services like Datadog will need to change their APIs or risk being disrupted; in the short term nobody is going to be able to move fast enough inside a walled garden to keep up with the velocity the Claude + Unix tools will provide.UI tooling is nice, but it’s not optimized for agents.
comments.content_cn:
关于大语言模型讨论中反复出现的一个非常有趣的观点是："哪些权衡需要重新评估？"我也认为可观测性领域将迎来新的机遇。我们现在既有需求也有机会在全新层面上利用它。过去大多数人难以自行构建eBPF程序，但大语言模型改变了这一现状。

我对2026年的重要预测是：行业将沿着这一思路持续推进。如今快速开发出效用更高、深度更强的开源项目已成为可能。大语言模型已能出色处理Unix工具——那些通过精简API和代码库实现有趣功能的小型程序。

我认为我们将见证小型工具（及其使用封装技能）的爆发式增长，特别是在DevOps等复杂领域，同时会出现用于构建内部系统架构专属技能组合的元技能工具。更具雄心的设想是：像Datadog这类服务商可能需要调整其API架构，否则将面临颠覆风险。短期内，任何封闭生态系统内的开发速度都难以跟上Claude与Unix工具组合所能提供的迭代效率。

UI工具固然不错，但它并非为智能体场景而优化设计。

comments.author: tavavex
comments.content: I've always used "proper" sentences for LLMs since day 1. I think I do a good job at not anthropomorphizing them. It's just software. However, that doesn't mean you have to use it in the exact same ways as other software. LLMs are trained on mostly human-made texts, which I imagine are far more rich with proper sentences than Google search queries. I don't doubt that modern models will usually give you at least something sensible no matter the query, but I always assumed that the results would be better if the input was more similar to its training data and was worded in a crystal-clear manner, without trying to get it to fill the blanks. After all, I'm not searching for web pages by listing down some disconnected keywords, I want a specific output that logically follows from my input.
comments.content_cn: 从第一天起，我就一直对大型语言模型使用"规范"的句子。我认为自己在避免拟人化方面做得不错——它终究只是软件。但这并不意味着你必须以与其他软件完全相同的方式使用它。大型语言模型的训练数据主要来自人类创作的文本，这些文本中的规范句式远比谷歌搜索查询要丰富得多。我毫不怀疑现代模型通常能对任何查询给出至少合理的回应，但我始终认为，如果输入内容更接近其训练数据、表述清晰明了，而不是试图让它填补空白，结果会更好。毕竟，我不是通过罗列一些不连贯的关键词来搜索网页，而是希望根据我的输入得到逻辑连贯的特定输出。

comments.author: Arainach
comments.content: > It always confuses me when I see shared chats with prompts and interactions that have proper capitalization, punctuation, grammar, etc.I've tried and fail to write this in a way that won't come across as snobbish but it is not the intent.It's a matter of standards.  Using proper language is how I think.  I'm incapable of doing otherwise even out of laziness. Pressing the shift key and the space bar to do it right costs me nothing.  It's akin to shopping carts in parking lots.  You won't be arrested or punished for not returning the shopping cart to where it belongs, you still get your groceries (the same results), but it's what you do in a civilized society and when I see someone not doing it that says things to me about who they are as a person.
comments.content_cn: 每次看到那些分享的聊天记录里，无论是提问还是互动都规规矩矩地使用大写、标点和正确语法时，我总感到困惑。我试图用不显得自命清高的方式表达这一点，但确实没有那个意思。这关乎标准。使用规范语言是我的思维习惯，即便偷懒也改不掉。按一下Shift键和空格键正确书写，对我而言毫不费力。这就像停车场里的购物车——不把购物车放回原处不会让你被捕或受罚，你照样能买到东西（结果相同），但这体现了一个文明社会的行为准则；当我看到有人不这么做时，便不禁对其为人产生看法。

comments.author: kashyapc
comments.content: > It helps a lot if you treat LLMs like a computer program instead of a human.If one treats an LLM like a human, he has a bigger crisis to worry about than punctuation.> It always confuses me when I see shared chats with prompts and interactions that have proper capitalization, punctuation, grammar, etcNo need for confusion.  I'm one of those who does aim to write cleanly, whether I'm talking to a man or machine.  English is my third language, by the way.  Why the hell do I bother?  Because you play like you practice!  No ifs, buts, or maybes. You start writing sloppily because you go, "it's just an LLM!"  You'll silently be building a bad habit and start doing that with humans.Pay attention to your instant messaging circles (Slack and its ilk): many people can't resist hitting send without even writing a half-decent sentence.  They're too eager to submit their stream of thought fragments.  Sometimes I feel second-hand embarrassment for them.
comments.content_cn:
如果你把大语言模型当作计算机程序而非人类来对待，会有很大帮助。若将其视为人类，你需要担心的危机可比标点符号严重得多。

看到那些分享的聊天记录里，提示词和互动都带有规范的大小写、标点、语法等，总让我感到困惑。其实不必困惑。我就是那种无论对人还是对机器都力求表达清晰的人。顺便说一句，英语是我的第三语言。那我为何如此费心？因为习惯成自然！没有借口、没有但是、没有或许。如果你想着“反正只是和大语言模型对话！”就开始马虎书写，你会在不知不觉中养成坏习惯，并逐渐在与人交流时也这样。

观察你的即时通讯圈子（Slack之类）：很多人总忍不住还没写出一句像样的话就点击发送。他们太急于把零碎的想法片段抛出来。有时我甚至为他们感到尴尬。

comments.author: cesarb
comments.content: It makes sense if you think of a prompt not as a way of telling the LLM what to do (like you would with a human), but instead as a way of steering its "autocomplete" output towards a different part of the parameter space. For instance, the presence of the word "mysql" should steer it towards outputs related to MySQL (as seen on its training data); it shouldn't matter much whether it's "mysql" or "MYSQL" or "MySQL", since all these alternatives should cluster together and therefore have a similar effect.
comments.content_cn: 如果你不把提示词看作是指示大语言模型做什么的方式（就像对人那样），而是将其视为引导其“自动补全”输出转向参数空间的不同部分，那么这就说得通了。例如，“mysql”这个词的出现应该引导其输出与MySQL相关的内容（正如在其训练数据中所见）；无论是“mysql”、“MYSQL”还是“MySQL”，这些变体都应该聚集在一起，因此效果相似。

comments.author: skydhash
comments.content: Very much this. My guess is that common words like article have very impact as they just occurs too frequently. If the LLM can generate a book, then your prompt should be like the index of that book instead of the abstract.
comments.content_cn: 确实如此。我猜测像“文章”这类常见词汇的影响力有限，因为它们出现得过于频繁。如果大型语言模型能够生成一本书，那么你的提示词应该更像是那本书的目录，而非摘要。

comments.author: nosianu
comments.content: We don't need automation for that, we "achieve" that through our processes already. Specifically, software creation processes of large teams with many changing developers over long periods. Example (but they are not the only one): https://news.ycombinator.com/item?id=18442941 -- changing or adding anything becomes increasingly burdensome.I would like to post that every time somebody warns of the dangers of AI for maintainability. We are long past that point, long before AI. Businesses made the conscious decision that it is okay for quality to deteriorate, they'll squeeze profits from it for as long as possible and then they assume something new has already come along anyway. The few business still relying in that technical-debt-heavy product are still offered service, for large fees.AI is just more of the same. When it becomes too hard to maintain they'll just create a new software product. Pretty much like other things in the material world work too, e.g. housing, or gadgets, or fashion. AI actually supports this even more, if new software can be created faster than old code can be maintained that's quite alright for the money-making oriented people. It is harder to sell maintenance than something new at least once every decade anyway.
comments.content_cn: 我们并不需要自动化来实现这一点，我们已经通过流程"达成"了这种状态。具体来说，就是那些由大型团队、在漫长周期内经历频繁人员更替的软件开发流程。举个例子（但他们并非唯一）：https://news.ycombinator.com/item?id=18442941 ——任何修改或新增都变得越来越困难。每当有人警告人工智能对可维护性的危害时，我都想发表这个观点。我们早已超越了那个临界点，远在人工智能出现之前。企业早已有意识地接受了质量下降的事实，他们会尽可能从中榨取利润，并假设总会有新事物出现。少数仍依赖这些技术债务沉重的产品的企业，仍能获得服务——只要支付高昂费用。人工智能不过是这种模式的延续。当维护变得过于困难时，他们就会直接开发新的软件产品。这很像物质世界的运行方式，比如房屋、电子产品或时尚潮流。人工智能实际上进一步助长了这种现象——如果新软件的开发速度比维护旧代码更快，这对以盈利为导向的人来说完全可行。毕竟，推销维护服务远比每隔十年推出一次新产品要困难得多。

comments.author: btown
comments.content: With great love to your comment, this has the same vibes as the infamous 2007 Dropbox comment: https://news.ycombinator.com/item?id=9224I'd also argue that the context for an agent message is not the commit/release for the codebase on which it was run, but often a commit/release that is yet to be set up. So there's a bit of apples-to-oranges in terms of release tagging for the log/trace.It's a really interesting problem to solve, because you could in theory try to retroactively find which LLM session, potentially from days prior, matches a commit that just hit a central repository. You could automatically connect the LLM session to the PR that incorporated the resulting code.Though, might this discourage developers from openly iterating with their LLM agent, if there's a panopticon around their whole back-and-forth with the agent?Someone can, and should, create a plug-and-play system here with the right permission model that empowers everyone, including the Programmer-Archaeologists (to borrow shamelessly from Vernor Vinge) who are brought in to "un-vibe the vibe code" and benefit from understanding the context and evolution.But I don't think that "just dump it in clickhouse" is a viable solution for most folks out there, even if they have the infrastructure and experience with OTel stacks.
comments.content_cn:
非常喜欢你的评论，这让我想起了2007年那个著名的Dropbox评论：https://news.ycombinator.com/item?id=9224。我认为代理消息的上下文并非基于其运行代码库的提交/发布版本，而往往是针对尚未设置的提交或发布。因此，在日志/追踪的发布标记方面存在一些不恰当的比较。

这确实是个值得探讨的有趣问题，因为理论上可以尝试追溯匹配几天前的LLM会话与刚刚进入中央仓库的提交。你可以自动将LLM会话与合并了生成代码的PR关联起来。但这是否会阻碍开发者与LLM代理进行开放迭代，如果他们的整个交互过程都处于全景监控之下？

有人可以且应该创建一个即插即用的系统，配备恰当的权限模型，让所有人受益——包括那些被请来“破解氛围代码”的程序员考古学家（借用Vernor Vinge的说法毫不脸红），他们将从理解上下文和演变过程中获益。但我认为“直接扔进ClickHouse”对大多数人来说并非可行方案，即使他们具备OTel栈的基础设施和经验。

posts.title_cn: 迪士尼幻想工程发布新一代机器人角色奥拉夫
posts.abstract:
该讨论围绕迪士尼最新推出的奥拉夫机器人展开，核心话题聚焦于娱乐机器人技术的进展及其实际应用前景。多数用户对迪士尼的研发能力表示赞赏，认为其“活角色”技术令人印象深刻，尤其对机器人展现的拟人化动作和互动潜力感到兴奋。

讨论中提到，有用户结合亲子体验，指出这类展示能激发儿童对科技的兴趣，带来寓教于乐的效果。但也有人对技术落地持怀疑态度，认为此类原型往往难以投入乐园日常运营，多限于宣传用途。争议点体现在技术细节上：部分用户称赞机器人行走能力突破，同时有人批评其外观缝合工艺粗糙；另有观点比较不同公司的机器人成果，例如提及环球影城的机械龙更优，或认为迪士尼蜘蛛侠特技机器人更值得关注。

关于未来展望，用户意见各异：有人期待LLM与机器人结合早日普及日常生活，亦有人幽默推测娱乐公司或将成为尖端机器人的主要推动者。整体而言，社区虽认可迪士尼的技术创新，但对其实用性、工艺完善度及行业竞争态势存在不同看法。

comments.author: shadowgovt
comments.content: Disney's had a notable amount of success with that formula. Turtle Talk with Crush arguably saved The Living Seas pavilion space at EPCOT, and it's executed via a digital puppet operated by a behind-the-scenes cast member doing their best Crush voice.I sincerely doubt that what makes that experience magical can be replicated with AI in my lifetime. Too much contextual knowledge, too much detail in the nuances of human-human interaction, and too much je ne sais quoi in the timing of getting humor right. I've seen Turtle Talk deal with a particularly excited young person leaning on Crush's "tank" by having Crush look at him and go "Hey little minnow... One of the big humans behind you is gonna come scoop you up. I've seen it happen, lots of times!" You can program that interaction in, but the domain-space of having an interaction for every possible "improv moment" might be outside the bounds of what the next several generations of learning models are capable of.... or I'm wrong, in which case I look forward to enjoying robo-Seinfeld in the retirement home.
comments.content_cn: 迪士尼凭借这一模式取得了显著成功。可以说，《与海龟克鲁什对话》拯救了EPCOT乐园的"活海"展馆，其呈现方式是由幕后演员操作数字木偶，并尽力模仿克鲁什的嗓音进行互动。我真诚地怀疑，这种体验之所以神奇，在我有生之年能否被人工智能复制。这需要太多情境知识、太多人际互动的细节把握，以及精准幽默时机的微妙把控——那种难以言传的精妙。我曾目睹《与海龟克鲁什对话》处理一个特别兴奋的年轻人倚靠克鲁什"水箱"的场景：克鲁什看着他说："嘿，小鱼苗……你身后那个大个子人类要来把你捞走啦。我见过这种事，好多次了！"这种互动固然可以编程实现，但要为每个可能的"即兴瞬间"都设计交互模式，其可能性空间或许超出了未来几代学习模型的能力范围……当然也可能是我错了，若是如此，我期待在养老院里欣赏机器人版的《宋飞正传》。

comments.author: shadowgovt
comments.content: This is one of those situations where that's legitimately difficult. Kevin Perjurer is quite a good documentarian, and there's very little trimmable fat on the four-hour product if you want to keep in all the points he made.gkoberger's peer comment is a pretty good summary. Another interesting point is that these technologies can benefit the brand bottom-line even when they don't make it into the park, because part of Disney's brand is "tomorrow today." Even when things are one-offs, they become one-offs that people stitch into the legend of the parks (in both the retelling and in their own memories), which gives them a larger-than-life feel; your visit might not include one of the "living characters," and statistically it probably won't.... but it might. And if it does, you'll never forget it.Personal anecdote / example: I stopped in at the "droid factory" in the Star Wars: Galaxy's Edge area of Disney World a few years back. They had several bits of merch for sale including one life-size R2-D2, inert. I took a close look at the R2 because it was an impressive bit of work. Turned around to look at a rack of t-shirts. And was, therefore, startled as hell to hear a bwoop behind me, turn around, and see that it had followed me out of its charging receptacle and was staring at me. It was not at all inert; it was a very impressive operational remote-control replica.The cast member behind the counter was doing his best to hold down his grin and not give me a "GOTCHA" look. posts.author: pretext
posts.title_cn: GLM-4.7：编码能力进阶
posts.abstract: 该帖子围绕GLM-4.7模型的编码能力进展展开讨论。社区普遍认为该模型在编码任务中表现良好，有人指出其通过保留多轮对话中的思考块来提升复杂任务处理能力，也有用户称赞其在工具调用和API集成方面的实用性。部分用户通过实际使用体验进行比较，认为GLM-4.7与Claude Sonnet水平相近，但尚未达到Opus或GPT-5.2的高度。讨论中提到模型未在对比图表中包含Gemini 3.0 Pro，这引发了一些疑问。此外，用户对模型在模拟软件开发环境中的自我纠错能力表示期待。整体上，社区肯定GLM-4.7的进步，尤其在编码代理和长上下文任务中，但对不同模型间的性能差异仍存在不同看法。

posts.title: Coarse is better
posts.author: _dain_
posts.title_cn: 粗优于细
posts.abstract:
该讨论围绕AI图像生成模型Midjourney v2与Nano Banana Pro的风格差异展开。核心争议在于新版模型是否在艺术表现上有所退步。作者认为旧版模型能生成更具艺术感的图像，而新版过于精确和商业化。

有用户指出，问题在于训练数据的不同：旧版将“大英博物馆”理解为美学风格，新版则直接生成博物馆内的场景。有人认为新版作为商业工具更实用，能快速产出可用图像，与旧版的艺术定位不同。也有用户批评作者对艺术的理解肤浅，强调AI本身缺乏艺术创作所需的意识和意图。

讨论中提到，部分用户认为标题过于模糊，未能准确反映内容。共识在于，两者是不同用途的工具，新版侧重实用性和精确性，旧版则更注重美学风格。分歧主要集中在对“艺术性”的定义以及模型优化方向的评价上。

They each serve their purpose.This analysis is just noise. Yawn.Ironically, even an LLM with its fake reasoning capabilities can point out the issue with the prompts if you ask it to critique this article.

comments.author: BoredPositron

posts.title: Show HN: WalletWallet – create Apple passes from anything
posts.content: I got my Apple developer certificate and built a simple app to solve a problem I had. One shop I buy from doesn't have Apple Wallet passes. Since you need signed certificates to build these very simple things, I created a minimal app that signs them. It's available if you need it too. It won't scan cards with AI - you manually enter the barcode, which I think makes it less prone to error.
posts.author: alentodorov
posts.title_cn: 展示 HN：WalletWallet – 从任意内容创建苹果通行证
posts.content_cn: 我拿到了苹果开发者证书，并构建了一个简单的应用来解决我遇到的一个问题。我常光顾的一家店铺没有苹果钱包通行证。由于构建这些非常简单的功能需要签名证书，我创建了一个极简应用来为它们签名。如果你也需要，这个应用可供使用。它不会用AI扫描卡片——你需要手动输入条形码，我认为这样更不容易出错。
posts.abstract:
该帖子讨论了一款名为WalletWallet的工具，它允许用户手动输入条形码信息来创建Apple Wallet通行证，以解决部分商家不提供电子卡券的问题。核心话题围绕该工具的实用性、隐私安全及技术限制展开。

多数用户肯定其便捷性，认为手动输入条形码虽不如AI扫描自动化，但能减少识别错误，尤其适用于实体会员卡数字化。同时，隐私问题成为焦点，有用户指出通行证数据需发送至服务器进行苹果证书签名，引发对数据安全的担忧；多人建议实现本地处理以规避风险。此外，讨论中提到部分条形码格式（如Codebar）不被Apple Wallet支持，限制了工具适用范围。

社区共识在于肯定工具解决了特定需求，尤其在处理无电子化服务的商家卡券时表现实用。分歧主要体现在对隐私保护程度的期待，以及是否应优先支持更多条形码格式。也有用户批评工具创新性不足，质疑其开发价值。整体上，讨论呈现对工具功能肯定与对隐私、兼容性优化的期待并存的态度。

comments.author: thwarted
comments.content: > It won't scan cards with AI - you manually enter the barcode, which I think makes it less prone to error.This is a very interesting sentence.I interpret this sentence as saying that manually entering a barcode is less error prone than letting AI do it, that AI would have an unacceptable margin of error (and this is probably an accurate assessment).But you don't need AI to find or read barcodes. Finding and reading barcodes is a reasonably mature technology that has existed long before AI.Barcodes exist as a fast, machine readable data transfer format meant to avoid data entry errors by avoiding manual data entry, and yet you've implemented manual entry in order to avoid errors?Now, if one of the constraints you've put on your implementation is that it work only in the browser and you don't want to have to download a large barcode scanning library to the browser, then it makes sense to implement manual entry. But that has nothing to do with AI.That being said, there are some barcode reading apps that can be used to prompt for a scan from a web page, and you get the barcode payload back. I've used an app called "bineye" on Android (source on GitHub) that works like this. This helps avoid error prone manual entry and gets the full barcode payload (many barcodes store/encode more information than the human readable text printed next to them).
comments.content_cn:
它不会用AI扫描卡片——你需要手动输入条形码，我认为这反而降低了出错概率。这句话很有意思。我的理解是，手动输入条形码比让AI操作更不容易出错，AI的误差率可能高到无法接受（这个判断或许很准确）。但识别或读取条形码根本不需要AI。条形码识别技术相当成熟，早在AI出现之前就已存在。条形码本身就是一种快速、机器可读的数据传输格式，旨在避免人工输入导致的数据错误，而你们却为了减少错误而采用手动输入？

如果你们设定的限制条件是仅限浏览器端运行，且不希望向浏览器下载庞大的条形码扫描库，那么采用手动输入确实合理。但这与AI毫无关系。

值得一提的是，有些条形码读取应用可以配合网页调用扫描功能并返回条码数据。我在安卓上用过一款叫"bineye"的应用（GitHub开源）就是这样工作的。这既能避免容易出错的手动输入，又能获取完整的条码数据（许多条形码存储/编码的信息量远超过旁边印刷的人类可读文本）。

posts.title: The Illustrated Transformer
posts.author: auraham
posts.title_cn: 图解Transformer
posts.abstract:
该帖子围绕《图解Transformer》一文展开讨论，核心话题是Transformer架构的理解价值及其在实际工作中的重要性。多数用户肯定文章的可视化效果对学习有帮助，有人认为掌握内部原理虽在日常应用LLM时作用有限，但能提供深层背景知识。也有用户指出，深入理解Transformer机制有助于在AI工程领域脱颖而出，成为顶尖人才。

讨论中提到分歧点：一方认为Transformer内部原理会像编译器内部一样逐渐变得次要，工程师更关注使用而非开发；另一方则强调理解核心机制（如Q、K概念）对专业成长至关重要。同时，有用户反映Transformer相关教程过于泛滥，可能造成理解混乱。社区普遍认同该文章是优质学习资源，部分用户还推荐了其他补充材料。此外，有用户延伸提问Transformer是否已完全取代传统深度学习架构，但未展开深入讨论。

comments.author: libraryofbabel
comments.content: I read this article back when I was learning the basics of transformers; the visualizations were really helpful. Although in retrospect knowing how a transformer works wasn't very useful at all in my day job applying LLMs, except as a sort of deep background for reassurance that I had some idea of how the big black box producing the tokens was put together, and to give me the mathematical basis for things like context size limitations etc.I would strongly caution anyone who thinks that they will be able to understand or explain LLM behavior better by studying the architecture closely. That is a trap. Big SotA models these days exhibit so much nontrivial emergent phenomena (in part due to the massive application of reinforcement learning techniques) that give them capabilities very few people expected to ever see when this architecture first arrived. Most of us confidently claimed even back in 2023 that, based on LLM architecture and training algorithms, LLMs would never be able to perform well on novel coding or mathematics tasks. We were wrong. That points towards some caution and humility about using network architecture alone to reason about how LLMs work and what they can do. You'd really need to be able to poke at the weights inside a big SotA model to even begin to answer those kinds of questions, but unfortunately that's only really possible if you're a "mechanistic interpretability" researcher at one of the major labs.Regardless, this is a nice article, and this stuff is worth learning because it's interesting for its own sake! Right now I'm actually spending some vacation time implementing a transformer in PyTorch just to refresh my memory of it all. It's a lot of fun! If anyone else wants to get started with that I would highly recommend Sebastian Raschka's book and youtube videos as way into the subject: https://github.com/rasbt/LLMs-from-scratch .Has anyone read TFA author Jay Alammar's book (published Oct 2024) and would they recommend it for a more up-to-date picture?
comments.content_cn: 当初学习Transformer基础知识时我读过这篇文章，其中的可视化图表确实很有帮助。虽然回想起来，了解Transformer的工作原理在我日常应用大语言模型的工作中并没有太大实际用处——它更像是一种深层背景知识，让我对那个生成词元的巨大黑箱如何构成有基本概念，并为我理解上下文长度限制等问题提供了数学基础。我必须强烈提醒那些认为通过深入研究架构就能更好理解或解释大语言模型行为的人：这是个思维陷阱。当今顶尖的大型模型展现出大量非平凡的涌现现象（部分源于强化学习技术的广泛应用），这些能力在该架构刚问世时几乎无人预料。早在2023年，我们多数人就曾信心十足地断言，基于大语言模型的架构和训练算法，它们永远无法在新颖的编程或数学任务上表现出色——事实证明我们错了。这警示我们应当谨慎谦逊，不能仅凭网络架构来推断大语言模型的工作原理和能力边界。要真正回答这类问题，可能需要深入探查顶尖大模型的内部权重参数，但遗憾的是，这通常只有大型实验室的"机制可解释性"研究人员才能实现。尽管如此，这仍是篇不错的文章……

comments.author: holtkam2
comments.content: I agree and disagree. In my day job as an AI engineer I rarely if ever need to use any “classic” deep learning to get things done. However, I’m a firm believer that understanding the internals of a LLM can set you apart as an gen AI engineer, if you’re interested in becoming the top 1% in your field. There can and will be situations where your intuition about the constraints of your model is superior compared to peers who consider the LLM a black box. I had this advice given directly to me years ago, in person, by Clem Delangue of Hugging Face - I took it seriously and really doubled down on understanding the guts of LLMs. I think it’s served me well.I’d give similar advice to any coding bootcamp grad: yes you can get far by just knowing python and React, but to reach the absolute peak of your potential and join the ranks of the very best in the world in your field, you’ll eventually want to dive deep into computer architecture and lower level languages. Knowing these deeply will help you apply your higher level code more effectively than your coding bootcamp classmates over the course of a career.
comments.content_cn:
我既同意也不同意。作为一名AI工程师，在日常工作中我几乎不需要使用任何"经典"深度学习就能完成任务。然而，我坚信，如果你有志成为所在领域的前1%，理解大语言模型的内部原理能让你在生成式AI工程师中脱颖而出。在某些情况下，你对模型局限性的直觉理解，会比那些将大语言模型视为黑箱的同行更具优势。多年前，Hugging Face的Clem Delangue曾当面给予我这个建议——我认真对待，并加倍努力理解大语言模型的核心机制。事实证明这让我受益匪浅。

对于任何编程训练营的毕业生，我也会给出类似建议：确实，仅掌握Python和React就能走得很远，但若要充分发挥潜力、跻身全球顶尖行列，最终仍需深入钻研计算机体系结构和底层语言。在职业生涯中，对这些深层知识的掌握将帮助你比训练营的同窗更高效地运用高级代码。

comments.author: ActorNightly
comments.content: People need to get away from this idea of Key/Query/Value as being special.Whereas a standard deep layer in a network is matrix * input, where each row of the matrix is the weights of the particular neuron in the next layer, a transformer is basically input* MatrixA, input*MatrixB, input*MatrixC (where vector*matrix is a matrix), then the output is C*MatrixA*MatrixB*MatrixC. Just simply more dimensions in a layer.And consequently, you can represent the entire transformer architecture with a set of deep layers as you unroll the matricies, with a lot of zeros for the multiplication pieces that are not needed.This is a fairly complex blog but it shows that its just all matrix multiplication all the way down. https://pytorch.org/blog/inside-the-matrix/.
comments.content_cn: 人们需要摒弃那种将键/查询/值视为特殊概念的想法。网络中的标准深层结构是矩阵乘以输入，其中矩阵的每一行代表下一层特定神经元的权重；而变换器本质上是输入乘以矩阵A、输入乘以矩阵B、输入乘以矩阵C（这里向量乘以矩阵的结果仍是矩阵），然后输出是C乘以矩阵A乘以矩阵B乘以矩阵C。这仅仅是层中维度更为复杂而已。因此，当你展开这些矩阵时，可以用一组深层结构来表示整个变换器架构，其中大量不需要的乘法部分用零填充。这篇博客相当复杂，但它表明这一切归根结底都是矩阵乘法。https://pytorch.org/blog/inside-the-matrix/。

comments.author: roadside_picnic
comments.content: It's just a re-invention of kernel smoothing. Cosma Shalizi has an excellent write up on this [0].Once you recognize this it's a wonderful re-framing of what a transformer is doing under the hood: you're effectively learning a bunch of sophisticated kernels (though the FF part) and then applying kernel smoothing in different ways through the attention layers. It makes you realize that Transformers are philosophically much closer to things like Gaussian Processes (which are also just a bunch of kernel manipulation).0. http://bactra.org/notebooks/nn-attention-and-transformers.ht...
comments.content_cn: 这不过是核平滑的重新包装。Cosma Shalizi对此有精彩论述[0]。一旦理解这一点，就能以全新视角看待Transformer的底层机制：本质上是通过前馈网络学习一系列复杂核函数，再通过注意力层以不同方式进行核平滑运算。这种认识让人意识到，从哲学层面看Transformer更接近高斯过程这类方法（后者同样基于核函数操作）。0. http://bactra.org/notebooks/nn-attention-and-transformers.ht...

comments.author: throw310822
comments.content: I might be completely off road, but I can't help thinking of convolutions as my mental model for the K Q V mechanism. Attention has the same property of a convolution kernel of being trained independently of position; it learns how to translate a large, rolling portion of an input to a new "digested" value; and you can train multiple ones in parallel so that they learn to focus on different aspects of the input ("kernels" in the case of convolution, "heads" in the case of attention).
comments.content_cn: 我的理解可能完全偏离了正轨，但我忍不住将卷积作为理解K Q V机制的心理模型。注意力机制具备与卷积核相同的特性：训练时不受位置限制；它学习如何将输入中一个较大、连续的部分转化为新的“消化”值；并且可以并行训练多个注意力头，使它们学会关注输入的不同方面（卷积中称为“核”，注意力中称为“头”）。

comments.author: energy123
comments.content: An example of why a basic understanding is helpful:A common sentiment on HN is that LLMs generate too many comments in code.But comment spam is going to help code quality, due to the way causal transformers and positional encoding works. The model has learned to dump locally-specific reasoning tokens where they're needed, in a tightly scoped cluster that can be attended to easily, and forgetting about just as easily later on. It's like a disposable scratchpad to reduce the errors in the code it's about to write.The solution to comment spam is textual/AST post-processing of generated code, rather than prompting the LLM to handicap itself by not generating as much comments.
comments.content_cn: 一个说明基础理解为何有帮助的例子：Hacker News上常见的观点是大型语言模型在代码中生成过多注释。但由于因果变换器和位置编码的工作原理，注释泛滥实际上有助于提升代码质量。模型学会了在需要的地方集中放置局部推理标记，形成易于关注且后续可轻松遗忘的紧密集群。这就像一次性草稿纸，能减少即将编写代码的错误。解决注释泛滥的方法是对生成代码进行文本/抽象语法树后处理，而非要求大型语言模型自我限制减少注释生成。

comments.content: I think there are two key differences though: 1) Attention doesn't doesn't use fixed distance-dependent weight for the aggregation but instead the weight becomes "semantically-dependent", based on association between q/k. 2) A single convolution step is a local operation (only pulling from nearby pixels), whereas attention is a "global" operation, pulling from the hidden states of all previous tokens. (Maybe sliding window attention schemes muddy this distinction, but in general the degree of connectivity seems far higher).There might be some unifying way to look at things though, maybe GNNs. I found this talk [1] and at 4:17 it shows how convolution and attention would be modeled in a GNN formalism[1] https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=J1YCdVogd14

comments.content: Seconding this, the terms "Query" and "Value" are largely arbitrary and meaningless in practice, look at how to implement this in PyTorch and you'll see these are just weight  matrices that implement a projection of sorts, and self-attention is always just self_attention(x, x, x) or self_attention(x, x, y) in some cases, where x and y are are outputs from previous layers.Plus with different forms of attention, e.g. merged attention, and the research into why / how attention mechanisms might actually be working, the whole "they are motivated by key-value stores" thing starts to look really bogus. posts.title: Scaling LLMs to Larger Codebases
posts.author: kierangill
posts.title_cn: 将大型语言模型扩展至更大规模代码库
posts.abstract: 该讨论围绕“将大语言模型应用于更大规模代码库”这一核心话题展开。社区观点多元，既有对技术进步的肯定，也有对当前局限性的担忧。有人认为随着模型能力提升，通过特定提示框架（如让智能体解释现有功能）能有效处理复杂代码任务；也有用户指出，尽管工具不断改进，但模型在面对用户专业知识领域时仍常出现幻觉与错误。讨论中提到，工程实践依然关键，例如将大型项目分解为有向图结构、在工具链中实施权限隔离等策略受到关注。分歧点主要集中在：一方担忧过度依赖模型生成的“生产级代码”可能导致开发者学习能力下降和系统整体脆弱性；另一方则强调优化工作流程（如避免冗余提示以节省token成本）的重要性。普遍共识是，当前LLM作为辅助工具价值显著，但无法替代开发者对代码的深入理解与必要的人工监督。

comments.author: mstank
comments.content: As the models have progressively improved (able to handle more complex code bases, longer files, etc) I’ve started using this simple framework on repeat which seems to work pretty well at one shorting complex fixes or new features.[Research] ask the agent to explain current functionality as a way to load the right files into context.[Plan] ask the agent to brainstorm the best practices way to implement a new feature or refactor. Brainstorm seems to be a keyword that triggers a better questioning loop for the agent. Ask it to write a detailed implementation plan to an md file.[clear] completely clear the context of the agent —- better results than just compacting the conversation.[execute plan] ask the agent to review the specific plan again, sometimes it will ask additional questions which repeats the planning phase again. This loads only the plan into context and then have it implement the plan.[review & test] clear the context again and ask it to review the plan to make sure everything was implemented. This is where I add any unit or integration tests if needed. Also run test suites, type checks, lint, etc.With this loop I’ve often had it run for 20-30 minutes straight and end up with usable results. It’s become a game of context management and creating a solid testing feedback loop instead of trying to purely one-shot issues.
comments.content_cn: 随着模型能力持续提升（能够处理更复杂的代码库、更长的文件等），我开始循环使用这个简单框架，它在快速解决复杂问题或实现新功能方面表现优异。[研究]要求智能体解释现有功能，以此将相关文件载入上下文。[规划]要求智能体以最佳实践方式构思新功能实现或重构方案。"头脑风暴"似乎是触发智能体更优提问循环的关键词。请其将详细实施方案写入markdown文件。[清空]彻底清除智能体上下文——这比单纯压缩对话效果更好。[执行方案]请智能体重新审视具体方案，有时它会提出补充问题从而重启规划阶段。此步骤仅将方案载入上下文，随后由其执行方案。[审查测试]再次清空上下文，要求其核查方案确保所有内容均已落实。此阶段我会根据需要添加单元测试或集成测试，同时运行测试套件、类型检查、代码规范检测等。通过这个循环流程，我经常连续运行20-30分钟并获得可用成果。这已演变为上下文管理的策略游戏，通过建立完善的测试反馈循环来替代单纯追求一次性解决问题。

comments.author: jarjoura
comments.content: As of Dec 2025, Sonnet/Opus and GPTCodex are both trained and most good agent tools (ie. opencode, claude-code, codex) have prompts to fire off subagents during an exploration (use the word explore) and you should be able to Research without needing the extra steps of writing plans and resetting context. I'd save that expense unless you need some huge multi-step verifiable plan implemented.The biggest gotcha I found is that these LLMs love to assume that code is C/Python but just in your favorite language of choice. Instead of considering that something should be written encapsulated into an object to maintain state, it will instead write 5 functions, passing the state as parameters between each function. It will also consistently ignore most of the code around it, even if it could benefit from reading it to know what specifically could be reused. So you end up with copy-pasta code, and unstructured copy-pasta at best.The other gotcha is that claude usually ignores CLAUDE.md. So for me, I first prompt it to read it and then I prompt it to next explore. Then, with those two rules, it usually does a good job following my request to fix, or add a new feature, or whatever, all within a single context. These recent agents do a much better job of throwing away useless context.I do think the older models and agents get better results when writing things to a plan document, but I've noticed recent opus and sonnet usually end up just writing the same code to the plan document anyway. That usually ends up confusing itself because it can't connect it to the code around the changes as easily.
comments.content_cn:
截至2025年12月，Sonnet/Opus和GPTCodex均已训练完成，大多数优质智能体工具（如opencode、claude-code、codex）都具备在探索过程中触发子智能体的提示机制（使用“探索”这一表述），用户应能直接进行研究，无需额外编写计划或重置上下文。除非需要执行大型多步骤可验证计划，否则建议避免这类开销。我遇到的最大陷阱是，这些大语言模型总倾向于假设代码基于C/Python语言范式，即使你指定了其他编程语言。它们不会考虑将功能封装为对象以维持状态，而是编写五个函数，通过参数在各函数间传递状态。同时，它们通常会忽略周边大部分现有代码，即使阅读这些代码本有助于识别可复用部分。最终你得到的至多是重复堆砌且结构混乱的代码。

另一个常见问题是Claude通常会忽略CLAUDE.md文件。我的应对方法是先提示它阅读该文件，再指令其进行探索。遵循这两条规则后，它通常能在单一上下文中较好地完成修复、添加新功能等任务。近期版本的智能体在丢弃无用上下文方面表现更佳。

我认为旧版模型和智能体在编写计划文档时效果更好，但注意到最近的Opus和Sonnet版本即便编写计划文档也往往产生雷同代码……

comments.author: __MatrixMan__
comments.content: I'm interested to see where we'll land re: organizing larger codebases to accommodate agents.I've been having a lot of fun taking my larger projects and decomposing them into directed graphs where the nodes are nix flakes.  If I launch claude code in a flake devshell it has access to only those tools, and it sees the flake.nix and assumes that the project is bounded by the CWD even though it's actually much larger, so its context is small and it doesn't get overwhelmed.Inputs/outputs are a nice language agnostic mechanism for coordinating between flakes (just gotta remember to `nix flake update --update-input` when you want updated outputs from an adjacent flake).  Then I can have them write feature requests for each other and help each other test fixtures and features.  I also like watching them debate over a design, they get lazy and assume the other "team" will do the work, but eventually settle on something reasonable.I've been running with the idea for a few weeks, maybe it's dumb, but I'd be surprised if this kind of rethinking didn't eventually yield a radical shift in how we organize code, even if the details look nothing like what I've come up with. comments.author: EastLondonCoder
comments.content: I’ve ended up with a workflow that lines up pretty closely with the guidance/oversight framing in the article, but with one extra separation that’s been critical for me.I’m working on a fairly messy ingestion pipeline (Instagram exports → thumbnails → grouped “posts” → frontend rendering). The data is inconsistent, partially undocumented, and correctness is only visible once you actually look at the rendered output. That makes it a bad fit for naïve one-shotting.What’s worked is splitting responsibility very explicitly:• Human (me): judge correctness against reality. I look at the data, the UI, and say things like “these six media files must collapse into one post”, “stories should not appear in this mode”, “timestamps are wrong”. This part is non-negotiably human.• LLM as planner/architect: translate those judgments into invariants and constraints (“group by export container, never flatten before grouping”, “IG mode must only consider media/posts/*”, “fallback must never yield empty output”). This model is reasoning about structure, not typing code.• LLM as implementor (Codex-style): receives a very boring, very explicit prompt derived from the plan. Exact files, exact functions, no interpretation, no design freedom. Its job is mechanical execution.Crucially, I don’t ask the same model to both decide what should change and how to change it. When I do, rework explodes, especially in pipelines where the ground truth lives outside the code (real data + rendered output).This also mirrors something the article hints at but doesn’t fully spell out: the codebase isn’t just context, it’s a contract. Once the planner layer encodes the rules, the implementor can one-shot surprisingly large changes because it’s no longer guessing intent.The challenges are mostly around discipline:• You have to resist letting the implementor improvise.• You have to keep plans small and concrete.• You still need guardrails (build-time checks, sanity logs) because mistakes are silent otherwise.But when it works, it scales much better than long conversational prompts. It feels less like “pair programming with an AI” and more like supervising a very fast, very literal junior engineer who never gets tired, which, in practice, is exactly what these tools are good at.

我最终形成的工作流程与文章中提到的指导/监督框架基本一致，但额外增加了一个对我至关重要的分离层。我目前正在处理一个相当混乱的数据处理流程（Instagram导出文件→缩略图→分组“帖子”→前端渲染）。这些数据不一致，部分缺乏文档说明，且正确性只有在实际查看渲染输出时才能判断。这使得它不适合简单的单次处理方案。

有效的做法是明确划分职责：
- 人类（我）：根据实际情况判断正确性。我查看数据和用户界面，提出诸如“这六个媒体文件必须合并为一个帖子”“故事不应在此模式下显示”“时间戳有误”等判断。这部分必须由人类完成，没有商量余地。
- LLM作为规划师/架构师：将这些判断转化为不变条件和约束（例如“按导出容器分组，分组前不得扁平化处理”“Instagram模式必须仅考虑media/posts/*目录”“后备方案绝不能产生空输出”）。这个模型负责结构推理，而非编写代码。
- LLM作为实施者（类Codex模式）：接收来自规划阶段的极其枯燥、高度明确的指令提示。指定具体文件、具体函数，无需解释，没有设计自由。它的任务是机械式执行。

关键在于，我不会让同一个模型同时决定“应该改变什么”和“如何改变”。当我尝试这样做时，返工量会急剧增加，尤其是在那些真实情况存在于代码之外（真实数据+渲染输出）的流程中。

comments.author: pron
comments.content: > Here's a LLM literacy dipstick: ask a peer engineer to read some code they're unfamiliar with. Do they understand it? ... No? Then the LLM won't either.Of course, but the problem is the converse: There are too many situations where a peer engineer will know what to do but the agent won't. This means that it requires more work to make a codebase understandable to a human than it does to make it understandable to an agent.> Moving more implementation feedback from human to computer helps us improve the chance of one-shotting... Think of these as bumper rails. You can increase the likelihood of an LLM reaching the bowling pins by making it impossible to land in the gutter.Sort of,  but this is also a little similar to claiming that P = NP. Having a an efficient way to reliably check if a solution is correct is not the same at all as a reliable way to find a solution. It's the theory of computation that tells us that it probably isn't. The likelihood may well be higher yet still not high enough. Even though theoretically NP problems are strictly easier than EXPTIME ones, in practice, in many situations (though not all) they are equally intractable.In fact, we can put the claim to the test: there are languages, like ATS and Idris, that make almost any property provable and checkable. These languages let the programmer (human or machine) position the "bumper rails" so precisely as to ensure we hit the target. We can ask the agent to write the code, write the proof of correctness, and check it. We'd still need to check that the correctness property is the right one, but if the claim is correct, coding agents should be best at writing code, accompanied by correctness proofs, in ATS or Idris. Are they?Obviously, mileage mauy vary dependning on the task and the domain, but if it's true that coding models will get significantly better, then the best course of action may well be, in many cases, to just wait until they do rather than spend a lot of effort working around their current limitations, effort that will be wasted if and when capabilities improve. And that's the big question: are we in for a long haul where agent capabilities remain roughly where they are today or not?
comments.content_cn:
这里有一个衡量大语言模型理解能力的简单方法：让一位同行工程师阅读一段他们不熟悉的代码。他们能理解吗？……不能？那么大语言模型也无法理解。当然，但问题恰恰相反：有太多情况下同行工程师知道该怎么做，而智能体却不会。这意味着让代码库对人类可理解所需的工作量，比让它对智能体可理解要多得多。

将更多实现反馈从人类转移到计算机，有助于提高我们一次成功的概率……可以将其视为保龄球道的护栏。通过让大语言模型不可能落入沟槽，你可以增加它击中球瓶的可能性。某种程度上是这样，但这也有点类似于声称P=NP。拥有一种高效可靠的方法来检查解决方案是否正确，与可靠地找到解决方案的方法完全不同。计算理论告诉我们，这很可能不是一回事。可能性或许更高，但仍不够高。尽管理论上NP问题严格比EXPTIME问题简单，但在实践中，在许多情况下（虽然不是全部）它们同样棘手。

事实上，我们可以对这个说法进行验证：有些语言，如ATS和Idris，几乎可以让任何属性都可证明和可检查。这些语言让程序员（无论是人类还是机器）能够如此精确地设置“护栏”，以确保我们击中目标。我们可以要求智能体编写代码，编写正确性证明……

sure you understand how we work together. Make sure you never proceed beyond your own understanding.> Always consult the user anytime you reach a judgment call rather than just proceeding. Anytime you encounter unexpected behavior or errors, always pause and consider the situation. Rather than going in circles, ask the user for help; they are always there and available.> And always work from understanding; never make assumptions or guess. Always look at the code first, search online for documentation, and find the answer to  things. > 在继续之前，请阅读本地和全局的Claude.md文件，确保你理解我们如何协作。确保永远不要超越自己的理解范围进行操作。

> 每当遇到需要判断的情况时，务必咨询用户而不是自行决定。每当遇到意外行为或错误时，务必暂停并审视情况。与其原地打转，不如向用户寻求帮助；他们始终在场并愿意提供支持。

posts.author: ofalkaed
posts.title_cn: 用于音乐的编程语言
posts.abstract: 该讨论围绕“用于音乐创作的编程语言”这一核心话题展开。社区成员分享了多种相关工具和项目，并探讨了其应用与特点。有人认为Strudel等实时编码工具展示了惊人的流畅性与互动性，也有用户指出Orca这类空间编程语言为音乐制作提供了独特范例。讨论中提到，Max、Pure Data、Supercollider和Csound等是较为流行且功能强大的选择，部分用户还分享了个人项目如Glicol或创意应用如用SQL生成音乐。尽管观点多样，但社区普遍认同编程语言能够拓展音乐创作的边界，并为实时表演与算法作曲带来新的可能性。分歧主要体现在对不同工具的偏好上，例如有人推崇专业环境的集成性，也有人青睐实验性或小众语言的创新表达。

However, the moving average can suffice as a simple filter.```I wonder if there's a way to implement the FFT using subqueries and OVER/partitioning? 2. Sampling/resampling - given clickhouse should do quite well with storing raw sample data, being able to sample/resample opens up a whole world of wavetable synthesis algorithms, as well as vocal editing, etc.Honestly, although the repo's approach is basic, I think the overall approach is wonderful and have wanted to be able to use SQL to write music for a while. I've spent a lot of time writing music in trackers, and being able to use SQL feels like it would be one of the few things that could spiritually be a successor to it. I've looked at other live coding languages, many of which are well built and have been used by talented people to make good music (such as Tidal, Strudel, etc). But all of it seems like a step down in language from SQL. I'd rather have their capabilities accessible from SQL than have to use another language and its limitations just to get those capabilities.Food for thought -- thanks for the interesting and thoughtful work!
